developer_response:
So glad you liked it!

Our earlier adventure, Primordia, is less of a head trip, but it’s the same team, same spirit, so you might enjoy it. Plus it’s often on sale for like 3 bucks, so it’s a cheap gamble. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198058216580', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1658491229}
review: Took about 5 hours to finish at a leisurely pace without using a walkthrough or hints. A decent point and click if you like themes like psychology, death and depression.
developer_response: Thanks—appreciate the review and we’re glad you liked it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197989490113', 'num_games_owned': 1796, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1657927661}
review:
Strangeland is a surrealistic point-and-click (PnC) adventure game with horror elements. There's a lot that I liked, and some things that I think could be improved upon. I'll mention some quick points first before getting into the story (the big one).

[b]Graphics[/b]: The graphics are quite souped-up and impressive relative to your typical PnC. It uses this sort of purple and gold color palette, which I thought was an interesting choice. It's not a style you see very often, but it works really well here due to Strangeland being a dreamlike, nightmarish construct. There is an unsettling sense of dread throughout the game -- you'll encounter lots of odd characters and disturbing visual sequences that are quite visceral and macabre in nature. They really nail the atmosphere on this one.

[b]Music/Sound[/b]: I wish the music stood out a little more, but it's very fitting nonetheless. Ambient, creepy, and foreboding. I liked the sound design, and thought the voice acting was very good, too. They did a great job on all those fronts. Even as I type this, I can still hear all those crazy sounds from the Dark Thing ringing in my head, haha. 

[b]Puzzles[/b]: In general, the puzzles are mostly fair. There isn't too much of the crazy try-everything-everywhere logic that you may associate with certain games in the PnC genre. Things have a reasonably logical flow to them. If you get stuck, you can walk over to the in-game telephone booth, dial 0, and get a hint for what to do next. Great idea! That being said, there are a couple lateral-thinking style puzzles that I thought were cool, but felt out of place in a game like this. One puzzle in particular (the missing telephone number) might be very frustrating for people who don't speak English natively.

There are a number of old PnC games where certain puzzles had multiple solutions, which is always fun -- and I was excited to find a shooting gallery puzzle early on that had multiple ways to tackle it. However, it seemed like a one-time deal, as there weren't any more multi-solution puzzles after that, as far as I could recall (either that or I simply missed the alternative solutions to certain things). There is a Tarot card puzzle that sorta-kinda introduces an element of choice, but it's not really a puzzle and there's no real penalty for "getting it wrong", nor any reason to get it right either (though there is a Steam achievement for it). 

Edit: As per the developer response below, I was incorrect about there not being more multi-solution puzzles. I simply missed the other solutions!

[b]Game Mechanics[/b]: I found the base game mechanics very fluid and easy. In addition to the usual inventory screen, you can use your mouse's scroll wheel to cycle through inventory items for quick use, which is super convenient. You can also double-click to fast travel, press escape to bypass cutscenes, etc - I like that the devs respect the player's time by giving them the option to speed things up if they want. Too many games force unskippable cutscenes and dialogue (which drives me up the wall), so I greatly appreciate that they get it right here.

[b]Story[/b]: This game is jam-packed with references - it's absolutely bursting at the seams. Some aspects are quite on-the-nose, while others are so subtle and esoteric that I was surprised to find them in a video game. It's sort of like trying to read Shakespeare for the first time in high school, where you'll either blitz right through and overlook 95% of the details, or slow down and get overwhelmed by everything that's actually going on. There's probably plenty that I missed - but even still, I noticed tons of easter eggs and shoutouts to famous works of literature, books, stories, movies, poems, plays, quotes, religious texts, mythologies, and even other video games. To elaborate here would take up several paragraphs - maybe pages - to get into it all, simply due to sheer volume. I cannot believe how many references and throwbacks were tucked away in here. I wouldn't say it's all necessary in order to understand the game, but the associated context can be useful.

In most PnCs, the dialogue tends to be a little more expository, so you can move through it quickly without missing much - but that's definitely not the case here. The game may alienate some players who go through a dialogue sequence or cutscene too briskly, not knowing what the hell just happened. That sort of thing can lead to detachment from the story if the confusion lingers on for too long. While I enjoyed all these details for the most part, it's a bit heavy-handed, and might benefit from a little more coherence and focus in order to better keep the player grounded. Hard to do in a surreal setting for sure, but I think it's needed from time to time so people don't lose their way.

Plot-wise, everything is one giant metaphor for the struggles of processing grief and learning how to find yourself. Various characters seem to represent different aspects of this process -- whether it's throwing oneself into work as a means of robotic dehumanization and trying not to feel, or using dark gallows humor as a coping mechanism, or invoking willful self-delusion and avoidance to forget painful memories altogether. The game does a good job of conveying the accompanying trauma, the total sense of aimlessness and helplessness, the ever-present threat of darkness, the pressure of maintaining memory and how it can evolve into nightmare, the horror of seeing someone you love reduced to something unrecognizable, the constant interjections of self-doubt, the ongoing feelings of guilt and regret, the difficulty of acceptance, and the maddening futility of trying to solve the unsolvable. As someone who has dealt with great loss myself, I found a lot of this game sadly relatable. 

Despite all this attention to detail, the protagonist ("The Stranger") is a bland bowl of oatmeal, comparatively speaking. This poor dude is caught in a whirlwind of shit, and yet we never get much sense that he's actually suffering or frustrated with anything that's happening. Not a knock on the voice acting, but rather his characterization. My ability to relate to this game largely stemmed from my own experiences as a sort of stand-in for what was happening on-screen - but if I didn't have those experiences, I would probably have a hard time empathizing because The Stranger doesn't give you much to latch onto. Most of the interesting bits come from all the wacky and zany creatures you encounter. 

[b]Endings[/b]: I do think the game drops the ball somewhat when it comes to its four endings. Three endings are (depressingly) bleak albeit realistic, and one ending is feel-good Hollywood stuff. Oddly enough, the good ending is the most unrealistic part of this surrealistic game and completely lost me. I think the writer wanted to offer some kind of hopeful outcome to a dismal situation, but for me (and most others I know who've dealt with similar traumas), it doesn't usually work out like that. You learn how to live with the darkness instead -- it never goes away fully. Trying to beat it is what ends up causing the most pain, since it's actually an unstoppable juggernaut, and all you can do is grapple with it, wrestle it, rechannel it, integrate it, draw power from it, etc -- that sort of thing. Games like Celeste deal with this notion so perfectly that it left me teary-eyed, and it's a good example of how to put a positive and realistic spin on a depressing subject -- and I wish Strangeland offered something similar here because there was a ripe opportunity for it.

[b]Overall[/b]: Strangeland is a very well-polished point-and-click adventure game with lots to chew on. I don't think it's for everyone, since some people will be turned off by the endless stream of metaphors, but I think if you're looking for something surreal and abstract, this is a good game to check out.
developer_response:
Thanks so much for the detailed and thoughtful review!

> multi-solution puzzles

Essentially all of the "UI puzzles" have multiple solutions (e.g., teratoma, Feejee Mermaid), and some of the inventory puzzles do, too.

> endings

Fair enough. Certainly my intention was not to suggest that anyone leaves the darkness behind entirely, nor has that been my own experience with tragedy or self-doubt. The game is more about the capacity to go back to living, rather than drifting lifelessly through life because of a cloud of despair. I do think (based on my own experiences) that it is possible for such changes to happen, not through force of will or strength of character but through the intervention of love in its many forms. But it is a very hopeful ending, to be sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068207360', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1657842401}
review:
Strangeland Primordia'ya imza atmış olan Wormwood Studios'un ikinci point & click adventure oyunu. Primordia hafiften Beneath A Steel Sky'ı hatırlatan ama asla taklit olmayan, son derece özgün olmayı başarabilen güzel bir oyundu. Temelinde "belirsiz bir gelecekte" geçen bir bilim kurgu öyküsü yatıyordu. Strangeland arayüz ve oynanış bakımından Primordia'yı takip ediyor. Ancak kesinlikle Primordia'nın devamı değil, çok daha farklı ve orijinal bir oyun. 
Primordia 90'ların ilk yarısının adventure oyunlarına saygı duruşunda bulunan bir oyundu. Strangeland ise klasik point & click adventure oyunu formatını hikayesini anlatmak için araç olarak kullanan bir sanat eseri. Bu sizi korkutmasın çünkü adventure oyunu kılığındaki interaktif "filmlerden" değil bu. Strangeland hala bir adventure oyunu. Hala bilmeceler çözmeniz, tercihler yapmanız, mantığınızı ve zaman zaman da duygularınızı kullanmanız gerekiyor. Ancak bunları üzerinden size görsel, işitsel ve duygusal bir "tecrübe" sunuyor. 
Fazla spoiler vermeden hikayeye değinmem gerekirse, kimliği belirsiz, deli gömleği giydirilmiş bir adam kendini uzay boşluğunun ortasında, bir karnavalın girişinde buluyor, kapıdan içeri giriyor ve kendini bir olaylar zincirinin parçası olarak buluyor. 
Bir adventure klasiği olan Sanitarium'u oynamış olanlar az çok neler olduğunu tahmin edebilirler, bir kişinin geçmişi, üzüntüleri, kayıpları ve suçluluk duygusu ile yüzleşmeye çalışması söz konusu. Ancak Sanitarum'da ana karakterin anılarından beslenen rüyalarda çıkış aramamızın aksine, burada rüyalarda değil, metafizik bir ortamda, tabiri caizse ana karakterin "ruhunda" dolanıyoruz. Bu bakımdan David Lynch'in Eraserhead, Inland Empire ya da asla gerçekleştiremediği Ronnie Rockett filmleri ile benzer olduğunu söyleyebilirim. Oyundaki tüm karakterler ve tüm mekanlar tek bir "ruhun" farklı dışavurumlarından ibaret. Gördüğümüz görüntüler de Max Ernst'in "içsel manzara" tablolarına benziyor. 
Oyun daha en başında sizi bilmeceler konusunda uyarıyor, oyunda istediğiniz zaman girişteki telefonu kullanarak ipucu alabileceğinizi ve bilmeceleri asla deneme-yanılma yöntemiyle çözmeye uğraşmamanız gerektiğini söylüyor. Bence bu yapımcıların derdinin basit bir adventure oyunu yapmak olmadığını gösteren en önemli kanıt. Oyun herhangi bir yerde takılmanızı, ne yapmanız gerektiğini bilmeden boş boş dolanmanızı değil, hikayeden kopmadan oyunu sürdürmenizi, ana karakterin tecrübesinin bir parçası olmaya devam etmenizi istiyor. 
Yukarıda karakterlerin tümünün aslında tek bir kişinin içsel dünyasının yansımaları olduğundan bahsetmiştim. Karakterler ve mekanların altında haliyle semboller yatıyor, bu sembollerin bir kısmı bariz iken bir kısmı ise daha muğlak ve derin. Böylece oyun Sanitarium gibi "aa meğer gerçek hayatta bu olmuş" şeklinde bir çözümleme ile asla banal hale gelmiyor. Bize sadece ipuçları sunuluyor. 
Oyunun bir yerinde karşımıza David Cronenberg tarafından yaratılmışa benzeyen şekilsiz et yığını bir yaratık çıkıyor. Bu yaratık karnavalda absürd biçimde adeta bir revü kızı olarak sergileniyor. Gövdesindeki kadın cinsel organını andıran ağızları ovalayarak bize ilerlememiz için gerekli olan bir nesneyi veriyor. Açıkçası bunu gördükten sonra oyun için kanaat notum zaten 10 üzerinden 10 oldu. 
Harika görselliği, nefis müzikleri, ürkünç atmosferi bir kenara, sadece böyle cesur bir denemede bulunabildikleri için bile Wormwood Studios'u kutlamak gerekir. Evet Strangeland herkese göre değil, evet Primordia 2'yi bekleyenleri şoke edecek ama bu oyun "bilgisayar oyunu formatı sanatsal bir düzlem olarak nasıl kullanılabilir?" sorusunun yanıtını veren benzersiz ve hafızalardan kolay kolay silinmeyecek bir başyapıt. Mutlaka şans verin.
developer_response: Bu gerçekten güzel bir inceleme -- başlı başına harika bir eser. Birçok şey söyleyebilirim ya da birçok kez "teşekkür ederim". Bunun yerine sadece *olmadığını* ifade eden zevki ifade eden satırın "'Aa, gerçek hayatta da olmuş' gibi bir analizi olduğunu" belirteceğim. Böyle bir paralellik olmadığına dair çok şikayet aldık; Kiralık bir oyuncunun bu kadar doğrudan olmamasına sevindim!

author: {'steamid': '76561198012998958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1657214598}
review:
Another excellent PnC adventure game by Wormwood!
Lots of dark and creepy characters and action.
Challenges are tough but if you keep at it and think about the visuals you can work it out. That's the most satisfying part of this game, that I could solve the puzzle with some thought and exploration.
The telephone 'helper' is a great idea. I had to use it a couple of times.
A LOT of thought went into this game and it shows!
Highly recommend!
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it! We're really grateful that you took time to leave a review, too -- matters a lot to indie devs. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198023020656', 'num_games_owned': 1265, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1657420544}
review:
Strangeland es una aventura grafica con algunas cosas bastante positivas y otras no tanto.

- Es una buena aventura grafica para iniciarse, mas que nada por que es casi imposible quedarse atascado, Tiene un sistema de ayuda que si te quedas bloqueado te va dando pistas gradualmente.
- Tiene un arte perturbador, lo cual es bueno y malo a la vez. Si te gusta el estilo, lo disfrutaras. Yo en lo personal no disfruto tanto con la aprensión que me provocaba.
- Es una aventura donde te "mueres" pero no es muy grave, por que en realidad resucitas y no pierdes los objetos, aun asi al principio te da un par de sustos.
- Es tremendamente corta, mas de lo que esperaba.
- Como casi todas las aventuras de Wadjeteye, no tiene traducción al español.

En definitiva, una buena aventura, sino corta. Que puede ser buena para iniciarse si aceptas la estetica grotesca.
developer_response:
Pero, como todas las aventuras de Wormwood Studios (Primordia es nuestra otra), *tendrá* una traducción al español, ¡y pronto! Wadjet Eye tiene una filosofía opuesta a la nuestra: básicamente no les gustan las traducciones, mientras que a nosotros nos encantan, por lo que trabajamos en estrecha colaboración con los traductores para asegurarnos de que se hagan bien.

Desafortunadamente, las traducciones toman tiempo, porque es importante que se hagan bien, a partir de la amistad entre el traductor y el desarrollador y el amor del traductor por el juego. (De lo contrario, traductor = traducidor, como dice el refrán). Si te gusta la traducción al español de Primordia, también debería gustarte esta, aunque tal vez sea incluso más difícil de traducir que Primordia.

De todos modos, ¡muchas gracias por las amables palabras, por jugar nuestro juego y por dejar una reseña!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991638297', 'num_games_owned': 1222, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1656885771}
review:
If you’re looking for a sequel to the exquisite Primordia, you may be sorely disappointed, but if you seek another unique point and click adventure game that goes beyond the usual trappings of the genre, you might just find yourself razzle-dazzled and transfixed all over again by the creative trinity of the twisted minds at Wormwood Studios as I was.

This time around, they deliver a much more personal narrative that feels rather introspective and intimate in comparison to Primordia’s overarching parable of the human condition that, in true sci-fi fashion, seemed to transcend the experiences of an individual and extrapolate them to the whole mankind, or what was left of it in that particular post-apocalyptic setting. Instead, Strangeland is asking you to try and empathize with a plight of a lone and lost husk of a man, driven to his wits' end by a series of tragic events in his life, which I won’t spoil here because deciphering the oft-vague clues and putting  the pieces of this nebulous puzzle together is part of the fun and games at the nightmarish carnival that the protagonist navigates through. It’s very commendable, in fact, that the devs are trusting YOU, the player, to figure things out (mostly) on your own, without spoon-feeding you the RIGHT interpretation, but leaving just enough bits and pieces for you to pick up and come to your own conclusions.

The story, tho far removed from my own life experiences (so far and thankfully so, I'd say), feels very... real is not the right word, perhaps, given the – well… strangeness of the overall premise. But definitely vivid, thought-provoking and evocative. Mark Yohalem’s writing is as eloquent here as it was in Primordia, chock-full of metaphors, literary allusions and references, and while some may find it too vague, high-brow and/or wordy, perhaps, I, for one, think it's very powerful.

Victor Pflug returns with his unmistakable brand of peculiar aesthetics in both art and sound direction. The visuals are distorted, gritty and visceral, whereas the soundscape feels suitably tortured and tormented with a lot of droning tracks and reverb, both very unsettling and effective in burrowing their way into your psyche, even without resorting to any gore and jump-scary cues. 
 
And last but not least, James Spanos’ code and visual effects are a masterclass of what you can squeeze from the limited capabilities of the AGS engine, giving both the writing and the audiovisuals a stable scaffolding to rely on without any noticeable frame drops, which is an impressive feat, given how much is happening on the screen (and no doubt, behind the scenes) at any given time.

Although shorter than Primordia (my initial blind playthrough took me about 6 hours), Strangeland doesn’t lack for content, what with the extensive annotations and dev commentary tracks that give you not only a reason to replay the game with those features enabled, but a lot of insight into the creative process of the aforementioned trio. It’s so substantial, in fact, that my second run lasted for about 9 hours, most of which was spent reading and listening to the various bits of trivia from the devs themselves. Now, that’s what I call bang for my buck.

What about puzzles, the crux of any point and click adventure game, you ask? Well, they’re here, of course, and quite varied at that, both in their mechanics and difficulty. They’re quite logical, even if not immediately obvious; some even offer multiple solutions. The somewhat open-ended layout of the world lends itself to exploration, experimentation and discovery, and if you’re stuck on one particular puzzle, you can usually go elsewhere and tackle a different challenge. And if you’re REALLY stuck, you can always use the in-game hint system seamlessly integrated into the world itself populated by many a twisted version of carnival attractions and a cast of memorable characters, professionally voice-acted by the likes of Abe Goldfarb (whom you may remember as the lovable Crispin from Primordia) and Miranda Gauvin, the staples of Wadjet Eye Games’ VO talent.

All in all, Strangeland is not your typical adventure game but one with a unique vision and voice, asking a lot of the players but also giving them an abundance in return. If you’re up to the task, give it a try and don’t be a stranger. 

(The game is actually ways better than my terrible pun might suggest, so please, disregard it and stop looking at me funny :-P)
developer_response: What a beautiful review -- and particularly thoughtful in the way you acknowledged so many of the contributors to the game! Many, many thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198108071634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1657084414}
review: Great music, and the art work is brilliantly themed.  Possibly the only Point & Click Ive played through where I didn't just turn the music off.  The inventory is accessible on mousewheeling, which is quite nice - most games don't do this.   Puzzles are mostly intuitive, but the game has a well built hint system if you really get stuck,  My only reference to a guide was because there was a an exit to a room I just didn't see (whoops).
developer_response:
Thanks for the kind words!

No matter how much we tried to signpost (literally in many cases!) the exits, it seems like they still get missed from time to time. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198333373531', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1656791232}
review:
I just adore the art in these games. There's also excellent atmosphere and soundtrack, and talented voice acting - though I found there were times where it felt a little off? A bit of Silent Hill energy there, not sure if it was intended.

I'm tempted to hold my tongue about some criticisms, but bearing in mind I have only played it once at the time of writing this; it did feel like characters were set up with a lot more to them than we ever actually find out. And though I greatly appreciate a good mystery, the fact a lot was not unravelled in the end left me feeling dissatisfied regarding the story. 

The experience itself was right up my alley and worthy of a recommendation, however.

Overall, what I got from my playthrough is that Wormwood Studios should get the rights to Dark Seed and remake it.
developer_response: Thanks for the thoughtful and balanced assessment -- glad you liked the game overall!

author: {'steamid': '76561198070453615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 150, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1667483694}
review:
+한국어 번역 지원 확인. 대체로 나쁘지 않고 우려했던 부분은 잘 살린듯하다. 주석과 코멘터리까지 번역된 건 놀라웠음. 어려운 작업을 해주신 제작진과 번역가 분께 찬사를 보냅니다.

눈 앞에서 극단적인 선택을 반복하는 어떤 여인(과 어쩌면 자기 자신)을 구원할 실마리를 찾기 위해 참으로 낯설고 기괴하며, 죄책감과 심리에 대한 은유로 도배한듯한 카니발을 탐험하는 한 이방인의 여정을 담은 어드벤처 게임.

개발사의 전작 Primordia에서 선보였던, 구불구불하고 황량한 그래픽이 다시금 돌아왔다. 차이점이 있다면, 그 특유의 화풍이 로봇과 같은 미생물이 아니라, 사람과 곤충을 비롯한 유기체에 적용되었다는 점. 호오가 갈릴 정도로 매우 그로테스크하니 플레이 전 주의해야만 한다.
게임 전반적으로 비유적 표현이 많이 쓰이기 때문에 영어에 익숙하더라도 스토리를 온전히 이해하기는 어렵지 싶다. 그래도 퍼즐에 연관된 파트는 대체로 무난...하지만 몇 군데 말장난으로 인해 난해한 퍼즐이 몇 개 있다. 이걸 과연 한국어로 알맞게 번역할 수 있을까 싶기도 하다. 그럼에도 불구하고, 퍼즐에 고통받는 순진한 플레이어들을 위해 힌트는 후하게 주어진다. "게임을 진행하시는데 필요한 힌트를 들으시려면 0번을 눌러주십시오".
사운드 연출과 더빙은 훌륭하다. Blackwell 시리즈를 비롯하여 배급사의 여러 게임에서 좋은 연기를 보여준 성우 아저씨의 1인다역 열연을 들을 수 있다.
게임 내 레퍼런스나 의도, 철학 등을 알려주는 주석 모드와 코멘터리 모드가 존재한다. 감격스럽게도 코멘터리 모드에 자막을 지원한다!!! 초장부터 코멘터리가 꽤 긴 관계로 천천히 들어볼 작정이다.
developer_response: 이런 친절한 말씀 정말 감사합니다! 곧 한국어 번역이 나오게 되어 매우 기쁩니다. 번역하기 어려운 게임이지만 번역가는 매우 신중하고 사려깊은 것 같아서 우수한 한국어 플레이어에게 합당한 훌륭한 번역이 되기를 바랍니다!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970667419', 'num_games_owned': 386, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1654354608}
review:
Abstract, every sentence and topic is an allegory style dialogue and pretty simple puzzles make up an overall disappointing narrative from Wadjet Eye Games. 

Wrymwood's Primordia was awesome, and Wadjet's other stuff I like WAAAY better but yeah, ultimately also for 4 hours I would I guess recommend this on a sale if you're a Wadjet fan. If not, you ain't missin' much.
developer_response: Sorry you had such a bad experience (and all the more so that you weren’t able to get a refund). Nothing worse than taking a player’s time and money and then disappointing his expectations. Apologies from the whole team.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106512564', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1654325912}
review:
[h1][b][u]BottomLine at the Top:[/u][/b][/h1] Quite possibly one of the best Point and Click games I have ever played.


[h1][b][u]Intro:[/u][/b][/h1] 
So I bought this when it came out about a year ago, better late than never right!?  I've picked up this habit lately where I buy a certain game I pre-judge as being something I'm probably gonna like and then save it, like purchasing a fine wine, (or usually in my case boxed wine) for a special occasion.  These pandemic years have been a nightmare so not exactly a lot of special occasions floating around.  Instead I've found myself just opening up bottles (...boxes) randomly to pass the time.  Long story short I wish I opened this one sooner as it was an absolutely phenomenal P&C gaming experience. 

-------------------------------------
[h1][b][u]Pros:[/u][/b][/h1]
-------------------------------------
-Hard to pick a first pro here, but I'm going to go with the voice acting.  Super pro all the way, featuring many of the classic Wadjet Eye Games VA's.  This game really solidified my personal belief that having competent and passionate voice acting can really make a good game into a great one. 
-Next up would be the artwork.  Backgrounds, sprite animations, and overall design is concurrently grotesque and beautiful and fits the ambiance of the story perfectly.
-Speaking of ambiance, the music is excellent.
-Next up is the story and writing (which is finding itself in the fourth position here but make no mistake dear reader, the ordering of these pros is simply a limitation of the laws of numbers in this shared delusion we call reality, each one of these could be in the top position.)  In Maslow’s Hierarchy of good P&C games, this is the foundational layer really.  I think all of my enjoyment of this game stems first and foremost from its bizarre set & setting which is fleshed out by some, in my (correct) opinion, great writing.  
-This game also features something that I plan on pointing out every time I see in a P&C game.  Namely, animating an interaction which does not achieve the goal.  The lever to turn off the electrified gate is on the other side of said gate.  "Well perhaps these tiny pebbles will move the lever" said no one in real life but in P&C logic, might work out?  A game with a lazier developer would rely on the old standby: "I can't do that." or "That doesn't make sense"  or "Your desperate Pyro, maybe try thinking of an actual solution".  But this game? nope.  It's going to animate tossing that pebble and THEN mock your dumb choice.  I respect that amount of effort.  Follow it up with using the rat skin you saved after tearing it open to get quarters (this is oddly already not the strangest sentence I've ever written, I've reviewed many P&C games so this is par for the course at this point for me) on the electrified gate, thinking "maybe it might work as an insulator of some kind, even though if I suggested this to myself as a solution in real life I would immediately have myself admitted to the looney bin".  Before that fateful click of the rat skin on the gate, I steel myself for the seemingly inevitable generic "you’re an idiot" response.  But no! Instead, it’s something like "Rat skins would make a poor insulator".  A strange validation for man whose brain has been warped from 30+ years of P&C games.....  
-Wrapping up the pros, we have some general "quality of life" features (double click fast room exit, autosaves, lots of save slots, optional click to advance dialogue box in the settings).  These should really be givens for a P&C game made in the 2020's (any decade really) but you'd be surprised how often these things are still absent from modern P&C's.  
 
-------------------------------------
[h1][b][u]Meh...:[/u][/b][/h1]
-------------------------------------
-No object highlight function.  This actually was a stylistic choice made for the game play.  And there was no real pixel hunting to speak of.  But the backgrounds are so intricate that you end up having this feeling that you’re missing something when you’re really not.  

-------------------------------------
[h1][b][u]Cons:[/u][/b][/h1]
-------------------------------------
-I accidently hit the "X" key while playing and apparently this causes "Abort Mode" in Adventure Game Studio titles which exits the game.  I had a mini heart attack when steam said that it suddenly had some problems connecting to my cloud saves, making me think I lost them all.  Luckily it was not the case.  I blame this on Steam (along with many, many other things in general as we all should) so it should actually be in the "Meh..." category but I actually don't have any real cons for this game, so I put it here for symmetry or something idk.

[h1][b][u]Final Thoughts:[/u][/b][/h1] 
I have many games in my backlog and I picked this one semi-randomly and then proceeded to play it for 4.3 hours straight thru.  This is also going to be my 120th posted game review here on Steam, I enjoy writing them and some of you weirdos enjoy reading them (for which I am [i]extremely [/i] grateful).  As such I try to put some effort into the process which means I actually take notes when playing these games.  Going thru this process 120 times I've noticed some patterns.  Namely, If I don't take a lot of notes, it means that I am so immersed in the game I'm playing that I don’t have time.  For some games I end up taking pages of notes.  I actually counted the number of words I wrote in my notes for this game, and it came to 35.  35 words.  Which I somehow successfully translated into all the eloquent nonsense above ^^^.  When I finish a game and ask myself "is this good" and I say yes, I can think of no better proof of my own opinion’s correctness than my incredibly sparce notes.  All of this is to say that I found this game to have a mastery of immersion.  I wanted to know who this Stranger is. I NEEDED to understand why he was in this Strangeland.  The vagueness of the main character, which even extents to the question of what his name even is, was a subtle but incredibly effective way of increasing this immersion.  Because when your put in the shoes of a mysterious character, you end up filling in the blanks with...well, yourself.  And also, as a person who has lived his entire life facing the challenges of living with my own shadows following me everywhere I go it would be very disingenuous of me to say that I did not identify with the main character.  I know that I am most definitely not the only one who deep down feels that way, and if you dear reader feel the same, I strongly encourage you to try out this game for yourself. 

So, in conclusion, this game is up to the standard I have come to identify with Wadjet Eye Games and Wormwood Studios.  They rightfully, in my mind at least, keep their position as one of if not the best modern P&C gaming developers out there.  They are up there right alongside Sierra Online and LucasArts, and that is not a statement I'd make if I didn't whole heartedly believe it.  

TL;DR : Buy it.

[hr][/hr]

[b][u][i]For more point & click goodness, check out our P&C fan Steam group, The Coalition of Point & Clickers!:[/i][/u][/b]

developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind and detailed review—it means so much to us to read, and obviously really helps bring other people to the game, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198260401907', 'num_games_owned': 1958, 'num_reviews': 320, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1654186547}
review:
[b]Saying that "Strangeland" is just another good point and click adventure game would be a lie. And that's because of its strong identity that makes it stand out from the others both visually and as a structure. Its deformed, surreal world is gorgeous with immersive peculiar atmosphere. Its sound design and music are great. Its multi layer dialogues are exceptionally written offering some deep thoughts and some unforgettable characters. On the other hand it gets too abstract or personal and the main character is a bit dull, so you may find it difficult to attach emotionally to it or find a motivation for your actions. Nevertheless, "Strangeland" is mostly a poetic experience, a philosophical research so unique that you have to try it.


Manometer: 7/10[/b]


The good
- Gorgeous visually with artistic pixel graphics and a unique brown - purple color palette.
- Unforgettable, weird, deformed world seen mostly through fish eye lenses. It's like you're inside a strange dream or at the darkest parts of someone's subconscious. A surreal experience with peculiar dark atmosphere. 
- Great sound design. All these distant mystical sounds enhance even more the atmosphere. Music is also cool and integrates perfectly the background sounds.
- Deep, poetic writing. Although it gets too abstract for my taste and sometimes the story lacks flow you will finally find yourself immersed in an esoteric, cryptic multi layered world full of metaphors and thoughts that manages to reflect fragments of each players' personality. Most of the dialogues are really strong with philosophical values that will often make you pause the game in order to think of them more. Plot's structure has flaws but a weird inner strength too.
- Well crafted characters both visually and as personalities.  Some of them are unforgettable.
- Great voice acting performances. They are not exactly natural but try to enhance more the surreal element.
- Nice, responsive control mechanics. You can click somewhere else to cancel your previous command. There is a double click to instantly jump to the next screen and you can skip dialogues if you have seen them before. Using mouse scroll to choose items from your inventory is a good addition too. A lot of pn'c adventures suffer from slow, unresponsive controls but that's not the case.
- It's well balanced. It has some challenging parts but it usually gives you a good amount of clues in order to figure out the puzzles' solutions. Almost all of them make sense.
- Instead of a dull button on a menu, the hints' system is fantastically integrated into the game and the help comes in multiple stages instead of revealing the whole solution right away.
- Clear cut design to avoid the most irritating thing in pn'c adventure games, pixel hunting.
- Death - resurrection mechanic is an interesting idea as both a punishment and a second chance. It also takes some of the game's linearity away. The reactions after each resurrection are hilarious.
- It offers some hours of unique, indie, surreal point and click adventure experience in a very good price.

The bad
- It's so personal and abstract that you are never sure what's your purpose inside its world. You don't know what you're playing for or what you wish to happen after you solve a puzzle. Yeah, there is that girl but without knowing her you cannot bother much. With no motivation powering your actions it is difficult to get affected emotionally or get passionate so you end up just wandering and admiring the peculiar world and the well written dialogues. Also the turn of events seem to have no particular coherence. It's more like a collection of scattered strong images and thoughts than a single, whole experience with flow, beginning and ending.
- Don't get me wrong. Puzzles are good and well balanced but I feel they are a little bit one-dimensional. They just lack the spark, creativity and variety that Primordia's puzzles had.
- I found the main character a little bit flat. He has no backstory, his personality is nothing unique and he rarely says anything inspiring (unlike most of the npcs). Probably the main character had to perform as a mirror where the players would reflect their own personalities and affairs. Probably he had to be neutral, yet it's difficult to attach emotionally to him.
- Animations are a little bit clunky and at some points they remind me those flash's bone tool days.
- Murmur's puzzle (with the phone number) can be confusing especially if you are not a native English speaker and you 're more focused to the subtitles than the actual voices.
developer_response: Thanks for this beautiful, and thoughtful, review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058616052', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1654141845}
review: This game was fun.  The atmosphere was very well crafted and the writing and dialogue was intriguing.  It was well written enough that I feel bad about my own writing style in this review.  My only complaint is that the game was slightly short, but that's perfectly normal for this style of game.
developer_response:
Your review was lovely -- and all of us really appreciate it!

I don't know if this particular game could've been stretched longer, but I agree that it is on the shorter side for an adventure.  Partly that is because we tried to quality of life features (like fast travel) that remove "filler," and we also tried to minimize design padding like putting puzzles and their solutions as far apart as possible (as some adventure games do).  But it's also just a fairly short game.  It has some replayabilty, though, since there are different paths through, different endings, and a very extensive commentary/annotation mode.  Not the same as game length, though!

author: {'steamid': '76561198024534939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1654158560}
review:
I enjoyed this game and can recommend it. Overall 7/10

Graphics: The art style was excellent. Perfect for the game. Spooky, many memorable images and whilst there is the temptation, in a game like this, to go too surreal or even disturbing and shocking, I think they got the balance just right. 

Sound: As with anything attached to Wadjet Eye Games, the voice acting is top notch. The music helped create a good atmosphere, without being too memorable. I didn't notice it or remember it, which is just as you want with such games. Sound effects were also just right - punchy, created an atmosphere, not jarring or too noticeable. 

Puzzles: Very tricky for a modern point n click given the different types of fans in 2022. If, like me, you grew up on 90s point n clicks - Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle, Gabriel Knight, Simon the Sorceror - I think you'll find the puzzles easy. There are limited numbers of scenes, objects and hotspots which makes it fairly obvious what to do next. There are also two acts and after act one, all objects disappear and there is a fair amount of repetition in act two. I'm not complaining. As a 40 year old with a busy job and family, I don't have the time or energy for those 90s point n clicks anymore. The puzzles were just right for me - all fair and logical and they pushed the story along - but if you are looking for Ron Gilbert puzzles, look elsewhere. 

Story: It seems that the game was very personal to the author. It was full of metaphors and riddles with a fairly ambiguous ending, although it is obviously about mental health of some kind. Probably depression and dealing with trauma. But despite dealing with sensitive themes well, I think it fell down here. And I hate to say it given the love and care that went into it. I don't mind metaphor and ambiguity. But there was too much and too little of the real world. The whole story was about the main character and his struggles. But I didn't know anything about him by the end. Not even anything about the main story - the woman. Who was she? How did they meet? The ending was well done, but how could I really care about this character? Take Fran Bow and Sanitarium. Two games that dealt with mental health and similar themes. They left you wondering (at least Fran Bow did and Sanitarium until the last scene). They were ambiguous and had metaphors. But they were still heavily grounded in the real world too. I suppose it was a design choice - even some flashbacks so you felt connected to the real world might have made a difference. 

Value: Terrific. At the sale price of two cups of Starbucks coffee, this was a steal. 

I wanted to give it a higher score, but in an adventure game, where the puzzles aren't the star (unlike say Thimbleweed Park) story is king. And it just fell short I'm afraid.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed the game—and thank you for leaving a review!

author: {'steamid': '76561197990682975', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1651822590}
review:
My first review- let's go.

I recently started playing though Wadjet Eye games. This is my the second one I've completed, the other being Primordia.

The writing and voice acting are stellar, especially the oracle head. The visuals are crisp and quite disturbing virtually constantly.

The story was good, particularly if you're fans of things like Silent Hill or Jacob's ladder. Themes of guilt, depression, suicide, etc..

My criticisms are that I felt the game was a little sparse and actual explore-able screens. Not sure how many off hand but it seems to be fewer than Primordia (although since its newer the quality is also better).
It was also a bit easier than Primordia for me. I used the ingame hint system a few times (mainly in between sessions to see where i left off) but didn't need to search online at all, and got though every puzzle withing a few minuted of trying.
Whether this is a good thing or a bad thing is up to your personal preference. Some of the puzzles in Primorida were a little senseless in that was..

I think i'll play Unavowed next.
developer_response: Thanks so much for these kind words -- and for making this your first review! (Reviews make a huge difference for indie developers, both inspiration-wise and helping raise their games' profile.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198180439931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1705638852}
review:
Surreal storytelling as a concept is an absolute bitch to concoct; too vague, and your audience will just wander through every word and whim without a care for their meanings; too clear, and your story ceases surreality, becoming a contorted blasphemer of its true self. If one expects to be successful in their creation of a surreal story, the final product must be, at once and at equilibrium, dissonant and lucid; unbound and uncontrived; lobotomized and thought-provoking. And, if that 'one' is you, then my word of grace to you is to take notes from Strangeland. 

This game might be the most consistently satisfying storytelling fever dream I've ever witnessed. Probably the only one, at that. Nonsensical as it may seem, paradoxical as it may gloat itself to be, it is truly a masterfully-crafted work of art, from beginning to end. Characters skew themselves, assign themselves unearthly or downright demented proclivities; places are scattered, nonsensical and repeating, traipsing back and forth, never anchored in time, never feeling quite true, never granting the audience a hint of resolve. And yet, still, no matter how deep you delve, how much dirt on your hands, how grim it all gets, there is always a way forward. Always a way to right your wrongs, wrong your rights, blight the scourge, and brave the maelstrom, no matter the agonies; for her. While the world of Strangeland is entropic and chronically plagued, YOU are the only constant amidst the variables, the only one who can undo the shackles beneath your feet, or seal them.

If this game is an allegory for insanity, guilt, trauma, mourning, mental illness, or all of the above, I can think of no other game that has done it better. This game shattered my standards for this genre, and has set a new bar for P&CA games and media in general. Well done, Wormwood. Here's to hoping I'll find my light someday.
developer_response: You just shared a light with me. Seriously.

author: {'steamid': '76561198414644487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1650870296}
review: as im playing im thinking to myself the writing and themes seem to be a bit psychoanalytically informed and the game namedrops lacan.  im a big fan of pnc adventure games and always welcome new games in the genre since its somewhat niche. the game doesnt disappoint and i highly recommend it both for fans of the genre and anyone curious for a good story. my only complain its a bit too light on puzzles.
developer_response:
Thanks for the kind words -- always nice to get the feedback that *more* puzzles or *harder* puzzles would be better.  The overall pressure on the adventure-game genre is to eschew puzzles, or reduce them to "click to advance."  We've tried to strike a good balance in Primordia and Strangeland, but we probably err on the puzzle-light side.

If you haven't played Resonance, I'd recommend it.  IMO it's the only indie adventure game from the "adventure game renaissance" that really focuses on puzzles.  And then Thimbleweed Park for the only big-budget adventure with a focus on puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198354087608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1652628466}
review:
UPDATE: I have completed the game. This game is OUTSTANDING!  It has many themes of meaning in life, loss, self-denigration, grief! Many of us are chased by a dark thing or "black dog". When experiencing loss we sometimes lose our way. I love that in the game it says: "Dead but not gone". From a Buddhist perspective in many ways this is true. There are ways to honour the passing of those who are gone but have also gone on. We can give to charities in their names, make offerings to them and wish them well. 

I love the successive shedding of masks until they are too heavy, like the stones in the end, we can no longer pick them up or put them on. We need to face ourselves. This game did a beautiful job of this journey until the breathtaking end moments of redemption, acceptance of grief and final flight to the light!

This is after 3.3 hours of play, my early review:
It is quite extraordinary. I love the "carnival" trope which links to horror so comfortably. I am taken back to childhood times, exploring halls of mirrors, going on visceral, seedy "scary" rides in the dark, hearing, feeling, experiencing simultaneously the horror and the knowing that its "just" a ride, a kind of thrilling trick of the senses. The smells and sounds somehow uncomfortable, the way things tug at your unconscious, you know something and this makes the experience all the more thrilling. What is unique, and what I am really enjoying is the developer input you can choose in the settings. I love the elucidation of the sources of quotes and imagery, to personal experiences of loss and grief. In life we do have the possibility of "dying" to an old life through perhaps "a dark night of the soul" and finding redemption in a new, even if only in the form of possibility. This really resonates with me and speaks to my own loss and grief. Also, you can click on a SuperEgo button for more insights. In some ways we are strangers, not only to our own lives, but to the inter-connectedness of life itself.  I will find out if the stranger 'wakes up" and finds some kind of redemption or some kind of acceptance. Yes, indeed he does!
developer_response: Thanks so much for this beautiful (and kind) review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198155758971', 'num_games_owned': 1473, 'num_reviews': 195, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1649773677}
review:
(Çeviri ile ilgili güncellemeler geleceğinden o kısım hakkındaki eleştirimi çıkardım.)

Söylenebilecek çok fazla söz yok gerçekten benden önce her övgü sözü sarf edilmiş. Kendiniz deneyimleyip bu karanlık ve gizemli yolculuğun içinde kendi yerinizi bulmalısınız.

Emeği geçen herkese teşekkürler.

Türkçe dil desteği olması da müthiş bir avantaj ve çeviriyle ilgili geri dönüşüme hızlıca yanıt verdikleri için bir kez daha teşekkür ederim.

 [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32515007-s%25C9%2590%25D7%259Fn%25C9%259Fnsn%25CA%258E/]Küratör Sayfam:   [b] sɐןnɟnsnʎ [/b] [/url] ːcozybethesdaː
developer_response: Ince sözlerin için çok teşekkür ederim. Çeviride bazı aksaklıklar olduğunu duyduğuma üzüldüm. Bu gönüllü bir projeydi ve çoğu zaman işler zorlaştığında gönüllü çeviriler terk ediliyor. Strangeland azim ve sevgisiyle ücretsiz olarak yapıldığı göz önüne alındığında, buradaki proje için sevgi ve takdir dışında hiçbir şeyim yok. İnsanların tespit ettiği sorunları düzeltmek için yama yapabileceğimizi umuyorum, ancak olmasa bile, çevirinin daha fazla oyuncuya kapı açtığı için minnettarım - özellikle sizin gibi oyunumuza bu kadar çocukça davrananlara!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013808975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1649698782}
review:
Very much lives up to its title. Strangeland is the journey of a man who doesn't know what is going on, can't even remember his own name. But the player quickly grasps the situation and really wants to help the Stranger overcome obstacles.
The puzzles were good fun to work out, and if you're stuck there is a hint system.
Heed those words at the beginning; dying may help you to progress
developer_response: Thanks for the lovely review! So glad you enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970653174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1647051889}
review:
A modern-day vision-quest, of a very disturbed young man.

Disturbing imagery?  Check.  Confused narrative mixed with profoundly prophetical word salad? Check.  Eerie, sinister NPCs who subtly mirror aspects of [spoiler]the main character and those he knows[/spoiler]? Ohhh... check.

"Atmospheric" doesn't cut it though - expect all the darker aspects of a deeply-rooted self-loathing, framed and aspected by unique disconnects from traditional mythological aspects.

That said, it's not exactly a game for the casual or faint-of-heart gamer - this is to Myst, as Heart of Darkness is to Moby Dick. (yes, I'm older - GOML)

TL;DR: If you like your games sinister and with mild puzzling, get it - else, avoid.
developer_response: Thank you! The review captures something about the game that is hard to articulate, I think. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198062623579', 'num_games_owned': 745, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1642216421}
review:
It's solid. I personally don't like it as much as this studio's previous game: Primordia. But if the screenshots and trailer interests you then I definitely think it's worth a shot. On a technical and presentation standpoint, this game is phenomenal. And quite honestly the highest quality to have come out of Wadjet Eye's publishing efforts so far. Visuals, music, voice acting, sound design, all of it is absolutely incredible. It's honestly worth a playthrough just to see the sights and hear the sounds.

While I do enjoy the dialogue and the voice acting that delivers it, I feel the part where this kind of lost me a bit was the story. The twist that[spoiler]it's all in the protagonists head. And a sort of twisted escape he's created for himself to avoid facing reality,[/spoiler] is all pretty obvious after not-too long. It just feels like there's never much added to it as time goes on. The scope of why and how[spoiler]he's put himself here[/spoiler] just doesn't really expand beyond[spoiler]his partner having died and him being depressed because of it.[/spoiler] I don't mind when a game's story is a sad one, this one is honestly quite depressing. But I just wish it did a little more to shed some light on things at times. The world and characters here are all so interesting, I'd love to understand them just a bit better. (That scribe under the tree being my personal favorite) But unfortunately the only way you're gonna be able to do that is with the optional captions and dev commentary modes. I understand that the idea is mostly to have things left up to interpretation. But sometimes being too vague or obtuse can make it hard for a player to start forming their own theories and ideas. Or at least, it was for me in this case. It's a subjective thing.

Overall I still recommend it. It's definitely not for everyone, but I found it to still be a very enjoyable journey despite my criticisms. All the puzzles feel fair and I never had to look up a guide for anything. Definitely worth a look if you find it interesting.
developer_response: Glad you gave it a look and enjoyed it! I wouldn’t say there’s a “twist” really; it’s outright stated at the start. But perhaps the game structurally feels like there ought to be a twist, so one plot element or another has to play that role.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066823974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1645738214}
review:
On Dec 29, 2017 @ 11:50pm, I wrote as my review for Primordia 5 years ago, all this time unchanged,
"One of the most beautiful and deep games I have played in a truly long time."

In the time that has passed, I've gained. I've suffered. I've lost. I've grown.         
It is with this perspective that I say again,

One of the most beautiful and deep games I have played in a truly long time.
developer_response: What a beautiful review to read -- seriously, words like these are the lights that keep us going. Deepest gratitude for the support over all these years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129523916', 'num_games_owned': 727, 'num_reviews': 194, 'playtime_forever': 2881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 627, 'last_played': 1700347140}
review:
1990' lı yıllardan beri oldukça geniş bir oyun koleksiyonuna sahibim.
Hayatımın çoğunu Kitaplara, Oyunlara ve Filmlere harcamış biri olarak oyun konusunda oldukça seçiciyimdir.
Bir oyun benim için sadece eğlence aracı ve boşa zamanımı harcayacak bir araç değildir.
Her oyun her film ve her müziğin kendi içinde yaşanmışlıkları olduğuna inanırım.
Yeni oyun firmalarının Online odaklı oyun yapmaları ve bu işi sırf para kazanma aracı olarak görmeleri su götürmez bir gerçek olsa da bazı oyun firmaları ve geliştiriciler halen o eskide kalmış anılarımızı canlandırmaya yetiyorlar.
STRANGELAND da bu yapımlardan biri bir oyun düşünün ki içinde kendine has bir hikayesi olsun ve bir oyun düşünün ki 
şimdiye kadar okumuş olduğumuz romanlara şiirlere ve mitolojiye devamlı atıflarda bulunsun.
Wormwood Studios insanın ruhuna dokunan nadir stüdyolardan biri.
Oyun içi spoiler vermeden size kısa bir anlatım yapacağım.
Hikaye ağırlıklı oyunlardan hoşlanıyorsanız bu oyunu almalısınız.
Kendine has grafikleri ve özgün temalardan hoşlanıyorsanız bu oyunu almalısınız.
Mitolojiye ilginiz varsa bol kitap okuyan biri iseniz.
Tüm bunların ötesinde gerçekten kendinizi bir İnsan olarak görüyorsanız ve sorgulayan bir insansanız bu oyunu kesinlikle oynamalısınız.
Son olarak; 
Oyunu bir kaç kez oynadım ve bitirdim, Kült sayılabilecek kitaplardan ve filmlerden bahsetmesi dolayısı ile neden bu oyunun Türkçe' si
olmasın diye kendi kendime sordum.
Wormwood Studios dan sevgili dostum Mark ile bunun hakkında konuştuk kendisi zorlu bir çeviri olacağını belirtti ve bu konuda anlaştık.
Mark daha önce Türkiye'ye geldiğini ve güzel günler geçirdiğini her fırsatta dile getirdi Kapadokya ya hayran kaldığını ve Türk insanının sıcaklığından bolca bahsetti.
Benim için gerçekten zor bir çeviri oldu ancak, daha önce okumuş olduğum kitaplardan alıntı olduğu için oldukça eğlenerek bu işin üstesinden gelmeye çalıştım ve ortaya güzel bir iş çıktığını düşünüyorum.
Wormwood Studios' dan sevgili Yunanistanlı dostum Spanos ile tanışma fırsatımız da oldu kendisi Alt yazılardaki sorunları büyük bir sabırla halletti.
Türkçe karakter sorunlarını vs büyük bir titizlilikle şikayet etmeden hazırladı.
Türk oyuncu arkadaşlarıma söyleyebileceğim tek şey oyunu deneyimlemeleri ve Wormwood Studios 'ya ellerinden gelen desteği vermeleri.
Mark, Spanos, Pflug ve diğer katkıda bulunanlara sevgi ve saygılarım umarım çok daha güzel yapımlara imza atarlar.
Şimdi gözümü yeni çıkaracakları oyun olan Fallen Gods'a dikiyorum ve büyük bir heyecan ile nelere imza atabileceklerini bir kez daha görmek istiyorum.
Sevgi ve saygılarım ile.
------------------------------                ------------------------                  ----------------------------
Strangeland
Review
It seems as if Strangeland, a game released recently by Wormwood Studios is going to give a unique experience to gamers. This psychologic and exhilarating game will launch you into a one-of-a-kind experience. Let us take a brief look into the game.
A strange man, a foreign land!
As the name indicates, “Strangeland” is indeed a strange game, at the very beginning of the game, we observe a woman drop herself into a well.
Who are we? Who is that woman that threw herself into a well?
When we start the game, a dark atmosphere draws us in. The thematic music and voiceovers allows us to immerse ourselves into the game. We start the game by encountering a clown head with a dark sense of humor. It is worth seeing the reactions we gave while we were writing every word said by a Clerk Crow (Raven) we encountered under a tree, who had lost both its eyes. Speaking of dark humor, we can communicate with everyone, from the Raven, to the clown head in the game. We will need to establish a lot of dialogue to find our way in this land, where we are lost. We even have a payphone in the game. When we need help, we can call our infuriated self and ask for help to find our way. (For this, we need to dial #0 from the phone.)
Never Give Up!
Sometimes we will lose our way, and just when we think we are stuck, we can free ourselves from all our misery by stabbing ourselves with a knife. In actuality, this is a necessity for us to progress. In short, “Death”, is a key to progress in the game. Strangeland exposes us to our fears, our guilt, our shame, in their entirety. The graphics of the game perfectly achieves the requirements of a point-and-click game in an artistic manner. Wormwood Studios which you will remember from Primordia has hit the bullseye with Strangeland.
To put it briefly, Strangeland has a loaded dialogue system which contains novels, books, Norse Mythology, human psychology, religions and many more. Strangeland has roughly 5 hours of gameplay, and if we include all the dialogues and the comments made by the developers of the game, you can extend the game for a little longer. Strangeland is a game that will provide you more than the price you paid with its world, dialogue structure and artistic design.
Finally, while dying over and over again, how can we save each other?
Now, back to the beginning, and we will wait and see who plays the game, whether it’s you, me, or us both.
See you at Strangeland…
developer_response:
"Wormwood Studios insanın ruhuna dokunan nadir stüdyolardan biri."

Hiçbir geliştirici bir incelemede daha nazik sözler bulmayı umamaz. Çeviriniz ve her şeyden önce cesaretlendirmeniz ve dostluğunuz için minnettarız. Umarım artık daha fazla Türk oyuncuya ulaşabiliriz!

Yıllar önce, Primordia'yı ilk çıkardığımızda, dergilerden ve büyük web sitelerinden çok sayıda düşmanca eleştiri aldık. Ama Türkiye'deki Level Magazine'den ve artık aktif olmayan iki web sitesinden (neooyun.com ve oyunefendi.com) güzel yorumlar aldık ve o zamandan beri Wormwood Studios ülkenizde destek buldu. İncelemede dediğiniz gibi, benim de aklımda, kalbimde ve hatta midemde (özellikle gözleme ve pide) Türkiye'de geçirdiğim çok güzel anılar var.

Ekipten çok teşekkürler ve sevgiler.

(Google Çeviri'den gelen her türlü kaos için özür dileriz.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197987991116', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1644823840}
review: A great game, but I would have really appreciated one more act to the story. The end feels kind of sudden and the final puzzles are easier than the ones in the middle of the game, but it's still very much worth a play through.
developer_response: Thanks so much! I’m not sure the story/setting could sustain another act (we already went well beyond our original scope), but perhaps one more involved puzzle in Deadland wouldve helped. The easier puzzles were by design, but sometimes (often) in adventure design you can overshoot either direction in difficulty. Anyway, many thanks for giving it a look and for the kind (and fair) assessment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006876821', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1643602476}
review:
I'm a simple man; I see a game released by Wadjet Eye Games, I buy it; they don't publish games  that aren't worth it. It's a philosophy that has only failed me once, and that isn't that time.

The other game by Wormwood, Primordia, is an excellent game - it's only flaw is that there isn't more of it, and that's not really a flaw - to create a world that the player desperately wants to know more about is a triumph in itself. Primordia is grim, but it's not dark. 

Shadowlands is dark. You've got your classic dark topics such as suicide, regret, remorse, sacrifice, death, 19th century poetry, entomology, even 1960's sci-fi, that sort of thing. It's well done. Some of it is straight up nightmare fuel. It's definitely more in line with Tormentum: Dark Sorrow in tone, but it is done well. 

I took about 4.5 hours to get through the game - normally that would be too short for the price, but with Wadjet Eye Games published games you get a tight narrative experience, and it is well worth it. 

The puzzles are not too obscure as to be punishing, there is help if need be (albeit mockingly condescending) and I never stopped in frustration. 

If you like class point and click puzzle adventure with pixel graphics, this is a no-brainer. Enjoyed is the wrong word, but I found it a thoroughly appreciated experience.
developer_response: Thank you so much -- it means a lot (psychologically as well as from a business-standpoint) for an indie developer to get player reviews, and you've found time for kind words about not just our game but also many others. Your review also gave me a laugh... he "classic topics" list reminded me of the Austin Power bit where Dr. Evil talks about his growing up: "My childhood was typical, summers in Rangoon, luge lessons. In the spring we'd make meat helmets. When I was insolent I was placed in a burlap bag and beaten with reeds, pretty standard really."

author: {'steamid': '76561198187839278', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 863, 'last_played': 1642249175}
review:
Wormwood Studios had created another success... For me, first was Primordia until I played Strangeland. If you think this is another retro Point n' click adventure game, think it twice. All the team surpasses all my expectations and make a finest game which can be another cult game, like the Monkey Island Series.

The plot was simply incredible... You don't know a thing at first, but the more you advance more you understand what's going on and what to do to make your way to one of the finals. The sensation that you start the game in the middle of the story is something that upsets me first, but when I finished the game my upset go away quickly.

I don't want to make any spoilers, so you have to trust me when I recommend you to buy this game and give to this studio all the support to make pieces of art like this game.
developer_response: We're grateful for your kind words about both Strangeland and Primordia, and more generally, for our team. You're the best!

author: {'steamid': '76561198216537667', 'num_games_owned': 1993, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1643162541}
review:
Quite a ride.
If you played Primordia, this game will feel somewhat familiar in style, mechanics, need to think about what and how you are doing things, and many other similarities.
Very different story content, darker, more introspective, more personal, and often challenging to deal with- some of the visceral responses and emotions that it may trigger for different people based on their own life stories will be different.

I enjoyed this game, though not in a "funny hahaha" sort of way.
The subject matter is dark, and may not be something everyone can relate to or deal with.
Loss.
Loss of a loved one.
Loss of self and self-identity.
Loss of control.
Recovery.
Recovery of control.
Recovery of self and self-identity.
Those were my main take-aways.
Yours may differ.
Our real life experiences differ, and so will the experiences we have while playing this game.

Make lots of saves. I did not think to do so until about halfway through the game, so there are alternate endings I can get to by loading saves, but there are missed achievements I will need to restart from the beginning to unlock.
I did play without commentary and annotations. I will replay with both enabled. The commentary is always interesting, to get insight into what inspired the game, and what lies behind some of the scenes. Annotations as well- there is a good bit of mythology and lore, as well as references to scripture, literature, and cultures that may not be obvious. some I understood immediately, some I did not. 

This is a "big words" game. Meaning- there are a good number of words and concepts that are not going to make sense to everyone. It's not a game you can play without thinking- turn your brain on before launching the game. And be aware that doing so may lead to some uncomfortable or even emotionally painful moments. This isn't a game for everyone, and that is okay.
developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind words and thoughtful (and thought-provoking) response to the game. I’m curious to hear how the commentary and annotations strike you when you give them a look. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198196831881', 'num_games_owned': 676, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1642495707}
review:
A beautiful and twisted psychological horror game, Strangeland is an interactive tone poem on loss, sin, and self-destruction. It's unmistakably the work of Wormwood Studios: a melancholic and haunted world brought to life by evocative and grimly whimsical art direction, a kindred spirit to their prior release Primordia while firmly establishing its own identity. The whole experience is brought together by a wonderful performance from the inimitable Abe Goldfarb.

It's worth noting that the game is relatively short, and its elegant puzzle design is unlikely to stall your progress enough to pad out the runtime. This will be a selling point to some and a deal-breaker for others, but personally I found the experience to be the perfect length. Overall, a highly recommended way to spend 4-5 hours.
developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind and beautiful words!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002913302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1642353453}
review:
Let me start by saying that I own almost all of Wadjet Eye Games point & click adventure titles and they are an insta-buy for me. If you're a fan of them you'll probably enjoy this one, too. It has many of the qualities you can expect from their games like top notch voice acting (incl. Abe Goldfarb, probably the only voice actor I know by name) and absolutely solid puzzle design with some very unique ideas.

Having said all that, Strangeland is, well, strange (and bleak and surreal). It's hard to explain why and how it is strange without spoiling too much and this is best experienced blind. So, I'll just say that the core game requires you to go through the (almost) same scenarios many times. The storyline is very opaque and open to interpretation. The latter is not a bad thing per se but it means (and this might very well be intended because it fits the story) that you feel a bit lost because you don't know what you're actually trying to accomplish, although the genius of the game design is that you still kinda know what you have to do right at that moment (and if you get stuck there's a brilliant in-game and in-character help line, quite literally: There's a phone booth where you can call the operator who'll give you hints).

Strangeland is definitely a memorable experience, well worth playing but it is certainly not everybody's cup of tea. I recommend it to more experienced adventure game fans who are willing to embrace a bit of strangeness.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words and thoughtful assessment—and for what sounds like a long history of supporting the P&C genre!

author: {'steamid': '76561198253551769', 'num_games_owned': 188, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 1238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1238, 'last_played': 1642232849}
review:
Strangeland is one of the best adventure style games I have played in a while not only for it's creepy atmosphere, but also for it's beautiful yet terrifying story. In which it seems to be woven together with interesting puzzle mechanics in which players can really interact with from different perspectives that really make the game a memorable experience. In addition to this, the voice acting is simply top notch thanks to Wadjet Eye Games! Honestly, the game feels like it could be an episode of the twilight zone and that's why this game is brilliant!  

Here are some of the reason's I bought Strangeland and why I'd recommend it even if your new to the adventure game genre!

First and foremost, Strangeland initially appealed to me because It had a very dark carnival style atmosphere that I really did enjoy. Simply, put the artist for Strangeland Victor Pflug was spot on for this game's atmosphere as far as the art goes as the art is very unsettling and it does actually send chills down your spine. The carnival atmosphere as mentioned above is also very creepy and it does actually make you question everything around you even including how you navigate puzzles. James Spanos, who programmed this game really did an exceptional job as the atmosphere around you that you interact with is very on edge and different from your own reality! Also, the characters that you come across in this carnival atmosphere are very strange and unsettling figures that really make you question not only the characters reality. but your own reality as your playing the game.  

However, what's very interesting to me is the actual story! The story is a very tragic tale and the way it develops is simply marvelous yet weird. It's worth noting here that during my first play through I found the story to be very confusing as the atmosphere around me really set me on edge and had me constantly question everything within the game including if this carnival was even real. I also constantly wondered if the carnival was actually all the manifestations of the tragedy that I was experiencing and thus it was manifested as a carnival of emotions inside of mind, instead of me physically being at a carnival. I did not pick up on any of the major hints or references during my first play through as the atmosphere was just very creepy! 

Regardless, I found the writing to be top notch and even though I was confused on my first play through of the game. I was still happy with the ending that I received at the end of the game partly due to how flexible I could be with my choices when solving puzzles. Then upon curiosity of knowing this game had multiple endings. I decided to replay the game a second time with both the commentary and annotation mode on. This was simply a brilliant idea! The reason why it was so brilliant is because it allowed me as a player to really understand and grasp the story that was being told in Strangeland. In addition to this, it also allowed me to see how the programmer, artist and writer really formed this world. I absolutely had a blast the second time around playing Strangeland because I loved listening to all the commentary by Mark Yohalem the writer as it was deeply profound what he had to say about his inspirations for everything within the game. In regard to listening to him, I absolutely had a different perspective in regards to the choices I made in the game a second time around in which definitely made me choose a different option, which significantly had the game end differently.

Overall, my experience of Strangeland has been really positive! I would totally recommended this adventure game to anyone! The artist and the programmer for this game really made the atmosphere super spine tingling in which you will experience will you play the game. In addition to that the writer also did an excellent job in which he crafted a story that was both terrifying in it's overall narrative but also beautiful at the same time depending on the choices you made. 

Interesting enough, upon doing more research about the writer. I found out that he graduated from Harvard Law and is a lawyer within Los Angeles, which honestly makes a lot of sense here as the writing is very detailed and indepth. Which is very refreshing as this game does not have a cookie cutter story and thus the story is very deep and meaningful in which all players will see when they experience the game for the first time or even the second time as I did. 

Overall, I give this game an 8/10! It's simply a good story that is being told! A story that is a tragedy but also doesn't have to be which is cool because you as the player can decide how the story ultimately enfolds. Great Job with everything Wormwood Studios!
developer_response: Thank you so much for this generous, thorough, and beautiful review. Very much appreciated.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992483396', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1670341516}
review:
Really beautifully made game. It avoids most of the frustration of point and click games that you usually get in that there's a sort of built in hint system that's actually helpful - as it berates you for using it. It's a game made almost entirely out of metaphors, intentionally butchered mythological references and a weird sense of dreadful ennui. The art is glorious in its pixellated goodness, hearkening back to the days when games were scarier because you -couldn't- quite tell exactly what things were or what exactly they looked like, until it zooms in and SHOWS you. And boy, does it have some things to show you.

Gorgeous visuals, great writing and a tight game design that feels just about the right length without being too railroady. Highly recommend.
developer_response: What a wonderful review! “A weird sense of dreadful ennui” is a great and apt turn of phrase.
