author: {'steamid': '76561198029328534', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1641839364}
review:
So to note, I'm huge fan of Blackwell series by Wadjet Eye Games but I've also been fan of games published by them even if they weren't developers. So obviously I'm going to like this one.

Ya know, I knew of the whole "stranger in strangeland" quote, but I never realized this game is about twisted amusement park so I love that take on the quote :p I also like what feels like inspiration from Sanitarium in this one.

Honestly though, I am kinda tired of allegorical/symbolic inside your mind stories about man being unable to let go their dead wife(sometimes its kids or childhood trauma, but like 90% its dead wife), I feel like that is most common type of version of these kind of stories. Heck I personally almost always feel that games talking about mental health problems more often than not are kind of repetitive when compared to each other in that "yes I have depression I know what its like, but I don't have deep scary voice telling me how much I suck, I think it myself" if that makes sense? Like I dunno, I just don't get much catharsis from the concept itself, like maybe I'm supposed to be like "this is relatable" or maybe I'm supposed to be healthy person who is like "oh so that is what it is like"? But I digress, I don't think that is actually problem here.

Despite that rant, this is extremely well executed take on that type of story, it doesn't hide its true nature at all, its very clear early on that what is happening isn't real and that really helps with it since its not used as plot twist. Heck game also avoids revealing at all what is happening "really" so that helps with allegorical nature of the game that it isn't about "specific events with specific people" so to speak. I think I got plenty of catharsis from good execution itself even if I'm tired of this type of stories in itself :D
developer_response: Glad the game gave you catharsis! Certainly one of its goals. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198084359321', 'num_games_owned': 1303, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1626439665}
review:
Version longue : https://dystopeek.fr/jouer/jv/strangeland/

Version courte : Strangeland est dans mon top 3 des jeux de 2021. Et pourtant je l'attendais au tournant, puisqu'il est l'oeuvre de Wormwood, qui a développé Primordia, un de mes jeux d'aventure préféré.

Si on devine les contours du scénario avant notre personnage, on reste impliqué par les détails et la symbolique de chaque élément. Les twists sont bien amenés, chaque personnage a une vraie profondeur et trop en dire serait gâcher le plaisir de la découverte ; c’est en partie sur ce point que je l’attendais et je n’ai pas été déçu par l’écriture.

Les énigmes sont également très réussies, ne tombant pas dans les pièges évoqués plus haut, gardant l’attention du joueur et récompensant la réflexion plus que les combinaisons hasardeuses. On dispose de tous les éléments pour progresser via les dialogues et les environnements, il nous laisse connecter les points. 

De cette forêt de qualités, il me reste en bouche une expérience marquante. Le travail est de très bonne facture, intelligent, dégueulant la folie par tous les pores de la direction artistique. Soyez conscient que les thèmes abordés ne sont pas faciles d’accès.

Uniquement disponible dans un anglais qui demande un peu de maîtrise, Strangeland est un des meilleurs Point & Click auquel j’ai joué ces dernières années, qui m’a happé de bout en bout.
developer_response: Une belle critique, aussi bien dans sa forme courte que dans sa forme longue. Nos plus sincères remerciements pour les deux. Nous espérons partager une traduction française cette année, mais comme vous pouvez vous en douter, c'est un jeu difficile à traduire !

Well worth the money despite being a little light on content, if you're hungry for a dark point and click look no further. Wouldn't recommend playing it while high.
developer_response: Ha! Thank you for the kind words—and the arcade game DARE advisory. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197987598378', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1641239861}
review:
I haven't lost a wife in death. But even if I did, I'd listen to Mount Eerie rather than this - and I'm sorry to say - pile of pretentious self-pity.

Oh wow life is a dark carnival! Crow eats a carrion! Bad puns interlaced with suffering! Everything is a metaphor for You ****ed Up Your Own Life!

I want to say that the last 10 minutes of the game redeemed it - again, since it seems to be based on a personal experience, who am I to deny people their coping mechanisms and their own impression of what it feels like? But as a game, I cannot recommend it.

The "adventure game" of the game is solid. Good, even. You pick objects, use them, combine them, try different timing, etc. But it's hard to motivate yourself to do that when every character runs their mouth and says, in 400 different ways, wow, life is suffering. I am you. Everything has happened before. Here's a reference to mythology. Here's a quote from Bible. But only the sad parts. Because, you see, life is suffering. Here's something more about suffering. You are already dead. You are me. Ad nauseum.

I'm not saying you should hate the game, but before buying, please just watch 5 minutes of dialogue from this game on youtube and see it will be too grating for you or not.

~ ~ ~

EDIT: I want to thank the developer responding to the review - I know it's difficult reading negative things about your art, especially when it is so personal. But I think, we're not meant to care about strangers' opinions. 

There's a difference between bad art (whatever that is) and unrelatable art. This game hits that exact spot where I want to like it, but I just cannot recommend it to friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980771676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 549, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1640905094}
review:
[h1]How do you want to die today?[/h1]

So oder so ähnlich wird man indirekt vom Spiel selbst nach einer Weile Spielzeit gefragt, denn sterben könnt ihr in Strangeland recht schnell. Aber keine Sorge: Das gehört dazu und ist auch keine Bestrafung ala Dark Souls. Immerhin spielen wir hier ein waschechtes P&C-Adventure - und da stehen nun mal das Rätseln und die Dialoge im Vordergrund.

Als "Unbekannter" aka "Stranger" wachen wir weiß Gott wo auf (nennen wir es "das Ende des Seins") und treffen allerlei merkwürdige Gestalten auf einem Jahrmarkt des Wahnsinns. Ein augenloser alter Narr auf einer Bank, ein sprechender Rabe, ein gefräßiges 1000-Münder-besitzendes Etwas oder eine anmutig schöne Lady, die sich immer wieder in den unendlichen Brunnen zu "Tode?!" stürzt - die Welt von "Strangeland" hat genau das zu bieten was der Titel verspricht. Ist aber auch kein Wunder: Entwickler "Wormwood Studios", die schon das geniale Primordia erschaffen haben, übertreffen sich mit ihrem einzigartigen Stil und ihrer wunderschönen Welt tatsächlich noch einmal selbst.

Publisher "Wadjet Eye Games" ist zumindest für mich noch einer der Überlebenden alter P&C-Schule - unter deren Hut kommen so einige Pixel-Perlen raus: Gemini Rue, Shardlight oder die Blackwell Reihe - inklusive eben auch Primordia.

Die Rätsel in Strangeland sind meistens recht bodenständig und einfach zu eruieren (leichtes Kombinieren gibt sich die Hand mit ein paar Exklusiv-Mini-Games), doch an der Spielzeit von ca. 4h hätten die Entwickler definitiv noch schrauben können - zumal der Schauplatz insgesamt recht übersichtlich ist (dieselben 10 Panels nochmal in einer Alternativ-Version - und das war's im Grunde genommen schon).

[b][u]Bottom Line:[/u][/b]
Wem die kurze Spielzeit und die ausschließlich englische Sprachausgabe (nicht einmal deutsche Untertitel gibt's) nicht stört, bekommt ein bizarr abstraktes P&C mit wunderschönen Panels, unverbrauchtem Szenario und einem insgesamt sehr guten Pacing. Manchmal schwanke ich zwischen "lieber kürzer und dadurch knackiger" und "lieber länger in dieser wunderschönen Welt verweilen" - aber hier gewinnt für mich ganz klar die kreative Gesamtleistung unterm Strich. Ich hab jede Sekunde verschlungen und wollte immer wieder wissen wie die Geschichte nun weiter geht - auch wenn man keine ausführliche Erklärung bekommt was das nun alles bedeutet, da vieles nur angedeutet wird. Dazu tragen leider auch die sehr abrupten 4 Enden bei. Aber gerade für die, die eine rätselhafte Geschichte mit doppeltem Boden suchen, sind hier goldrichtig.

🔫 Pew Pew Pew! 💥 Bock auf mehr Reviews? 🔎
🏃💨 [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42792002/]Folge mir[/url] und verpass' keine weiteren Neuigkeiten! ⚡
developer_response: Vielen Dank! Wir hoffen, demnächst eine deutsche Übersetzung (Text, nicht Audio) zu haben Monat oder so.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015381850', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1640585740}

author: {'steamid': '76561198054985169', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1640596639}
review:
I've played Primordia I don't know how many times (and filled my profile with it!), so when I got some games for Christmas I knew I'd be playing this first. It's obviously a different genre and style of storytelling than Primordia, but continues to draw on influences from other games I loved (Planescape: Torment again especially, though different aspects of it than Primordia did, but this one feels like a wonderful Sanitarium love letter at times too) and I definitely plan to play it again once my brain's had time to rest and think it over.

It IS shorter than Primordia, and doesn't have the same vast store of random and semi-hidden dialogue to support as many playthroughs either. But I think it's definitely got at least two or three playthroughs in it (including a commentary mode like Primordia had) before you're likely to have "seen everything" and then just be going back to it like you'd re-read a good book. 

A more significant difference from Primordia is that Strangeland has a higher and more constant level of "heaviness" - what comic relief there is is infrequent and itself often pretty gloomy or dark. Hearing about that was one of the things that prompted me to wait until now to play it, as I wasn't really in the mood for that when it released. I'm glad I picked this game up at the right time, such that I was able to have a great experience with it, so I hope anyone out there thinking of getting it will give careful consideration to the same!

The final and most important thing that everyone needs to know about this game is that the cicada is the best character and I would trust it with my life. Thank you, devs, for including one of my favorite bugs so beautifully. :)
developer_response: Thank you! Lovely review. I too love cicadas; a magical part of my childhood

author: {'steamid': '76561198881816010', 'num_games_owned': 1031, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1639708730}
review:
This is absolute poetry. Beautifully written and powerfully atmospheric. I could feel just how much grief went into the creation of this deeply-personal game. I can't imagine many would make it through without feeling a strong resonance with at least a scene or two.

I love how unflinchingly bizarre the world of Strangeland is. Many scenes reminded me in the best way possible of the less-gratuitous (in terms of shock-value, at the least) David Firth animations, albeit far more heady; particularly the cicada and teratoma interactions. Every corner of Strangeland is dripping with Giger and Poe and various mythological and biblical allusions. These references thankfully serve to strengthen the unique narrative of Strangeland -- it never feels like a hollow vessel for previous works. In fact, there's a great comment or two in the game about leaning heavily on quotation.

The puzzles and interactive gameplay elements serve their purpose well in creating a connection to the narrative. I never felt too stuck or frustrated, and a simple call to the operator could point me in the right direction if I'd overlooked a cue.

I'm not particularly keen on replaying this one any time too soon, however. It was just a lot to take in! I finished Primordia earlier this week, and will almost certainly return to it sooner than this, despite the excellent evolution in design. All of that being said, I'm very happy to have had the experience and give Strangeland my highest recommendation.
developer_response: Thank you for the very special gift of this review. It means the world to read a player reaction like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053849244', 'num_games_owned': 160, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1639356551}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027502227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1638131838}
review:
Strangeland really is just that: an immensely strange land.

From the very start, this game both extremely confused and intrigued me; from its setting, over the looks, to the story you are just thrown into and you'll have to unravel piece by piece. I had no idea what was going on but I wanted to find out!

It's quite an experience, a weird trip into a surreal world you don't want to miss.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed the strange ride! We always really appreciate when a player leaves a review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045352209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1638683343}
review:
I was impressed with Wormwood's first point and click outing, Primordia, despite some of its design flaws, but they've certainly taken some of the criticisms of that game to heart and have delivered one of the most compelling narratives and visual adventure games I've experienced. The mix of dark and surreal fantasy blending cohesively with its rather nihilistic yet still twistedly hopeful story has left an impression on me that I certainly don't think I'll be forgetting any time soon. 

If I were to levy some criticism towards this one though it would certainly be the phone number puzzle, which felt a bit obtuse, but at the very least the game has a safety net feature via the payphone that is a lot more gracious at saving the player than Primordia's far more purist design. 
And also the other endings besides the true ending do feel like they lack a bit of substance when they're essentially punch lines for a joke, which is definitely in keeping with the story tonally but I guess my gripe there is I wish at least one of them carried perhaps as much thematic weight and taken as seriously. Not to say of course that they aren't properly set up, but if you somehow found yourself getting any of those endings before the true one then you might feel a bit disappointed and think "is that it?"

All that said though, I highly recommend Strangeland to anyone who's a fan of the genre, especially those that are into weird and dark settings.
developer_response: Thank you so much for playing both this and Primordia, for engaging with them so thoroughly, and for leaving the kind review. Very grateful!

author: {'steamid': '76561198132102458', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1638553096}
review:
This game was awesome!

Wormwood Studios is a collection of really talented people who make good things. I played primordia a few years ago and it blew me away. I cant think of that many games that I have become so invested in that I can sit down for 5 straight hours and play through the entire thing with no breaks. Strangeland and Primordia feel like if David Lynch tried to make games. Anyways, this game is worth 15$ and is an amazing experience. I had some technical issues like not being able to use steam overlay, and tabbing out of this game is a little funky. But one can easily overlook those minor things. This game is definitely not for everyone, but I liked it. Thanks Wormwood!

To the Dev who reads all of these: It's really awesome to see someone who is so passionate about making sure people are having a good time with the thing they made. You rock dude.
developer_response: Aww. What a wonderful note at the end! We’re grateful for your and other players’ support. Vic in particular is a huge Lynch fan, so I will make sure to pass along your kind words.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966002728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1638426662}
review:
A really well-done, creative game that held true to the original point-and-click adventure style of the 90s.

My only qualms with it is the short gameplay time. Just when I felt I got into the game it was over.
developer_response:
Very glad you enjoyed it!

I think we would have had to take a very different approach to the themes, narrative, and setting to stretch it out much longer, but I agree that it's on the short end (partly because of quality of life features like being able to instantly exit rooms and a design that avoids backtracking, but also just because it's not a large game). There is some replay value, particularly if you play with annotations/commentary on, but those aren't for everyone.

Most importantly: many thanks for playing the game and taking the time to read a review! We really appreciate it, and it helps motivate us to continue making games. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198122399346', 'num_games_owned': 204, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 789, 'last_played': 1626899803}
review:
How many times have we started a game with protagonists waking up having no recollection of themselves or their memories? A few times. A Stranger (if we choose to call him that) waking up on a tiny island in the middle of a black, brown and purple VOID next to a nightmarish circus, with a path illuminated inviting you right in adds it's own flavor though. Then you get eaten by a clown head, witness a woman in white jump down a well as you reach her, right after that you receive a phone call from the nearby booth in which the voice blames it all on you, only for you to turn around and see the same woman jump down the well AGAIN. Oh, and most of the things here will try to kill you in the first few minutes. Multiple times. Serves as a pretty fitting intro of how this game is going to play out. And of our protags self-preservation insinct. 
Which is surprisingly relevant this time.

[u]A warning about non-specific spoilers bellow!![/u]

Finally, another one from Wormwood Studios. First things first: It's not Primordia. Both are puzzle filled point'n'clicks with almost similar gameplay and sharing similar art style of decay, but Strangeland is different in themes and execution, though PERHAPS they share a few concepts, since both have protagonists that are quite philosophical, in a sense. I've seen some of the other comments and honestly, if you ONLY expect another Primordia, you'll most likely be disappointed. Now, with that out of the way, what about Strangeland? Admittedly, I haven't been digging too much info about the game before playing, just the general stuff that was available, as that was how I wanted it. So I was a little surprised that it turned to be, in my eyes, a much more personal tale than I was expecting. Although wrapped neatly in a surreal, creepy, depressed package. Psychological horror doesn't exactly have much to offer these days, but Strangeland takes a different approach which, in my opinion, is much more fitting for the genre. The horror part is more in the aesthetic than the story, the enviroment is inhabited by several quirky characters, both helpful and spiteful. I did enjoy annoying the voice from the phone booth on purpose, who actually ends up serving as your hint system should you get stuck. Whether you do or do not get all the narrative references you will feel the atmosphere it chooses and breathes. It also did play a bit on my own nostalgia, since I did recall several older adventure games with similar narrative style. =)
The voice acting is great and the art very beautiful, as usual, but it grew more detailed and refined. Anyone who played a few games from Wadjet Eye will probably recognize several of the voices and I wished there were more fullscreen illustrations than the few location intro pages we've gotten. Most of the puzzles aren't too difficult but present an adequate challenge. I felt that they take a little bit of a backseat this time to benefit the narrative. Several mostly depend on you listening to the dialogues well. The most frustrating thing that can happen is if the very rare pixel hunt prevents you from progressing or, as has happened to me a few times, you speak to an NPC before you've had the necessary conversation/object from a different NPC/enviroment. The Stranger is more of a mouth piece than a character. I did feel empathy towards him, but since his (understandable) fixation on specific events in his life is integral to the shaping of his character and the story as a whole, there isn't much room to learn more, though we do get some hints. How important that is however, depends on how you view the story the game is telling. Once you see past the creepy atmosphere you'll realize that the background and message has been done before and with less words, but as I've mentioned, I do get a personal point of view vibe from it here, so I welcomed it.
I do think the game gets a little lost in its own philosophying a bit. But perhaps that is because I was coming freshly from a similarly flavored debate before I played this and admittedly, most of the ones used in Strangeland share main themes. There's a mishmash of several philosophy theories, but also various mythological concepts. Mostly Norse and Greek, but a few others as well, even if just for one or two references. So if you're a fan of either or have read some of the works I THINK it's alluding to, you'll probably have a blast. If themes of the psyche, knowledge, surrealism, madness, fate, guilt, death and the helplessness to prevent that loss speak to you, you will find your mark here. If the Norse myths in a deeper sense than just "VIKINGS!!" are your jam, you'll probably find a kindred soul in this game. If not, well... depends on how much you don't mind getting a bit lost in all the metaphors. As you can see, it's trying to cover quite a few ones in one package. I'll have to replay with the dev commentary one day, as I'm sure it will bring light on much of the choices, because whether you like it or not, the one thing you can feel amidst all of that, is the developers passion for these subjects. 

In the end, I would prefer to be able to give a "mixed" review, but since it would be a positive mixed I'll stick with what I have available. Strangeland is unique in the genre of the slowly resurrected pixel style adventure games, perhaps BECAUSE it uses this genre to tell its message. It hides well behind macabre horror stuff that makes you think of old "Freak Show" carnivals and a surrealist story at first, but is actually about grief and self-reflection. And ultimately acceptance. To be able to accept losses and ourselves. And have the strength to move forward. It's heavy and bittersweet. I believe everyone can benefit by reflecting on that at least once in our lives, through any form of media we choose from. You mind find strength you didn't think you had.
developer_response: Thank you so much for the detailed, thoughtful, and balanced review. Really appreciate your take.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074583083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1638052150}
review:
I don't normally play point and click adventure games, but for some reason this one stuck out to me. I'm glad it did. Would definitely recommend to anyone who want's an immersive and thoughtful experience. I enjoyed it so much that I beat it in only two sittings.

I like the story a lot. The characters, especially some of the side characters, got me thinking quite a bit. It's open ended, and there's a lot to dig into here if you take the time to examine and think through the world and the dialogue.

The puzzle difficulty is really nice I think. All the answers make sense in the context of the game and there's none of those nonsense puzzles that used to make the old games so difficult and annoying to play. Some of the puzzles, particularly the word play ones, I thought were really cool.

The art is beautiful and very impressive, to me at least. Definitely made me uncomfortable at times, but that's kind of the point and is part of the experience. But maybe not for everyone. If you don't like Giger you almost definitely won't like this.
developer_response: Thank you for this lovely review. Means a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980649150', 'num_games_owned': 530, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1622862541}
review:
After I finished Primordia, a looong time ago, I caught myself looking for more games from both companies, and I saw two blogposts from Wormwood, talking about two games in development. Both games looked nice, but I ended up forgetting them.
And this year, one them was released: Strangeland. And I must say, it worthed the wait. The first thing I noticed was the artstyle, and it's gorgeous. The gameplay is a standard point and click, but the story is quite interesting. It may not make too much sense, but just play it, and you'll get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010224454', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1637785309}
review: Strangeland ist ein kurzes, sehr abgedrehtes Point-&-Klick Andventure. Ihr erforscht die Psychche eures Charakters, erlebt dabei die in vielen Metaphern erzählte Geschichte und löst leichte bis mittelschwere, genretypische Rätsel. Für Fans solcher Spiele, die wie Ich mit dem niedrig aufgelösten Pixellook etwas anfangen können, ist es eine Empfehlung, sonst lieber erstmal Paar zugänglichere Vertreter ausprobieren.
developer_response: Vielen Dank! Wir hoffen, dass es bald mit einer deutschen Übersetzung besser zugänglich ist, obwohl dies natürlich nichts an der Auflösung der Grafik ändert. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198331862151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 821, 'last_played': 1624702831}
review:
Short version: Not as good as Primordia, but since Strangeland is a psychological horror, it is as recommendable as Sanitarium or Layer of Fear. Uh...I'd rather prefer Layers of Fear. though.

Long long version:
Uh...I can't decide whether I like or dislike this game. To me, it feels like eavesreading a personal diary which is filled with deep grief of loss and self destructive narcissism. I think...the worst part of grievance is when your heart is broken, your body also feels hurt - like headache or chest pain. And this Strangeland is like, the gamification of that symptom. It made me physically hurt - not because of its disturbing images, but because of its abyssal sadness. And though it must be dedicated to the lost one, this extreme sadness is a bit...self-immersive. Even narcissistic. That also made me physically sick. Well, I know it's eventually about the healing and the light, but why this should be this painful? 

H.R. Gigeresque artworks are not very appealing(but maybe that's just because I'm not a fan of Giger), and the overall game is a bit overstuffed with homages and metaphors. The commentaries and citations are interesting and enlightening, but make Strangeland like a kinda philosophy textbook. I still don't understand some references...oh, and the credit is unskippable. Well if the genre 'psychological horror' means 'the game which is filled with grotesque self images', Strangeland is the one...but I expected some more...or less...I don't know, but not Gigeresque thing. I can't explain. Sorry!

Anyway, I can't recommend this in a light mood, but it is still recommendable. Puzzles are logical, items are adequately located, and writing reminds me some Greek tragedies and Jewish poems. Abe Goldfarb's voice acting is somewhat exaggerated, but still brilliant. If you've experienced the loss of loved one, I could recommend this, but also I couldn't recommend this. Because it's like the healing process through self-harm. This path to the light in the sky is only reachable through many falls.

I rarely rate the game by stars, but this one is 7.5/10 good and bad.
developer_response:
Thanks for the detailed and thoughtful review -- thought-provoking, as well as thoughtful. To me it raises the question where the line lies between positive and negative reviews. On the one hand, the review begins with "it is as recommendable as Sanitarium," a classic game for which you left a positive review, and ends with a 7.5 rating, which I take to be a positive rating. On the other hand, the agony the game explores "made [you] physically hurt." Where does that leave things?

Before trying to answer that, I did want to address one point. I could not be more opposed to the notion of "healing through self-harm." Almost by definition, if something heals you, it isn't harmful. The game does take the position that we have to face and accept the painful things that happen to us, but always with the understanding that there is a light that lies past that darkness. If we let pain paralyze us with fear, then we wind up trapped in the darkness of that pain. The only way out is through. 

You ask "why this should be so painful," and I suppose my only answer is that our capacity to feel the pain of another is empathy, and empathy is the root of humanism. The hardest part of despair for me is the sense of isolation, that we are alone in a sorrow that no one else could possibly understand. When you play Strangeland, you aren't "eavesdropping"; you're there by invitation, with the goal that if you recognize the Stranger's pain in yourself, you will feel less alone in that pain.

So, to the extent Strangeland causes pain, it's meant to be cathartic -- not the kind of lingering unpleasantness that I associate with depressing works (e.g., the movies Kids or Requiem for a Dream). If Strangeland caused you that kind of lingering unpleasantness, then I'm very sorry. The intention is entirely the opposite.

Anyway, that doesn't answer the question where the line should be drawn between a positive and negative review. To me, it sounds like you had an extremely strong experience with Strangeland, not entirely pleasant, but very real. And you seemed generally to engage with the game's mechanics and design. If you came away nevertheless with a negative view of the game, that's too bad. But this isn't a negative review to which my response is, "I'm sorry," because much of what you describe as your reaction is the intended reaction. I feel worse if someone plays the game glibly and comes away with a superficially positive reaction.

Anyway, thank you again for your thoughtful take. I read your Primordia reviews years ago, and have checked out your other reviews from time to time. I appreciate your support of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025696404', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1636747682}
review:
cliche af, shock horror/body horror/almost hr giger-esque presentation. don't get me wrong the art is pretty cool, abe goldfarb does a pretty nice job too. 
but the story sucks, metaphors suck, the entire ride sucks, and the excessive amount of time padding almost made me not come back to this game. 

the "puzzles" are lazy
the stupid word play is lazy
the "story" is so painfully phoned in
and maybe it was part of the process but the repetition, false leads, and pixel hunting definitely don't add some metaphorical edge to the game. if it wasn't trying so hard to be weird, i'd just brush it off as classic AGBS

it has an option to have foreshadowing and references made pointed out to you, recommended for a second playthrough, and an apparent choice system, but honestly it fell so flat I'm not close to considering playing it again.

oh and the tutorial saying that all the information will be present, and given to you at any time so you don't have to remember anything? big fat lie.

tldr it's dark and edgy in a boring, phoned in, almost smug/masturbatory way, like a teenager wearing tight jeans writing song lyrics and that analogy spreads to the story, subject matter, written dialogue.
to quote the scribe; "there is nothing new under the sun"

post-script edit;

I appreciate the dev response, and I want to be transparent in that I'm really not trying to be harsh, but I will concede that this was written soon after the first playthrough, and came from a place of disappointment having loved all of the wadjet eye games I've played. I thought it would be better if I added some more refined thoughts:

There are plenty of positives to this game, as i mentioned the art, but the sound design, the voice acting, etc. also. it's a very aesthetic game, and it shows. Even looking past the aesthetic and metaphoric tropes, the game part falls down hard imo. It's hard to give specifics without directly giving spoilers, and I'm not down for that, even marked up. Lets just say pacing and timing need work. some of the uncontrollable delays just felt tedious. along with some more thought to ag stuff, puzzles etc. For such an esoteric and abstract setting, the old combining inventory things and using items was surprisingly common garden and mundane in a lot of ways. Even some of the more imaginative sections are squandered by the game immediately spoonfeeding you the solution or making itself very apparent. 

Without trying to go too far onto a tangent, i may also be biased by a personal gripe i have with some of the themes and ideas approached by not just this game, in that as someone who suffers with such an antagonist, there's always some disconnect and discomfort when it comes to handling the parallels and differences expressed and abstracted by someone else. It can make going through games like this more effort than it should be.

Finally, I don't want anyone to be sorry or ashamed for what they've made here, there are plenty of great, positive reviews, and a lot of people are happy with the game as a whole. There's good work in there, honest. But personally I just can't recommend it.
developer_response:
At least it elicited a strong reaction!

In all seriousness, sorry for the bad experience. Definitely doesn’t sound like you should play it again!

author: {'steamid': '76561198014611990', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1636339435}
review: Fell completely flat for me. The game suffers from combination of obtuse and cryptic presentation and banal and cliched story underneath. I didn't care for the main guy and was only slightly amused by some characters (and mightily annoyed by others). I think voice direction could be better - it doesn't feel like the hero is burdened by his circumstances, he sounds nonchalant and sometimes cracks jarring jokes. I have nothing against humor, but considering the topic I feel like the tone could be maintained a bit better. Puzzles could've carried the game, and some are pretty clever, especially those employing word play, but in general they are not exceptional. Buy Primordia if you haven't played it.
developer_response: Sorry you had an unpleasant experience (and even sorrier you weren't able to get a refund). Glad, at least, that you enjoyed Primordia!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006321953', 'num_games_owned': 603, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 1153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1153, 'last_played': 1629513957}
review:
Strangeland is perhaps the darkest game I've ever played. The setting is just so nightmarish and bleak, and although it kind of disturbed me and brought up bad memories, I found it compelling enough to finish in one sitting.

Everyone in the Wormwood Studios team really knocked it out of the park. Compared to their previous game (Primordia), Strangeland shows an obvious improvement in visuals, sound, technical ability, and game design in form of reduced player friction. In many ways it's Primordia's opposite, with a small universe, a very personal, emotional story, and horror setting, so it may not be enjoyed by fans of that game. Likewise, you might like it if you didn't like Primordia.

Dislikes:
[list]
[*]Almost no relief from the bleakness
[*]Few likeable characters
[*]Somewhat predictable
[*]Horror is a little systematic and uses tired tropes like the carnival setting
[/list]

Still, I recommend it for its great atmosphere, design and pace.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind review (and for playing both this and Primordia). I hope in the end there was a glimmer of something other than bleakness

author: {'steamid': '76561198006563025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1636185066}

author: {'steamid': '76561198115701912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1632878681}
review: Once again, a very enjoyable, poignant game as released by Wadjet Eye Games, one of my favorite game publishers and developers.  GORGEOUS art style and quality voice acting (especially by the protagonist's voice, Abe Goldfarb).  I know this was a very personal game to make, and the story behind the protagonist's motives was very easy to understand.  The gameplay was smooth, and the puzzles were pretty logical in their flow.  I actually wished the game was longer, I was enjoying it that much.  I'll probably replay it to understand the story's nuances even more.
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it! If you do another run, you might enjoy giving commentary and annotation a go—they help with the references but also explain some of the team’s goals with the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199040646308', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1635665073}
review:
Good story.

Edit: If I had known the developer was going to respond I would have put more effort into this lol. I got so engrossed in the story that I played straight through without stopping. I love classic point and click games and one of the best improvements they've made is the "operator" who can give you hints if you're stuck. So many point and clicks of the past would just let you... wander aimlessly, I guess. 

It was certainly difficult in some places, and I do wish there had been a journal with key events, like another reviewer had mentioned. Sometimes I felt as though if I'd had a log of what I'd done, I wouldn't have had to call the operator so many times haha. 

The aesthetic reminds me of the old game "Sanitarium", which was pretty tough but hit on some heavy topics. This studio has another game so I'll probably check that out as well.

A+ game, music is great, art is incredible, the themes are dark and very "human". Gameplay is awesome, and 100% an improvement on point and clicks of the past. I love horror stuff but don't always love having to fight things, so this type of game is perfect and I hope there are more in the future.
developer_response: Thanks! Glad you liked it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025004289', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 295, 'last_played': 1635634853}
review:
Game is pretty short for an adventure game. I only got tripped up on two puzzles - one because I wasn't fully paying attention and one because I was thinking far too abstractly. Got one ending in about 4 hours so likely a bit more than that to see them all.

Art is fantastic. Very much old school looking with nice flair to it and a lot of love put in, Voice acting was top notch, too. Every line is voiced and done by great actors.

Story is pretty standard for this type of game but I enjoyed it. It went where I was expecting it to the whole time but the presentation of it was nice and really moved it along.

I would recommend this if you like adventure games/point-and-clicks; you've got depression and anxiety (like myself); or you want something nostalgic that isn't unfair.
developer_response: Thank you for the kind and detailed review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060125630', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1635343417}
review:
Such a disappointment after Primordia. I recall the only flaw in that game being the ridiculous amount of things to keep track of by the end, all of it piling up into a bit of vagueness. That applies 100x here.
This game is just filled with so many vagueries and metaphors that it's really easy to get lost (not in an enjoyable way). The set pieces by themselves are great but nothing in this game connects or provides a real sense of its vast world, more just a pile of ideas randomly sprung together - which i guess was partially the point, but it doesn't make for an enjoyable experience. There is no sense of adventure and progressing towards something like in Primordia, just a gradual descent into more and more nonsense. There is not a single real character to talk to that provides any understandable dialogue or a role besides plot-necessary info or mocking the protagonist. I recall a robot waiting to be saved in Primordia that didn't serve any narrative purpose and wasn't related to any puzzle, it was solely there to add to the atmosphere. This game lacks things like that. Some puzzles offer multiple solutions, but the larger ones mostly depend on a signular absurd solution.
With so little that is understandable or clear, it's impossible to really care about anything going on. Everything feels purposeful, yet so vague. I just spent most of the game scratching my head about what is going on. The story is a generic 'you have to save her' plot with abstract elements that come with exploring the main character's psyche, but the guy himself is so uncharacteristic and has absolutely nothing interesting to say, it's impossible to care for them aswell. Combine this with a vague dud of an ending where nothing feels resolved in any way and nothing is explained in the slightest.
The puzzles also, in comparison to the story, feel extremely 'adventure-gamey'. I was half expecting there to be the classic key-stuck-in-lock puzzle. In this completely alien bizzare mysterious metaphoric world i was expecting to do the same puzzle I had to do in the most common room escape games - that's how much the puzzles undermine the real game. There is even a hint system, which seems like it had a tremendous amount of effort put in it, yet comes across as lazy in execution and i think shows a lack of confidence in the puzzles actually making sense.
Art great, music good, but it doesn't amount to anything enjoyable, I really wish it did. But I really really hated it. Just play Primordia instead.
developer_response: Sorry to have disappointed you. Fortunately there are plenty of adventures out there that might cleanse your palate. Have you played Whispers of a Machine? Much more direct story and protagonist, and a lovey game overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971103804', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1635279208}
review:
An old style, 2D pixel-graphic adventure game. Dark, brooding and surreal. It reminded me of Dark Seed. From the gameplay perspective it is a classical point and click adventure. Some of the puzzles are pretty hard, but there is multi-tier hint system built into the game, so there is no real threat of getting stuck. Narratively it is full of metaphors and psychology. It has a rather dark and oppressive atmosphere. Characters are well written and excellently voiced.
You really need to be in a proper mood to play this game.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind and detailed review!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999058204', 'num_games_owned': 1560, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1632434508}
review: Another poetic masterpiece of art from Wormwood Studios, that will hit you with It's own style and atmosphere tightened to perfection. Something what you hardly see these days. It will make you think and question your own mistakes. It will hit you with a great humor, that will make you laugh. It might hit you with feels, that let you cry. Just about right mixture of ingredients for those, seeking adventure experience, that will not let you go so easily..
developer_response: What a beautiful review to start my day with. Thank you. It’s a gift.

author: {'steamid': '76561198205895069', 'num_games_owned': 785, 'num_reviews': 306, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1634397511}
review:
Strangeland es una buena aventura gráfica con una historia un tanto más críptica que lo que suele verse en el género habitualmente. Por momentos, en lo temático, me hizo acordar a Sanitarium aunque con mucha más oscuridad (sintáctica y semántica) en los diálogos.
La parte de los puzzles me gustó bastante con una buena variedad y diseño. Para lo extraño que es el mundo los puzzles siempre tienen lógica. Los gráficos llevan al límite lo que se puede hacer con pixel art. Las voces si bien tienen mucha calidad, en algunos momentos se me hicieron un poco exageradas.

Puntaje: 8/10
developer_response: Muchas gracias por las palabras amables. Esta frase - "mucha más oscuridad (sintáctica y semántica) en los diálogos" - era extremadamente elegante y acertada.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000326220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1633942502}
review:
[h2]No Strangers, but a Strange Land[/h2]
[h3]Pros[/h3]
[list]
[*]Creepy, detailed, heavily H.R Giger inspired art.
[*]Passionate voice over lines.
[*]Fun metaphors to grok.
[*]Weirdly logical puzzles, particularly given the genre and the aesthetic of the game.
[/list]
[h3]Cons[/h3]
[list]
[*]Familiar, trope-y story.
[*]Familiar, trope-y ending.
[*]Brief. Feels small.
[*]Some lazy puzzles (light puzzles. switch puzzles).
[/list]
[h3]Recommend To[/h3]
[list]
[*]Fans of H.R. Giger art.
[*]Fans of creepy DOS era adventure games like "I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream" or "Dark Seed"
[*]People who prefer ghost trains and Halloween haunts over traditional horror films.
[*]Drama nerds.
[/list]
[h3]What Might You Enjoy Instead?[/h3]
[list]
[*][b]Tormentum[/b] - Same Giger art, but feels like you get more of it. In exchange, you give up Strangeland's far better incorporated puzzle design and voice talent.
[*][b]The Cat Lady[/b] - Horror game with a less direct and more engaging take on its subject matter, but not as visually striking as Strangeland and will ask you to use your imagination.
developer_response: Thanks for giving it a shot, and for the thoughtful review.

author: {'steamid': '76561199171946497', 'num_games_owned': 15, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1623764622}

author: {'steamid': '76561198034889051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1629481260}
review: I recommend this game for its creativity, its well thought out characters , its dialogue, and well written story.   If you happened to like Primordia, which I did very much, then this is worth a try.  That all being said I disagreed with some aspects of the story and how certain core elements of the characters were portrayed; however, I still stand by my earlier statement about the creativity of this game.  My disagreements stem from having different life experiences, interpretations, and understandings of the story elements.   Take it as a recommendation that it is a good game if one can still enjoy playing it while not necessarily agreeing with it all the time.  It takes a captivating story to do that with characters one can empathize with.
developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind review and open mind for the game. It’s just one perspective on life, which is seen from as many different eyes as there are people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004883420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1633867926}

author: {'steamid': '76561198123138150', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1633510719}
review:
I really wish I liked this game more, but I found the experience lacking.

Don't get me wrong, by no stretch is this game bad, but I couldn't help but feel that the overall experience was lacking. In retrospect, I can not say that I was afforded a coherent experience, or any resolution to the many dark themes encountered along the way.

The game is very short and quite easy, I would regard it more as an interactive story as an actual puzzle game as it is mostly obvious exactly how to progress (and when I did get stuck, it is because I missed a particular line of dialogue). At no point was there a sense of problem solving or accomplishment. This is not a criticism but rather an observation, it is not etched into any stone that an adventure game must be puzzle driven. My criticism is that if the developers choose to forgo puzzle solving, they should offer some other form of substance.

[spoiler]The set up of the story is very intriguing, and throws the player into a cloud of mystery which they become excited to unravel. But by the time the player reaches the untimely conclusion to the game, it does not feel like any mystery has been unraveled at all. The game makes it very explicit that it is an allegory, but never reveals the subject of the allegory (and if it does, I am too dumb to have picked it up). The writing constantly builds up to a catharsis that never arrives, no sense of relive, conclusion or closure. It is made painfully obvious in pretty much every major turn of event that the protagonists grasp of reality is shrouded in some incredible agony of the soul (be it grief, despair, shame, guilt, insanity), and it is our task to guide him on his quest towards clarity. It is hence incredibly anticlimactic when the game pretty much says "okay, clarity reached" and ends with a borderline laconic sequence (on all possible endings). One could argue that the metaphor itself is the story, but I do not think they were nearly developed enough to carry the narrative on their own. It pains me to say, but by the end I felt like I was slapped in the face with a sequence of tropes which did not form a cohesive story. I found it a bit cheap, as if I am expected to find the game profound simply because it touches difficult subjects through clever imagery.[\spoiler]

I adore the atmosphere, the music, the grotesque graphics and the themes. I love how motifs of death are borrowed from a variety of cultures. The designers have no qualms with drowning the player with verbose bleak dialogue which makes the edge of insanity almost relatable. There are many moments in this game which are thought provoking and downright chilling. The only character which I found unbearable at times was the protagonist itself, which afforded much unneeded witticisms and stoicism which felt simply out of place.

So my bottom line is: it is a game, it is interesting, it has a lot of character and atmosphere, it is thought provoking at times. However, it is pretty short, pretty unsatisfying both puzzle wise and narrative wise, and it did not leave me with a sense of accomplishment or adventure. I am very partial about this game, but when all is said and done, it justified its price in time and money.
developer_response:
Thanks for the thoughtful review. I'm glad that, on balance, you enjoyed the game, though I certainly wish you'd enjoyed it more!

Gauging puzzle difficulty is tricky.  We seem to get roughly equal reviews saying the puzzles were impossibly hard and the puzzles were trivially easy.  I tend to like challenging puzzles myself, and I thought we included a few of them, but "challenging" depends on one's puzzle-solving skill, so for people who cruise through Myst or Savoir Faire, Strangeland will seem like a joke.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996842909', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1633021650}
review:
A good adventure game with an extremely odd and unique story. I enjoyed it, but it goes some dark places, and  if you are easily disturbed or are triggered by, among other things, self harm and suicide, I would give it a pass. 

The game is very short, and without consulting guides I managed to finish the game in roughly 4 hours, which is almost unheard of for me.  There are interesting options to replay with an explanation of the many, many references and allegories in the game, as well as developer commentary which will probably double that time at least.

Overall, if you enjoy horror and stories that are deeply steeped in allegory and double meanings, this is a really good play. Excellent for a long evening especially with Halloween approaching.
developer_response:
Glad you enjoyed it, and made it through without a guide! (The inclusion of a built-in hints system is meant to help people stay in game rather than consulting a FAQ or walkthrough.)

That's a fair warning on the themes, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988398097', 'num_games_owned': 360, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1633181323}
review:
I love this game from a technical point of view. There are many new beautifully drawn scenes / cut-scenes. There is much quality-of-life improvement too, you can now use the scroll wheel to select items from your inventory which is such a good change, all future AGS games should use this feature now. The sounds and music are great and fits the theme well. The puzzles are great too. The sepia, purple and dark tones of the game looks amazing.

What I did not like is the story. It's too cryptic for its own good. I like metaphors in my games but this game takes it to another level. Stories like these are layered in order of complexity, the first one being the easiest to follow, need to save girl, need to kill dark thing. This is the layer I believe most of the people who play this game will follow. There are much deeper layers which honestly speaking went over my head. There are metaphors to biblical texts, heavy use of symbolism, also the game does not shy from quoting various pieces of literature. It will take me multiple playthroughs to decipher most of what the game is trying to say.

However, I do not wish for this game to have a more simpler plot. I'm glad developers are experimenting with ideas. I'd recommend this game for it's great artstyle and puzzles.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed it -- and thanks for the thoughtful feedback.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017646676', 'num_games_owned': 901, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1632855236}
review:
This was a thoroughly weird, and intriguing experience. It's not hard as an adventure per se, I kinda missed a screen but otherwise it was quite possible to breeze through, but it was such a strange and intriguing story. I'll be thinking about this for a few days, that's for sure. It's a solid recommendation from me, if you're looking for a few hours just experiencing this. 

And sure, it took me about 4 hours on the first playthrough, and if I wand the other endings, it'll be another 2 hours with some tactical saving. But that's entirely expected from an adventure, quite honestly. Especially if it is this graphically intense. There is a lot of hand drawing in here and very few re-used animations.

But all in all, this is another year in which I find myself fully confirmed that I'll buy whatever wadjet eye publishes every year. And Wormwood Studios is a developer to keep an eye on. One of the last point+click producers out there.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words and support!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042662424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1632438188}

author: {'steamid': '76561198093682310', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1670179834}
review:
THIS GAME BOGGLES THE MIND

The hidden mythology and symbolism is amazing! 
The artwork is phenomenal and disgustingly intriguing.
Gameplay... Well it's a point and click game but, and this is a big stinky but. Unlike most mindbuggers, you don't need a walkthrough for the game as it has it's own clue system! 


Also! synonym for strangeland is Oddworld. Reference maybe`? 

I came to Wadjet Eye through Unavowed and noticed that they are reaaaaally not subtle to advertise their inspiration subjects! And honestly I like it. It elevates the source as well as the game how well they use their inspiration. 

I really don't wanna say much about the game since it was such a mindbuggering moment to figure out stuff. So take this recommendation with a grain of salt and try it yourself. You'll be disgusted, horrified, intrigued and amazed.
developer_response: I think it's hypocritical for people to say "i wasn't inspired by this", especially when it's very apparent that they were. We love paying tribute to things that we get inspired by and we're not ashamed about it! We embrace it with all our heart!

author: {'steamid': '76561198077447337', 'num_games_owned': 504, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1631918546}

author: {'steamid': '76561198057885708', 'num_games_owned': 336, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1631783458}
review:

Ok graphics and nice sound & voice cover.

Strong vibes from Dark Seed and I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream.
developer_response: Thanks for checking it out and for leaving a review -- very glad you enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987565903', 'num_games_owned': 559, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1631556476}
review:
Wow. This was a very interesting and surreal experience about grief, loss, self reflection and even self acceptance maybe? It's dark stuff man...

I do like these type of games and was not dissapointed by Strangeland. Easily on the top 10 of memorable point'n clicks I've ever played.

Puzzles, while indeed strange, are reasonably logical considering where the story plays out. There weren't any long stretches of aimlessly trying everything on anything just to solve a puzzle. And I think that making the puzzles any harder wouldn't have done justice to the story. Difficulty is fine where it is. There's also an in-game hint system which is very well incorporated into the story itself. Very unique.

While being a relatively short game, it's was fascinating from start to finish. Lots of symbolism in dialogs, which might not be everyones cup of tea. Personally, I enjoyed every second of it. Loved the art style, the story it was telling and most importantly, *how* it was telling the story. Voice acting was great for the most part. Murmur was exceptional.

A very solid game and a must-have if you like dark-themed adventure/puzzle games.

Really enjoyed this one.
developer_response: Beautiful review, and this line in particular -- "the story it was telling and most importantly, *how* it was telling the story" -- made me very happy. Many thanks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006537310', 'num_games_owned': 583, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1623144559}
review:
Something truly different in the world of point & click adventure games.

Strangeland dives deep into the darkness withing a troubled soul to search for closure that eludes them. Heavy & dark, painful & beautiful, the utter strangeness of this land calls out in every frame, in every line of dialogue. Yearning for an end.

So beautiful it hurts, so agonising it's liberating. One of the best adventure games of the last several years at least.

Gorgeous & surreal graphics. Haunting music. A compelling if heart-wrenching story. Puzzles that compel without ever being moon logic.
I can't recommend it enough, go get it and feel something real.
developer_response: Wonderful review. Very grateful for your kind words.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032150922', 'num_games_owned': 1643, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1631226053}
review:
A very gripping, interesting experience.

Strangeland has a wonderful atmosphere, great writing, phenomenal art direction, perfectly fitting soundtrack and the kind of imagery that will stick with you for a long time.

While the story presents itself in a way that makes it look more complicated than it really is, to me the real interest was trying to figure out how each of the game's segments, environments and characters fit into the larger narrative. If you like to try and find meaning in symbolism and interpret a story according to your own sensibilities, you will have a field day with Strangeland.
developer_response: Thank you so much for these kinds words -- I'm particularly pleased that you enjoyed puzzling out the symbols and allusions, something that not every player has enjoyed so much. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198055414222', 'num_games_owned': 533, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1630972760}

author: {'steamid': '76561198095203641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1630878065}
review:
Intriguing theme. Decent puzzles, nothing particularly brain bending, for good or ill. Disappointed with the ending, felt like a predictable trope. Loved the many nods to Norse Myth.

Decent adventure game, but doesn't compare to Primordia for me. Lacks the uniqueness of ideas / story, the range of puzzle solutions, and a compelling character.

Edit: For all my criticisms I did really enjoy the first two thirds of the game, great puzzles, wordplay, logical conclusions for items, good dialogue... the premise just wore thin in the third act. Also you should definitely get Primordia, 1 to support the devs, 2 it's my favourite modern adventure game
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed it overall, and that you took the time to leave a review about what you liked and didn't. Appreciate the feedback and the interest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105109732', 'num_games_owned': 1005, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1625778976}
review:
I played many if not all of the games developed or published by Wadjet Eye Games.
The games developed by David and friends are almost always solid, while games they published are usually very neat.

However I must say Strangeland is a bit disappointing in terms of story and puzzle. Feels like the writer tried so hard to put all the symbolic things and twists on a lacking storyline. I appreciate the attempt. If it worked well it could be something like the Sanitarium. But the premise is you need a solid storyline. Without that it just feels like a montage of unrelated references and symbols.The behind story of the main character is too thin, that it is very hard to connect with or care about him. After I while I just don't care anymore.

Puzzles are not top notch. Confusing at times. But they are ok.

Sorry if I sounded harsh. But I am giving my comments on the writing so I hope the dev can make a better game next time. Keep the good work and hope to see your next game.
developer_response:
Sorry you didn't like the game -- and no need to apologize for being harsh! If you don't enjoy a product you paid for, the least you should have is the consolation prize of airing your grievances as harshly as you want. Strangeland's probably not a great game for someone who gets stuck on puzzles or symbols.

I would suggest that you skip our next game, though. It's no likelier that we'll change the things we like to design than you'll change the things you like to play, and there is enough unhappiness in life without one's entertainment irritating him, too. Fortunately, there are plenty of adventure games with more straightforward puzzles and stories -- or, in any event, stories and puzzles that take a different approach that you enjoy more. No sense banging your head against our wall further. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198044644639', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1630479202}
review: I don't usually leave reviews

author: {'steamid': '76561198871478064', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1630665417}
review:
Since English is not my first language, I'm pretty sure I missed half of the metaphors, but I think I got the vibe right :p

Well, the last piece of conversation about light is beautiful, and somehow makes me think it cannot come from nowhere, it is triggered by a real loss, the beauty with sadness, a rebirth from ashes. I feel sorry for the loss and hope whoever is experiencing it already got your redemption.

btw, is it normal that after the game, I especially want some curry?

==== update 9-3 ====

After turning on commentary mode and annotation mode, I think this is a much more profound story than I realize. 

Maybe a person could only see its nature through a glitch, facing the void and darkness, accepting them and finding a way to live with them, alone or with the help of other.

I'm glad that I'm a simple person, I might just escape this part. Look at our dog! She's the happiest being in my family, lol~
developer_response:
MARK Y: I just want to echo what James said (which unfortunately cannot be done as a separate comment). Your reaction to the game's story means a lot to me! Ultimately, the themes and symbols are meant to be universal enough that many people can find their own connections to them, but also specific enough that if someone is curious as to how they all fit together, they can ponder over them or listen to the commentary/read the annotations and see where they came from. :)

JAMES S: I'm not a native speaker myself, and I feel that some of the metaphors do get lost, which is not the intention, these mostly provide depth, but the feelings evoked by the game are simple, humane, and I'm glad that gets across. 

I'm not sure about the curry craving, but quite possibly that is a side effect. Thank you for your kind kind kind words <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198031759923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1632957797}
review:
Like their earlier game Primordia, Wormwood Studios have crafted another exceptional adventure game in Strangeland. The themes of grief, loss, struggle, acceptance and transcendence are all explored in the powerful writing in this game. While the voice cast were familiar from the last game, their performances carried the game well, and I never felt pulled out of the story by them. The art is fantastic, evoking surrealist works from Man Ray, Salvador Dali, and H.R. Giger, but with a pixel art style. The game play is light, with a few puzzles, and some dialogue choices, but nothing that requires moon-logic to complete, and the narrative has a lot of tolerance of error, in fact in some parts, dying is actually required to progress! You can finish this game in a single setting if you have a few hours to spend, but that seems like just the right length to me, given the heavy nature of the subject matter. 

The obvious comparison point for Strangeland would be 1998's Sanitarium, another fine game that mixes horror with the adventure game format and I would say Strangeland holds its own there. For my part, Strangeland reminds me more of the film Eraserhead or the comic Sandman in that I find myself pondering the themes long after finishing the game.  Strangeland reminds me of playing  Wraith the Oblivion, where ghosts wander the shadowlands, bound to the world by fetters from their former life and fighting for control of their soul with their shadow, which represents everything they fear, hate or suppress about themselves. It nearly felt like a licensed game in that World of Darkness setting, which I loved about it.

Had this game released in the time before COVID it might not have the impact on me that it does. The real world tragedy very much lent pathos and connection to the story that Strangeland is telling. In a way the game is a welcome catharsis that helps make sense of the victims of the pandemic. Strangeland proves that it is possible for lightning to strike twice, and I look forward to the next project from this talented team.
developer_response: What a beautiful review. It means the world to be able to see our games through the eyes of players like you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004484646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1623201235}
review:
Wadjet Eye Games and Wormwood Studios bring another puzzle infused point and click adventure, and it's pretty damn good. I have only played one of their previous releases, Primordia, which was insanely good. I was actually notified by the developer after I reviewed it of Strangeland's close release, and had high hopes. And those hopes were met incredibly well, and makes me want to try their other games as well.
Strangeland takes a hit at what seems to be a man's mental downfall into his own mind, and even dying can't bring him out. Cryptic riddles and dialogue are all over this game, which would be much more annoying if the game was longer. However, since the average time seems to be 5-7 hours, I got used to it and began to pick up on exactly what was happening without being totally clueless. The biggest aspect I absolutely LOVE from this game is the art style. As a lover of pixel art, Strangeland knocks the ball out of the park with the art. From complicated backgrounds and even surprisingly detailed faces to even just weird hallucinogenic-like pieces, I always just found myself stopping in awe with how beautiful the game looks. The detail and art style honestly rivals Blasphemous, another insanely beautiful pixel game.
Puzzles were not too difficult and I liked the hint aspect people can use if they get too lost. Every time I solved a puzzle, continuation felt rewarding. The voice acting was also excellent. I immediately recognized Abe Goldfarb's voice (he voiced Crispin in Primordia), and he and everyone else involved really gave the game it's own charm. The characters, messaging, music, and dialogue are all there.
All in all Strangeland delivers a standout and memorable point and click adventure with gorgeous art, interesting dialogue, and satisfying puzzles. Fully recommended.
developer_response:
What an immensely satisfying review to read! It's great that Primordia led you to Strangeland, and that the latter didn't disappoint!

Many thanks for giving our games a go, and for leaving two such nice reviews.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008907637', 'num_games_owned': 485, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1632082031}
review: Great game with a lot of charm and personalityof his own, some really interesting puzzles. Overall a nice little game to test out that won't need a lot of time to complete but will stick whith you for even more !

author: {'steamid': '76561197980088665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1630259865}
review:
May all future point & clicks have the same [i]"the most important thing is to have fun"[/i] attitude: progressive contextual help, excellent design. At no point did I utter "why are devs making me do this?"; attention to "Quality of Life" / respecting player's time is everywhere. Two little examples:
- Navigation from screen to screen is fast, they're almost always framed to be immediately able to double-click the other end, making for fast and fluid traversal / gathering / experimentation.
- A repetitive action (of grabbing something 6 times at the same place) is automated once you proved to the game you understood it had to be done 6 times, by doing it 2 times

And finally, ambiance / story / visuals / voice acting / music are all excellent. But I finish with them (even though they are the "meat") because it's rare these days for me to enjoy a point&click, given how much they still generally suck with regard to QoL / help / respecting the player, and how much they repeat bad recipes from the past. Strangeland is the good vibes of old point & click, with none of the bs.

Bravo, Wormwood. Keeping an eye on your future releases.
developer_response: Very glad you enjoyed it -- especially that you appreciated the QOL features. This has been a hobbyhorse of mine for a long time (here's an almost 15-year-old article I wrote under a pen name that is on the subject : https://www.escapistmagazine.com/v2/the-four-virtues-of-freecell/), and I feel we achieved the goal better on SL than we did on Primordia. Hope our future games hit the mark, too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198405524030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1632375948}
review: It's a definite throwback game with the feel of the late 80's and early 90's click-and-point adventure games, but with the benefits of much faster computers to run it on. A very trippy game. Without spoilering it or anything, you can be the bad guy or the good guy, it really won't matter - though perhaps you might want to try being both. Definitely something that would be even better appreciated with a slight buzz. And it has developer/programmer commentary tracks, too, which I happen to like. It's interesting - after you've played through once without it - to hear them talk about the development of the game. The answers aren't easily given to you, though hints are available via the payphone (blast from the past!). I definitely enjoyed it. The art style was pretty cool, too - definitely a very retro feel to it. I could picture playing something like this on my old Commodore 64, though it would be much slower and probably fill up about twenty of those old 5" floppies, lol.
developer_response: I'm glad you had a good time and thank you for taking the time to do this small but very fascinating write up of your thoughts and experience. It would take 1041 floppy disks [compressed game] and 3241 [uncompressed game] but I do understand that sentiment, and I personally feel the same way!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048202637', 'num_games_owned': 587, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1629948438}
