author: {'steamid': '76561197972624697', 'num_games_owned': 893, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1629954704}
review:
Wormwood Studios produces yet another excellent modern point & click adventure game. Sharing many strengths with their previous entry, Primordia, Strangeland features superb visuals, writing and voice acting. It also feels like a deeply personal game, filled with a lot of sadness and grief.

The Writing & Performance

With an adventure game, you want a strong story. With Strangeland, you get a dreamlike, contemplative narrative of one man's journey through his own trauma related to his dead partner. The actor who plays the protagonist (Abe Goldfarb) does a lot of heavy lifting here, and I appreciate the range and passion he put into each performance. When it comes to a dreamlike setting like this, it's difficult to keep a story thread that is still coherent, and while I don't think it completely overcomes this limitation it wields it very well. (Shout out also goes to the clown (who I believe was Mike Pollock) who created a really distinctive laugh with the bizarre clown character.)

The Art

There have been comparisons to other artists such as H.R. Giger or Beksinski, but I don't think it's quite right. It's gothic and has body horror, but I feel it's distinct enough that it doesn't feel derivative like The Medium felt at times with Beksinski. That said, it does a great job getting that epic, despairing aesthetic that the previously mentioned artists evoke. There are multiple sequences (some featured in the trailer) that I really enjoyed as morbid art. The music and sound design also fit perfectly. The ambient sound was on point.

The Puzzles

Adventure games often hinge on the quality of its puzzle design. Strangeland opens with an interesting but welcome message that you will have access to all the information you need in any puzzle, and that there would be no information you need to memorize. This was true, and it also helped me solve a certain puzzle. If you get stuck otherwise, there is an in-game method to get hints that I found were always the right balance between being helpful without giving it away.

Conclusion

If you're a fan of point & click adventure games, I would get this without hesitation. It's really great to see the devs of these games grow and flourish, and I hope to see more.

P.S. Dear Mark Y --

You responded to my review of Primordia in 2016, and I had never had a dev respond to my review before. It was awesome. I also see you're responding to reviews here, so I just wanted to say something to you directly. Both this game and Primordia are some of my favorite games, and I love to see these sorts of story-driven adventure games still being made in 2021. Thank you so much for you and your team's effort in making these cool experiences. Please keep making more, as any game from Wormwood Studios is an automatic buy from me. I didn't realize it had been so long since you had released this one -- I guess Steam has room for improvement in surfacing games from developers I really like (though better late than never). Cheers to you and the team -- thanks for the great experiences!!

P.P.S.

     And the Raven, never flitting, still is sitting, still is sitting
On the pallid bust of Pallas just above my chamber door;
    And his eyes have all the seeming of a demon’s that is dreaming,
    And the lamp-light o’er him streaming throws his shadow on the floor;
And my soul from out that shadow that lies floating on the floor
            Shall be lifted—nevermore!
developer_response: Thank you for the beautiful review and for the personal note at the end.  We're very lucky to have the support of players like you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045736635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1629491445}
review:
好一陣子沒玩到這麼精緻的點擊解迷了
總算是暫時止了渴
-
7/10
-
謎題都滿簡單的
除了電話號碼 那個大概要對英文的熟悉度到一定高度才能自己解吧
不過即使是電話號碼的謎題 打電話求助都能直接問出來
電話求助這點滿有趣的
比起一般給個hint按鍵 這遊戲的提示方式是打電話
這代表每一句提示都有配音 而且帶有劇情向的情緒
沒有從頭到尾不聽提示的成就 所以不妨有事沒事去聽個提示 那也是遊戲內容阿

劇情上算是普普
比較特別的是塞了很多北歐神話 西洋文學之類的引用
這部分就見仁見智了 知道出處的人就會眼睛一亮 不知道的人就只能無視了
我自己只認得出大概一到兩成吧
至於遊戲本身的劇情倒是很好猜
-
射擊遊戲的成就滿難的
-
整體的美術風格
算還不錯吧

-
快速存檔只會存在AUTO SAVE那一格
不會分開一個一個存
請注意
-
對話都可以一句一句快進

遊戲時數偏短
-
沒有分支
但是結局有四個選項
-
很高興看到2021還有人願意繼續做點擊解謎類的遊戲
而且不是那種大家來找碴類型的
加上這款難度真的低 又是線性劇情
很適合沒玩過這類型遊戲 又有興趣的人來玩玩看

author: {'steamid': '76561197962833906', 'num_games_owned': 590, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1630384957}
review:
I give this game a cautious recommendation.  Although I enjoyed the puzzles and the weirdness of the setting/characters, the actual substance behind the writing feels a little weak.  All the dialogue seems to be trying to sound dreamlike/prophetic/profound, as if you're talking to figments  of your imagination that are all deranged Confuciuses.  And although it sounds cool in the moment, upon reflection it doesn't particularly tie together that well to an overall narrative. A large part of the supposedly profound and insightful dialogue is just rambling without any strong connection to a central narrative.

Maybe that's what the writer wanted to preserve a more dream-like feeling to the experience and project a wandering mind just like in a dream, but I found myself speed-reading some dialogue and clicking through it faster than the voice could deliver it as it wore on me and started to feel a little pretentious. 

So if you like adventure games and weird settings give it a shot, and see for yourself if the writing is for you.
developer_response:
Glad you liked the game overall, though I'm sorry that the story didn't gel for you. I certainly think the dialogue is connected to the central narrative, but it doesn't really matter what the writer thinks -- the relevant question is how it's experienced by the player.

Still, if you're curious about the connections, you might poke around with the commentary and annotations on. That doesn't "fix" the experience you have, but it might be interesting in its own right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019651823', 'num_games_owned': 651, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1629248372}
review:
This game is a tad bit short (finished it in about two hours and a half) but it's very amazing. It's surreal and dreamlike, has a wonderful art style, and a great soundtrack. If you're a fan of classical point and click adventure games, this game is definitely for you. The price, in my opinion, is a bit high for a game this short, but the game comes with annotations and commentary that you can enable whenever you want (but it's preferable you enable them after your first playthrough.)

If you're a sucker for point-and-click adventure games, definitely get this one. However, there's no shame in waiting on a sale.
developer_response:
Hey Greyline, thank you for the kind words, not to be disrespectful towards your review or opinion, but to add to it, is that the median time is 3-4 hours, which is of course on the short side, most people take about 4 hours, you really sped through it (that's a compliment!) I'm also quite sure, Mark Yohalem, our writer, who came up with annotations appreciates your wonderful wonderful critique about that. 

I'm glad you had a good time <3

author: {'steamid': '76561197995382795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1629060019}
review:
Great game, love point and clicks. If you were a fan of Dark Seed and/or can handle the H.R. Giger-esque art and some trauma related concepts, you'll love this well written, dark and cryptic journey of troubled introspection. Cool and creepy with sometimes eerily relateable messages depending on how you interpret everything. It's got that almost horror-like vibe that seems cheesy at first and then grows on you. Just a hapless fellow in a nightmare carnival.
Also, the game is pretty good at avoiding the frustration that other point-and-click puzzle games have by generally not having overly obscure and unintuitive puzzles and interactions. And while you could still get stuck, there's a built in hint system because you can literally call for help.
Find yourself an evening for a funky mood, 4 spare hours, and go for a ride in Strangeland.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words -- you hit on many things that we put a lot of effort into (mood, hints, puzzle intuitiveness, etc.), and it means a lot that they worked for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198871946895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1628969778}
review: If only they made more point and click games like this. The horror elements are *chefs kiss*
developer_response:
Thank you so much! We're honored by, and grateful for, your reaction.

P&C is a great genre, and there are a good number of horror P&Cs worth checking out -- not dozens, but at least a handful!  Stasis and Beautiful Desolation are achingly beautiful, The Cat Lady and its sequels are unsettling and very personal, Sanitarium -- despite its outrageously slow walk speed -- is a classic, I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream is too depressing/grotesque for me but it's obviously a classic, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048732371', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1628044394}

Couldn't wait for them to play it again the next week, I had to see what happened next. Was not disappointed!
developer_response: Wonderful to hear -- we've been so fortunate to have streamers large and small play Strangeland, and of course fortunate to have players leave kind reviews of it on Steam. author: {'steamid': '76561199090152711', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1671774723}
review:
While I'm always happy to play a good point & click by wormwood studios, I really hate how short all their games are...!!!
I mean I'm glad that they're obviously talented enough to make a point and click with very little frames, BUT THAT'S JUST FUCKING BORING!!! The WHOLE POINT of a good Point & Click is that it's long as fucking shit, and there are LOTS of frames to go through!!! Wormwood's are even MORE SO HELD BACK SOMEHOW by the Point & Click genre's most important and prominent lesson, FUNDAMENTAL to a good Point & Click! Coming across a frame in the game with one or multiple puzzles that require items from other frames, and backtracking to it later on!!! Because you have to STILL do that in Strangeland AND Primordia, it makes the environments eventually get too fucking old for your liking AND BORING!!! Because by following basic point and click game logic when it comes to backtracking, which is probably the ONLY thing Wormwood is good at, it takes AWAY EVEN MORE re-playability AWAY from their games!!! You've GOTTEN bored of the same environments over and fucking over again, you KNOW the solution to every puzzle or atleast most of them by memory, until you can basically solve ALL of them when you replay the game, because you'll remember EVERYTHING!!! You've TALKED to the surmount of NPC's the developers at Wormwood even bothered to put in the game! AND YOU HAVE LISTENED TO A VERY SHORT STORY!!! POINT AND CLICK IS ABOUT AS LINEAR AS IT  FUCKING GETS!!! WHILE STRANGELAND AND PRIMORDIA ARE AT THE MOST, INEXPENSIVE, REALLY CHEAP GAMES, IT STILL FEELS LIKE I COMPLETELY WASTED MY FUCKING MONEY!!! ESPECIALLY WHEN THERE'S SOME STUPID ASSHOLE CHARACTER LIKE CRISPIN OR EVEN YOU ON A RETARDED TELEPHONE THAT BABY THROUGH ALL THE PUZZLES IF YOU CAN'T FIGURE IT OUT!!! IF WORMWOOD JUST DIDN'T INCLUDE THESE STUPID USELESS CHARACTERS, THEN MAYBE I'D ACTUALLY CONSIDER THEIR GAMES "GAMES", FUCK NO!!! THESE INCONCEIVABLE RETARDS LITERALLY TOOK AWAY ALL PLAYER CONTROL IN ALL OF THEIR  ONLY TWO GAMES, YOU CAN LITERALLY BEAT FUCKING BOTH OF THEM ON FUCKING AUTOPILOT!!! I HAVE TO INTENTIONALLY NOT USE AN IN-GAME FUCKING CHEAT INCLUDED BY THE DEVELOPERS THEMSELVES TO ATLEAST PLAY SOME SEMBLANCE OF A VIDEO GAME!!!

The last things I have to say is that: Strangeland's story is borderline retarded when we don't even learn who the stranger and some copy and paste blonde bitch I don't even care about ARE, even though the developers at Wormwood could've just gotten off their lazy incompetent asses and just given them ANY KIND OF BACKSTORY!!! I don't care about the people in this world!
Primordia's story is actually good, but again, all of that is completely fucking ruined, because the game's too FUCKING SHORT YOU RETARDS!!! Why couldn't we have just stretched out the adventure, you idiot's literally chose THE VIDEO GAME GENRE THAT HAS NEXT TO KNOW FUCKING RE-PLAYABILITY!!! Unless you want to re-scramble the letters or numbers or symbols or what the fuck ever for a stupid numbers puzzle somewhere in the game, THAT'S FUCKING IT!!!

For the people who are not a WormWood employee reading this review, your money is either spent on a MUCH LONGER point & click game or a COMPLETELY different fucking genre entirely, that actually has some goddamn re-playability for fucks sake. Buy an action game, or a strategy game like Civilization 6 and all its DLC, because I know I could've done way better than all this crap. 0/10 for both.
developer_response:
It's one thing finding the game disappointing, which I understand and we apologize for it, we always want to satisfy all our players. At the same time, I think bashing us intellectually for wanting to make the game more accessible to people and not forcing people to alt-tab to find out the solution, is not a good take. Both in-game systems are integrated and not mandatory, nothing forced you to talk to Crispin in the case of Primordia and nothing forced you to hit 0 on the phone.

Point and click games in their majority do not have much replayability, minus different endings. At the end of the day, we're making the games we want to make, it's hard to read a review that's very insulting and actually take it seriously.

If you want, i'll gladly pay you back the money. Even offer to buy you a different game. Please edit your review and blank out the r words tho.

Adding a backstory to a game that works as a vessel for the player would be too cheesy and too done to death. The game works as a mirror, if you don't have much to say, neither will the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198349544262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 680, 'last_played': 1627258284}
review:
Primordia was among the reasons I learned English, and is my favourite point-and-click. (I don't play a lot of them, so excuse my taste.) So, I had some expectations for Strangeland.

I didn't vibe with Strangeland as much, but the quality (both technical and story-wise) is 100% there - and I enjoyed the game a lot. I gained a special appreciation fot the game and its themes after listening to the in-game commentary. Thank you, Wormwood Studios!

P.S. Victor, if you're reading this - I too think that the Folktek stuff is great :) It's a bit too esoteric to my taste, but still - great stuff.
developer_response: Thanks so much -- what a lovely review to read!

author: {'steamid': '76561198272651591', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1627764168}
review:
This is a short and overall enjoyable adventure game. Too bad I cannot rate it as high as the other games published by Wadjet Eye Games, because for me there were too many external references. There's almost not a single line not referencing some book, or Scandinavian mythology, or psychoanalysis, or being a direct quote. I would like to get to know the story itself, the characters, their backgrounds, their past. Instead, sometimes I felt like I was reading through somewhat obscure lecture notes. Discovering hidden allusions and references is fun, but not when you're doing that constantly.
 
That aside, the game raises fairly serious topics, pixel art is decent, puzzles are good, and Abe Goldfarb's voice acting is great as always. It's probably worth playing just to hear him again.

I would love to see an extended version someday. If we could get more mundane stuff about MC's life, that would both make us sympathize with him more and create a great background for all those allusions to shine against.

P.S. My initial response was "Not Recommended", but then I realized I still got a surprisingly long and pleasant aftertaste, and I feel like replaying it to capture even more references. So I guess it's fair to change this review to a positive one.
developer_response: Very sorry that you didn't enjoy it! I don't think it's necessary that players catch the references (any of them, let alone all of them), but I can see how for some the extent of references/symbolism could be irritating.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980958847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1627736068}

author: {'steamid': '76561198321234680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1627480424}
review:
Sehr gutes Spiel, die Welt von Strangeland zu betreten und die mit ihr zu interagieren ist einfach klasse. Gerade die Thematik ist gut gewählt und holt einen gleich von Anfang an ab. 
Daumen hoch. 
Die kürze des Spieles hat mich etwas gestört da ich gerne noch länger in Strangeland verbleiben würde.
developer_response: Vielen Dank! Ich stimme zu, dass das Spiel ziemlich kurz ist (teilweise aufgrund von Dingen wie dem schnellen Reisen zwischen Räumen, aber es gab auch eine Grenze für die Menge an Inhalten, die das Thema unterstützen konnte). Es gibt jedoch eine gewisse Wiederspielbarkeit, insbesondere wenn Sie den Kommentaren und Anmerkungen einen Blick darauf werfen möchten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018894642', 'num_games_owned': 1516, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1627484991}
review:
This game really brought me back right away to my younger gaming days on the PC with its point and click style of play and pixelated art style, reminiscent of games like Gemini Rue.

The color scheme is dark, gritty and miserable. The music twisted and perfectly suited to the atmosphere.  The characters you meet are well, certainly strange and talk in metaphors and riddles. This adds to the feeling that your losing your sanity as you traverse through this hellish, twisted world that is inside your own mind. 

The style of art will not be for everyone true but if you can look past the retro look and focus on the story it has substance.  The game is full of puzzles, finding items to use on other items, combining items to make new ones and solving riddles to progress. 

You really need to approach this game with a more open mind as it's not your typical adventure game. For me it has nostalgic flavors that make me appreciate the game. But that does not hold true for everyone. I recommend the game as I personally enjoyed it but it's hard to judge this one for the greater masses. ❤️
developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind words -- glad we were able to tickle the nostalgia bone. :)

Одна беда - придётся сидеть с переводчиком и переводить...

In case the developer reads my review (as it was last time) - I express my deep gratitude for this game, it was a very cool experience and a psychedelic journey.

PS
And of course phone number situation :)
My english still too low skill for tricks like that.

Мы работаем над переводом на русский язык, поэтому, надеюсь, когда-нибудь игрокам не придется делать паузы, чтобы воспользоваться переводчиком - какая боль! Я удивлен, что вам удалось таким образом пройти через игру. Полагаю, это неукротимый русский дух, победивший Наполеона и т. Д. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970687509', 'num_games_owned': 1185, 'num_reviews': 283, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1626558809}
review:
Wormwood Studios have done it again. Primordia was a brilliant game that I devoured from start to finish because of its atmosphere, characters, music and voice acting. Strangeland is different, but shares all the same qualities and is brilliant just as well. I will not pretend to publicly interpret its meaning and I feel there is no need to do so: the story had meaning for myself and that is all that matters.

Some notes gameplay-wise: The recently released Linux version started fine but had some problems with a choppy mouse cursor, so I played the Windows version via Proton. Worked just fine as well. I finished the game in basically one sitting and never had a technical problem. Used the in-game hint system (btw, brilliant way to implement this) twice when I was stuck, but otherwise the puzzles fit right into my line of thinking and I could concentrate on the story.

Best part of the game and following Primordia one could think that this is a Wormwood staple: the combination of atmospheric music and voice acting. The scene with the wise man and the raven is dripping with greatness to the point where I wished it was possible to listen to the wise words in the context of that scene for hours.
developer_response: Thank you so much! Very glad to hear you enjoyed it, especially coming from a return customer. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198044609295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1626566405}
review: Primoria is probably my favorite point-and-click adventure of all time, and I just cannot stand this game. The puzzles are consistently mediocre, the art is all over the place, and the writing is a weird combination of obvious and obtuse - it either beats you over the head or misses you by a mile. There's some clever stuff here and there, but overall it feels like the very definition of pretentious; its a game with a pretense of depth, or having something to say at nearly every juncture, but in reality whenever this game opens its mouth its to bend over to fellate itself.
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience! I hope you'll get a refund -- I'd hate to think that you'd lost not only your time and positive expectations, but also your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198291108165', 'num_games_owned': 924, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1630867922}
review:
[h1]"Where madness is rooted in myth amid the void"[/h1]

[i][b]Strangeland[/b][/i] is a surreal, nightmarish point'n'click adventure game, deeply allegorical, set in a twisted, creepy carnival. With symbols, metaphors, archetypes and associations galore, this game is all about workings of the subconscious, the unraveling of the mind, the underside of working through grief and guilt.  

It's a long-awaited title from the creators of [i]Primordia[/i] (and this should already be enough to get you interested), but instead of its decaying mechanical world amidst desolate post-apocalyptic landscapes, here we have something more organic, curvy, wavy, meandering, almost Gigeresque, even if still a bit monochrome... and decaying. The game is a visual delight, even with rather disturbing imagery or precisely because of it. Art is pixelated like its predecessor, but more smooth with subtle animations from details in the fantastical scenery to full blown CGs. Every creature, every weird thing you encounter is there to reflect the inner.

By setting it in a surreal carnival, Strangeland immediately calls to mind another nightmarish horror game, a great macabre classic [i]Sanitarium[/i]. There's something inherently creepy about carnivals, a place where anything could happen, like a dream, wondrous  and pleasant, turning into a nightmare. The dark side of what's supposed to be fun and shiny and colourful, the underbelly, the unconscious (id). A Purgatory of sorts, it's a fitting stage for the Danse Macabre. *1

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2535211854
[h3][i]You never know till the end whether something's a comedy or a tragedy[/i][/h3] 

I heard this line a few times in the game, and besides it expressing the tragicomical nature of one's life/fate/story, it got me thinking how unlike [i]Cat Lady[/i] which was relentlessly bleak and depressing, I actually had... fun here, even a few laughs, but there wasn't any real doubt how this would turn out. Still, with all the cryptic lines and wordplay, references, associations and symbolism, witty quips, I had great fun. Hey, I rode a giant cicada after all~

You're a [i]Stranger in a Strange Land[/i] and whether your first thought is Moses or Heinlein, feeling a disconnect (from self) is a big theme. Well, you are thrust into this weird, twisted carnival in a straitjacket, totally confused and after going through this giant clown's mouth (a real comedian telling you grim jokes every time you pass through it - the joke's on you), you witness a woman jump into the well. Immediately you get a phone call telling you "It's all your fault". This part reminded me of Lynch's [i]Lost Highway[/i] a bit, with a mystery man acting as the accuser, the adversary (Satan, eh), your nemesis, alter-ego, or The Dark Thing as it's called here. It was clear this would be an introspective game (literally) that deals with coping with loss, learning acceptance and finding peace with yourself. In that sense, I wouldn't call it a mystery, even though it is for Stranger while he explores this strange world, trying to kill The Shadow and save The Woman, all the while falling deeper into himself until he's ready to confront the truth.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2536168616
[h3][i]A masquerade of metaphors[/i][/h3]

The game is very rich thematically and going through it all and peeling all the layers of meaning is beyond the scope of this review (some deeper analysis would be fun), but I will mention some that jumped at me. 

There are clear inspirations from Biblical and Norse mythology, myths in general. The image of the blind old scribe under a tree with a raven spitting words at him clearly points to Odin under the Tree of Life. But later it gets a poisonous snake on it making it also into the Tree of Knowledge. The idea of a poisonous knowledge is tightly connected to another prevailing theme: comfortable darkness. One character says: "Better to be in the darkness, I can't see or be seen", expressing a subconscious desire to repress, to forget. "You took my shadows!" "At last I was truly in the dark."  Darkness takes away sight, but also gives it. 

Masks/masquerades is a reoccurring motive and comes in threes. Three Valkyries, Fates, Weird Sisters - The Triple Goddess, act as Greek Chorus of sorts. And then mirrored, we have the triple me, Past, Present and Future self. They all wear masks, masquerading as men ('cause there's place for only one Woman here' - heh) or you. A mask is a cover, worn by an actor in a tragedy, but also a weight, a burden. Beneath one mask there is another, like a matryoshka. 'Can you truly take off your mask? Set down your burden?' What is beneath it all, at the bottom? What bottom?

This game likes words, words to forget, words to remember, wordplay (tarot, rota, Inside-Rotta, Nein-Eve, Nineveh, 83, Eitri), different meanings of words (imago, masca), word puzzles etc. I loved it! Lots of interesting insights can be gleaned from 'machine-men', dead rats and all the mirror symbolism, but alas, no space for that here. 

Overall, the symbolism isn't too obscure to leave you scratching your head, but just right to tickle your imagination and get your inner wheels spinning. Nor is it too obvious but when it is, the game is aware and comments on it: "You walked through your mouth to get here" of course it's in your head; "Only a fool thinks he needs a broken mirror to reflect a broken man"; golden-haired Woman, his shining light, indicating idealisation and pedestaling etc. Also, there's a commentary and annotations mode that explains the intentions and meaning behind some symbols, but while interesting, I wouldn't rely on it for interpretation...*2

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2545112955
[h2][i]What bottom?[/i][/h2]

Underneath it all (at the bottom?) Strangeland is a classic point'n'click game, but like all Wadjet Eye Games I played, one that doesn't have all those annoying gameplay elements the genre is famous for. There's no pixel hunting, only a few hotspots per screen, small inventory isn't full of useless junk (well depends on how you see a dead rat skin). There's a nice feature: you can browse your inventory by just scrolling your mouse wheel and not actually opening it. And despite the crazy, bizarre setting there's no bizarre logic involved when it comes to solving tasks... mostly. Only one puzzle (phone number) felt a bit out of the left field, but I wouldn't call it bizarre, just obscure. In hindsight, it makes perfect sense and utilizes wordplay this game likes so much. But hints are strewn across the environment, so you can always solve things in different ways. In the end, if nothing works, there's phone hint system where all you need to do is dial 0 to be pointed in the right direction. Not to mention, listen to the crow-raven! Actually listen to every cryptic line for they may not be so cryptic, but actual hints for puzzles, along with having deeper symbolic meaning. I really like how the writing is seamlessly incorporated into the gameplay. *3  

You can die here. You should die. Die a lot in every possible way (there's a prize). Sometimes dying is a part of puzzle solving. But since this is a dreamlike world, you don't lose anything, you just respawn at the start screen. Backtracking isn't actually daunting (and there's a fast travel at exits) cause the gameworld isn't that big. There are a few locations and while very creative visually and even with different versions (Deadland), the world still feels small, for better or worse.  

At bottom, with excellent writing and voice acting, creative visuals and dark ambient music, Strangeland is a must play for adventure fans. Even though it's on the shorter side and while feeling small in width, it seems bottomless in depth. You bet I recommend it!

[h3][quote][b]Curated by [url= https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40848670/]Drugoja In The Dreaming[/url][/b][/quote][/h3]
developer_response: I've been looking forward to this review while watching your screenshots pile up, and it doesn't disappoint. Many thanks for the thoughtful and thought-provoking analysis.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998332408', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 901, 'last_played': 1623261501}
review:
In keeping with Wormwood Studios tradition, this was an excellent game.  Intriguing story and themes.  Excellent acting, stunning and occasionally upsetting artwork :)

I'm not a huge fan of the [spoiler]all in the characters head[/spoiler] type narratives, since it often undermines the stakes of the story, but this one was told well enough and the themes explored so interestingly and uniquely that it negated my usual aversion.

Also, the commentary was particularly good.  Yohalem's delivery can be a little dry, but his insights and observations are so thoughtful and informative that it balances out just fine.
developer_response:
It's all the microphone's fault! :D

In seriousness, thank you for this kind review -- I'm especially glad that the game succeeded despite a skepticism for its formula. Much love!

author: {'steamid': '76561197978550579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1626538138}
review:
Fantastically surreal and disturbing visuals, combined with sometimes challenging, sometimes just plain fun puzzles. Also, the voice actors do a great job (with is on par with all games published by Wadjet Eye Games).

If you've played the classic adventure game Sanitarium, you'll see some common threads, though Strangeland feels more personal and twisted.

As a fan of both point-and-click and horror - I loved every minute!
developer_response:
" sometimes challenging, sometimes just plain fun puzzles."

Couldn't ask for a better reaction!

author: {'steamid': '76561198029879585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1626521528}

author: {'steamid': '76561198008452457', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1668526516}
review:
THIS GAME IS AWESOME. 

I loved every aspect of game-play, story and improvement from their previous game.
the only thing that really sucks is... THE GAME IS INSANELY SHORT LIKE THIS IS A 3-4 HOURS GAME 
that's nothing.... i wish they maybe make a director cut so they could add more stuff.
OHHH... and also the phone guide thing... kinda ruins the game for me because instead of giving me hints on how to progress. it just tell me what to do and makes me feel dumb. (maybe that was their point idk)



this is a solid short point and click game  i cannot wait to see a new project from this guys  

8/10 (make it longer next time pls)   (:
developer_response: Thanks! Part of the brevity is because we tried to cut a lot of fat out of adventures (slow walk speed, "puzzles" that require backtracking across long distances, lengthy non-interactive cutscenes, etc.), but I do think that if we make another, we'll probably shoot for a somewhat longer experience. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197969870364', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1626351407}

This is made by the team that made Primordia which is one of my favorite adventure games of all time.  They did not disappoint. I highly recommend this game.  Play it in the dark with headphones on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084351472', 'num_games_owned': 481, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1626213049}
review: Thank you, Wormwood Studios for a memorable experience. I completed the game this evening in one sitting. Engrossed at the subject matter - living in the world in this time... full of its horrors... death and depression... thank you for shining a little bit of light (you can probably guess which ending I chose) in the darkness. Loss is immeasurable, but so is the love left behind.
developer_response:
"Loss is immeasurable, but so is the love left behind."

Beautiful. My thanks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964351915', 'num_games_owned': 1223, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1625923615}
review:
I liked this game a lot, but I did think it was rather short.

I didn't find any puzzles that completely halted me, except for one near the beginning regarding a phone number which still doesn't make sense to me. But the game is happy to provide enough in-game hints to get you through rather than forcing you to rely on a walkthrough. The hint, in this case, goes as far to solve the puzzle for you if you ask enough times.

I think it would've been nice to get the characters to repeat what they said, even when it didn't matter, as sometimes I felt like I would've liked to hear the lines again, as the voice acting is mostly above par and the lines are pretty interesting. Lines that do matter can be repeated.
developer_response:
Glad you enjoyed it! Whether to have lines repeat is always a tricky thing -- to me, it feels less natural and more "game-y." It can also make the player feel a bit overwhelmed when there are a lot of topics and none of them go away.

At one stage, we actually had a dialogue log (the code for it is still probably lurking in the game), but I decided that it didn't quite fit the surreal/dream-like atmosphere, since dreams are so fleeting in our consciousness.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116496879', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1627575929}
review:
Интересный, атмосферный сюрреалистичный квест с интригующим сюжетом, который я не хочу спойлерить, занятными головоломками, не скатывающимися ни в излишнюю простоту, ни в излишнюю сложность и удобной системой подсказок, которые не дадут вам совсем затупить, но в тоже время, не будут вести вас за ручку всё время. Тексты тут, правда, не из простых. Поэтому, я надеюсь, её переведут на русский. Вроде разрабы писали, что ведут работу в этом направлении.

Very atmosperic and interesting adventure game with nice difficulty balance for it's puzzles. Highly recomended for all fans of the genre. Especially modern indie titles. Although text can be hard sometimes. We all need this Russian translation. ;)
developer_response:
Большое спасибо! Мы надеемся получить русский перевод, но перевод всегда требует времени, фанатский перевод занимает больше времени, а в Strangeland есть сложный и сложный текст. Однако я уверен в нашем переводчике и надеюсь, что мы сможем представить эту игру большему количеству российских игроков! 

Thank you so much! We hope to have a Russian translation, but translations always take time, fan translations take more time, and Strangeland has some dense and tricky text. I'm confident in our translator, though, and hopeful we will be able to bring this game to more Russian players!

author: {'steamid': '76561198081477001', 'num_games_owned': 577, 'num_reviews': 290, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1625118879}
review:
There are two points to discuss here.

[b]One.
Adventure game design[/b]

Context: I've never been a point-and-click adventure game player. I can understand the appeal of FPS, RTS, blobbers and RPGs of old, but the solution-finding process in classical adventure has always frustrated me. I could never get the feel for consistency of puzzle logic in any of the games in this genre that I played - with probably the sole exception of [i]Loom[/i].

Now that I've said it, at no point did [i]Strangeland[/i] frustrate me. All the threads that your mind should pick up are clearly communicated, you are never left without at least some sort of direction, never forced to just roam around clicking everything or trying all of your inventory on every object in the world. Does it mean [i]Strangeland[/i] is the best point-and-click adventure I've ever played? Well... Yes. I'm not a connoisseur, but yes.

There's also an ambiguous matter of a phone booth. At literally every moment and every step of every puzzle you can pick up the phone, dial up 0 and the voice on the other end will just blatantly spill out what you have to do. I understand why the author would want it in the game: to give the soft modern player an option to simply skip the puzzle. But... I found myself using it a bit too often in the second half of the game. And I know why. Because of blunt laziness. I know for a fact that if I'd put in a tiny bit more effort to remember my options (or in a few cases any effort at all), I would have solved the puzzle without help. Not calling for help requires a certain degree of adventure game ethic which I know I lack. It would probably be a good idea to limit access to it with... Something. I don't neccessarily mean objects like coins to be found in the world, but maybe a negative aesthetic change in the player model? Or a phone booth entourage? A rude mockery  of the protagonist who calls way too often - by every character in the game? Something to psychologically discourage the player from abusing the hint system would be needed.



[b]Two.
Everything else[/b]

I didn't like the objective narrative behind the allegories.
There's way too much unneccessary talk in this game in my opinion.
The protagonist voiceover is mixed: sometimes he sounds half-hysterical and out of breath which is good, but sometimes he's confident and even witty which is just out of place.

That being said, let me describe the feeling I got from playing this game. It's as if I'm lying down on my back and my abdomen is open, and it's a filthy ocean without bottom - with unidentifiable chunks of something sporadically floating up to the surface. And somebody is stirring it all with a huge wooden paddle-like ladle and occasionally feeding me with it.
Logocentrism be damned, this is a game to live through. It's loathsome crippling self-consumption made into an interactive experience. Perhaps, it lacks true XXth century-style inhumanity to go all the way, but other than that it's as far as it can go.
And also Jungian tradition is strong with this one.

Although narratively I would like it to be even less polished, even less consistent, even less streamlined, even more spasmodic, even more guttural, but atmospherically it is all of those things and then some.
And also the best point-and-click adventure game I've ever played, whatever that means.
developer_response:
Quite a review! :)  I really enjoyed reading it.

"The best point-and-click adventure game I've ever played" -- especially coming from a Loom fan -- means a lot. I liked the description of the feeling you got from the game, as morbid as it is.

Re: the hint system, your reaction is reasonable, but I disagree. It's a tricky thing to calibrate, but players actually get quite mad when soliciting hints results in the game insulting them too much. Even as it is, some players have felt the "operator" is too insulting. The reason is that most players who get stuck are ALREADY frustrated, and they tend to feel the fault is with the game for not clearly signaling what they should do, rather than with themselves for missing the signals. (This is a fair reaction, and a natural one.) When the game then attacks them for needing help, the result is a counter-attack from the player at the game -- "You think I'm stupid? *You're* stupid!" So the goal is to have at least a little resistance built in (e.g., the hint system isn't available in every room, it requires a couple steps to get a hint, the hint dispenser mocks you for needing them), but no too much resistance.

And, above all, the reality is that if you make in-game hints too much of a hassle, players will just alt-tab to a guide. This is an all around worse situation. It breaks immersion, it creates a considerable risk that the player will see solutions to other puzzles that he could've solved on his own, and even setting those issues aside, it means that the first hint the player gets is an outright solution (whereas we often give the player a nudge the first time, then a solution).

I don't disagree with the sentiment that easy hints tend to take away some of the fun of adventure games, but since easy hints are going to be there no matter, you have to mitigate the issue rather than trying to solve it outright.

Anyway, thanks again for giving the game a go and for leaving your review!

author: {'steamid': '76561197966471297', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1625112092}
review:
tldr: 10/10 would catch rats for cab fare

Overall, a solid adventure game. Art is great, puzzles are largely intuitive, the world itself is well-realized and internally consistent, and there are nice little touches (try drinking the acid) that are much appreciated. The script is clever and well-written, voice acting is great too. This is from the same studio that put together Primordia, and I managed a recent replay of that as well. You can clearly see how they've improved since Primordia, making the interface more lightweight, eschewing tedious puzzles (the second "bread" puzzle plays with this in a great way), and cleaner, faster-to-traverse levels.

Definite buy, get Primordia as well (I'd say Primordia is actually the superior game due to its setting/universe)
While you're at it, Wadjet Eye's back catalogue is full of winners, and download Yahtzee's Chzo mythos if you're into some creepy adventure games. 
Looking forward to the studio's next game 

[spoiler]which hopefully won't be another fever dream. It means the events are insignificant in the game's own universe, and even the denouement is unsatisfying. One minute in: We are in a dream sequence, and the ending will feature the main character letting go of whatever trauma is behind his self-inflicted torture, and you can't save the girl, because that is what always happens in dream sequences. So formulaic. And you don't discover enough about the events underlying the trauma to make that interesting either. But that's on me, sounds like a lot of other people had the setting really resonate for them.[/spoiler]
developer_response: Thanks! Glad you enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198121208934', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1623265049}
review:
Greek Review: https://gamesenpai.gr/strangeland-review/

--- A sorter version in english ---
If you want to feel the glorious age of adventure games from the 90s, then without any second thought you must play Strangeland. The atmosphere and the theme might not be everyones cup of tea, but that does not exclude that it is a very good game. From the sound and the audio, to the story, that might be simple to some, it is great. The biggest flaw, for me, might be the exclusion of cancelling an interaction, which might cause more deaths than normally. Overall, this project makes you excited for the future of Wormwood Studios and their next announcement.

--- A sorter version in greek ---
Αν θέλετε να βιώσετε την ένδοξη εποχή των adventures του ‘90, τότε χωρίς δεύτερη σκέψη να παίξετε το Strangeland. Προφανώς, η ατμόσφαιρα και η θεματική δεν θα αρέσει σε όλους, αλλά δεν εξαιρεί ότι αποτελεί μία πολύ τίμια προσπάθεια. Από τον οπτικοακουστικό τομέα, μέχρι και την ιστορία, η οποία θα φανεί απλή για κάποιος, είναι υπέροχο. Το μεγαλύτερο παράπονο αποτελεί την μη επιλογή να κάνετε cancel κάποια κίνηση σας, η οποία μπορεί να σας κοστίσει κάποιους παραπάνω θανάτους. Εν τέλει, το project αυτό σε κάνει να ανυπομονείς για το μέλλον της Wormwood Studios, καθώς και την επόμενή τους ανακοίνωση.
developer_response:
Many thanks, not just for this short summary, but for the longer review, which I quite enjoyed reading when it was first posted.

Much love to you and the site!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008241409', 'num_games_owned': 922, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1624390061}
review: Самый слабый проект Wadjet Eye, хотя они, справедливости ради, и выступали исключительно в качестве издателя. В игре минимальное количество локаций, мотивы персонажей и вообще [i]чар-дизы[/i] безумно примитивны, а именно Point & Click геймплея тут кот наплакал. Я, конечно, понимаю, что хотели как бы Cанитариум с артом а-ля Гигер, но получили штЫрлиц: танго в пампасах.
developer_response: Сожалеем, что у вас был такой плохой опыт и, что еще хуже, вы не смогли вернуть его. Мы, конечно, предпочитаем, чтобы клиенты уходили с ощущением, что игра им выгодна, или, по крайней мере, не теряя на ней свои деньги.

author: {'steamid': '76561198199507906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1625976591}
review:
If you haven't played Primordia, play that game first. Primordia is the reason why I bought Strangeland. I would not recommend this game to most people, however if you played Primordia and are hungry for more you might give this a try when it goes on sale. It is not a bad game, but overall pretty linear in terms of gameplay (find new item, bring it where you need it, find other new item). IMO it lacks the sense of total immersion that Primordia provided so well. 

6.5/10
developer_response:
Sorry you didn't like Strangeland more, but I appreciate your supporting us and playing both our games!

I actually think Strangeland is quite a bit less linear than most modern adventures (the puzzles, dialogues, etc. generally don't need to be done in any particular order, and many of them have multiple solutions), but ultimately what matters is how it feels to the player, not how the design works on paper. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197968907104', 'num_games_owned': 1057, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1625141983}
review:
A very atmospheric, surreal, psychological horror-adventure game.
Filled to the brim with metaphors, great voice acting and beautifully disturbing art.

I don't want to get into detail about the story to avoid spoilers. Let's just say it is good, allows you to draw your own conclusions without leaving you hanging completely in the air like some stories do.

The only downside I see here is the game's duration.
Three hours really is not a lot - however, the $15 price tag offsets that, IMO. Other short games sometimes ask twice that much and deliver much less.
developer_response:
Thank you so much for the kind assessment! 

I agree that the game is relatively short -- partly, but not entirely, because we've excised a lot of the filler material you sometimes see in adventure games (slow walk speed, long-distance backtracking, long dialogue-only cutscenes), but it is also a little smaller than Primordia was. That said, it has some replayability, both because there a different paths you can take and because the commentary/annotations mode is a pretty different experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067369795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1625630599}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993516952', 'num_games_owned': 902, 'num_reviews': 273, 'playtime_forever': 599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1625465663}
review:
The set-up of Strangeland reminds me of a cross between Silent Hill and Psychonauts. It's astonishingly hopeful, with a resolute protagonist who inches his way forward to a deeper understanding of a difficult truth. I was quite pleased to learn that the game refused to wallow in a morose tone, rather it peppers its macabre imagery and horror in doses, balanced by a sober sense of humor. It makes me wonder how many iterations there were in regard to the overall tone of the game. Was there a version that leaned too heavily on self-punishment and woe? I've yet to place the numerous metaphors the game presents, but I very much look forward to replaying it with the commentary to get a better grasp of some of the more minute details (the 3 men, the mermaid). Upon reflection, I was surprised by how little fat and filler there is. It's a very economical title that makes great use of its maps, the voice acting was very well done and the art is a delight. I was reminded a lot of Twin Peaks: The Return, particularly the black & white segment toward the end with the more frequent macabre imagery. I do wish there was more music as there were particular moments/rooms that had standout pieces. 

Puzzles: I only got stuck with the phone number puzzle. I had thought I had it, but I was underthinking it. I appreciate the in-game hint system, and chuckled when the operator called me an idiot. I smiled when I heard the solution and commend the devs for the solution.

Edit: thoughts after 2nd playthrough with commentary/annotations 

Strangeland is a wonderful little point-and-click adventure title that succeeds through its great writing, art, and world design. I'd say the puzzles were on the easy side, with the game offering sufficient tips through its NPCs, or built in phone-line. Thematically, withing the medium of games, Strangeland is reminiscent of Silent Hill 2, but with a much more literary pedigree. That's not to say it doesn't deliver visually, as the game progresses you will be subject to grotesque images that rival anything in the medium (my particular favorite was the close-up of the Dark thing).

In sum, Strangeland is a compact experience that does a great job of ushering you through its puzzles and maps at a brisk pace.
developer_response:
We iterated a *lot* -- but the tone never changed. The flow, some of the puzzles, the scope, entire dialogues (I rewrote Murmur, the Scribe, and the Well Raven)... but we always had this mix of despair, gallows humor, and flashes of light. With a game this personal, the tone is probably the thing closest to identical with the creators. :D

I'm glad you liked the phone puzzle, and I'm pleased you're going to give the annotations and commentary a whirl. Much love.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053791074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1625106349}

The puzzles were not difficult. The graphics were not high quality which was good because it added to the mysterious quality of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046458067', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1625091577}
review:
This game gave me the best case of nostalgic feelings, particularly my love for "I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream" as well as other creepy games of similar nature. So, if you've played that or any other point & click but like a dark flair, you'd enjoy this. I don't say it as a comparison, but just that they're of similar flavors while maintaining its own identity, which is a hard thing to pull off.

PROS:
- A beautiful game. It's exceptionally designed and perfect for someone who has an appreciation for the strange and the dark. Things get twisted and weird in this game, and it's delightful.
- The voice acting is VERY good, and I rather enjoyed the dialogue as a whole. It can lean into philosophical one moment, then be frank and cruel the other. 
- The puzzles are just like the rest of the game: unusual. Fortunately, if you get stuck anywhere, you can easily find your way in-game. 
- There are alternate endings naturally!
- The music is uncomfortable in just the right way that suits the aesthetic of the entire game.

CONS
- My biggest issue with the game is probably the lack of content for the endings. I understand you're never going to completely satisfy everyone, but I feel like even the majority of the endings for one of their previous games, Primordia, felt like it was fulfilling and needed little additional fluff. Here, I feel like we barely get much in return, about 20 seconds for each "choice". I will argue that most of the endings in Strangeland do work well for the game's general tone, but I would have liked a little more out of the theoretical best ending. However, I recognize that this is just a personal take, and I otherwise loved the experience of the game, which is really the most important part. 

Overall, I do recommend Strangeland! I had a fun time playing this with a friend, and I hope others give it a fair shake.
developer_response:
Thanks for the thoughtful review. Without veering too far into spoiler territory (which I think is risky even behind a spoiler tag in responding to a useful review that I hope other players read!), I tend to view the ending as actually starting during interactive portions of the game (i.e., it's not a cutscene ending, it's an ending sequence).

That said, I remember years ago being extremely annoyed at truncated ending cutscenes in a number of games I had played -- feeling that they were more like a semi-colon or an ellipsis than a period or exclamation point, if that makes sense. I can see that criticism here, though, as you say, I think the endings fit with the general tone of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984565236', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1624942636}
review: Back in 2019 I discovered Wormwood Studios through playing Primordia, their first game released on steam. After playing that, I knew that these devs were serious about their craft, and consider them to be artisans now more than ever in the point and click adventure genre.  Strangeland took everything that Primordia was, and ran with it, creating a dark, poetic, introspective metaphorical world within the protagonist's head. You are immediately dropped off alongside the protagonist as he wakes up in this bizarre nightmare world. The art is crisp and fresh while still being reminiscently familiar, and beautifully dark. Shades of brown, black, and grey are emphasized with perverted yellows and oranges, and fluorescent neon purples giving an ambiance of sickness and putrescence. the color palette with the maddening landscape perspective is packaged into a back alley carnival freak-show with twists and breaks, representing the shattered memories of a broken man. Throughout the game, plot points are revealed in conversation that is fully voice acted - and well done at that. All in all, the moody soundtrack, beautifully horrifying art work, and puzzle / conversation centered game play give a beautifully little packaged story, and a very fun ride that keeps you clicking through the world hoping to discover what new monstrosities lay in wait at the next sideshow tent. I highly recommend you take a look at this game if you enjoy an immersive, interactive storytelling experience. Thank you Wormwood Studios!
developer_response: The contrast between this beautiful review and your user name has put a big dumb grin on my face. In all seriousness, though, thank you so much -- it is really gratifying to read a review like this, which confirms that the game worked as intended for you. I know it won't for everyone, but when we make that connection, it feels like all the pain of development was worth it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198023199040', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 787, 'last_played': 1644053052}
review:
The arrival of Strangeland had for me been a long-anticipated event. As a great fan of Wormwood studios earlier endeavor Primordia, I was just about ready for another point-n-click epic. However, comparisons will not fill up much of this review, as Strangeland remains a story set in an entirely different universe. It is a change almost literally like night and day, where Primordia seemed to be set in a perpetual dusk, where the morning sun almost but never manages to rise over the horizon. The realm of Strangeland, on the other hand, is eternally bathed in the cold gleam of twilight, enchanting this carnival of the macabre with an ominous glow.

The rusty art-nouveau architecture of a steampunk city have been replaced by a nightmarish H.R. Gigeresque carnival, where monsters and poets stand side by side to unravel the tormented mind of a lone traveler. Though the story is not in its entirety simple, it is best summarized in its core content. You play as a nameless wanderer, though sometimes referred to as “the stranger”, who have to navigate a surreal circus of the grotesque, trying to save a nameless woman and fight the dark thing which plagues this world. When playing this game you might come to experience puzzles of the classical adventure game variety and harrowing psychological symbolism.

If you’re a fan of adventure games, Strangeland is certainly an experience that should be savored. From the sprites of tar and flesh to the stanzas of death and despair, it heralds a journey of sober self-reflection, and while I’m not personally a veteran from the LucasArt and Sierra On-Line era, Strangeland bears the mark of a mad savant standing on the shoulders of giants. Wormwood Studio could with their talent begin a new renaissance for adventure games, which only makes me more excited for what their future would bring.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this beautiful, and generous, assessment of our game. Reading things like this makes all the pain of game development worthwhile. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198329475193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1623351758}
review:
Aquí la reseña completa:
https://indiechest.es/resenas/strangeland/

Strangeland es una aventura surrealista y muy peculiar que trata temas tales como la depresión, el duelo, la enfermedad y la pérdida. A través de metáforas, unos gráficos francamente oscuros (bellos pero enervantes) y un gameplay correcto e interesante iremos comprendiendo dónde nos encontramos realmente, quién es la mujer del pozo y qué es "La cosa oscura". El juego en sí merece muchísimo la pena, es una aventura gráfica francamente típica pero con un sabor de boca muy particular, pero tengo que aclarar esto: es un juego que toca temas difíciles, que nos va a poner cara a cara con el dolor y la dureza de la vida, por lo que puede que no sea para todo el mundo. Si estás pasando por algo difícil o duro y este juego empeora esa situación, recuerda que siempre puedes apagarlo y volver a él en otro momento... o nunca, si es que no te llegas a sentir preparad@.
developer_response: Gracias por estas amables palabras, tanto en la reseña corta como en la completa. Abrazos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118709568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1624942771}
review:
Strangeland absolutely nails the dark, oppressive atmosphere and all the little tidbits of high strangeness you'd expect from a game called... well, Strangeland. Everything from backgrounds to set pieces to all the things that go bump in the night all work so well together to build this Lovecraftian type world that I just wanted to explore it all. The art style and surreal atmosphere definitely drew me in immediately. 

The story is pretty good too (no spoilers!) and I loved all the interactions with the other strange denizens that populate the carnival and enrich the plot. I do want to mention that the story is not spoon fed to you. It's often told with symbolism and metaphors which you have to look out for. One thing is for sure, there's a lot to go back and reflect on once you've finished the game. Some things that didn't make sense prior will make more sense after the story's conclusion, but there's still a lot of mystery and things left to be debated and guessed at. I foresee many fan theories in the future about what's really going on at this devilish carnival. 

Puzzles are balanced and some even have multiple solutions. Not too hard, not too easy. There's also an in-game hint feature if you get stuck which I admittedly used once or twice. How to progress made me think and ponder at times, but I never felt stuck for more than 10-15 minutes at a time. I was always able to figure things out eventually by using my brain and that is a sign of great puzzle design. 

Overall, I highly recommended Strangeland to point-and-click adventure game fans as well as people who like dark, surreal games. Two thumbs up from me.
developer_response: So glad you had such a positive experience! Means a lot, especially with the Horatio avatar. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198044508902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1624143879}
review:
Let me preface this by saying that I have been a huge fan of Wadjeteye Games going back to 2012. I adored Primordia and therefore was very excited for this entry. 

With all honesty, Strangeland is a mixed bag. The visuals are incredible. Easily some of the most gorgeous I've seen in a pixel game. The musical score is likewise breathtaking, adding a great sense of foreboding and dread to the already fantastic background art. In that same vein, the voice acting is stellar. As a sucker for Abe Goldfarb going all the way back to the Blackwell Series, it is a treat to the ears to hear him as the main character. Lastly, the overall story is nothing short of excellent (as someone who has had close family members suffer conditions in ways similar to Strangeland's main character's, it struck a uniquely personal tone for me.)

However, where this game comes up short is the gameplay itself. Far too much of the experience in Strangeland feels like a forced narrative, always taking away player freedom in favor of furthering the story. There are no consequences for failure in the game. There are many ways you can die, and every time you do, you simply respawn at the start point with a cheeky message. If you cannot solve a puzzle at first glance, just keep clicking on the phone and it will eventually give you the solution. Challenge is not an issue and this is without a doubt the easiest games from Wadjeteye yet. It's also one of the shortest: compared to Primordia, this entire game could be completed in the time it takes Horatio to reach Metropol. 

Long gone are the in depth cerebral challenges of games like Primordia, Resonance, or Technobabylon. Player choice seems almost completely removed from the experience. In this way, Strangeland succeeds as a narrative, but fails as a game. Gameplay is about player choice and consequence. Here, there simply feels like there is no consequence for your actions. Of course there are slight changes of dialogue if you chose one option over another, and a critic of this review may point out how other games from this publisher have likewise had linear narratives, but this game far more than others seemed to be limited in what it allowes you to do. Your actions do hardly feel like your own. Choice is merely the nouns used in specific dialogue. This makes the world of Strangeland unfortunately shallow. 

Therefore my final thoughts on Strangeland are that it is a beautifully crafted piece of art, reinforced by fantastic sound and acting. But I feel that it lacks meaningful gameplay. It is a quick, one-and-done that I am unlikely to return to in the future. Once completed, I felt no drive to replay the game. Even the accompanying audio commentary--often a favorite extra of mine for these games--did little to engender further interest in the game, as it is mostly a prolonged monologue of obscure literary references used to inspire the game. These references might interest a B.A. in literature, but if you have one of those you probably picked on the references during your first playthrough. 

Final thoughts on Strangeland: 
Pro) This is a great game for digital art lovers and fans of the macabre. 
Con) This is a play novel, not a fully fleshed out adventure game.
developer_response:
Fantastic review.  And a fascinating one because essentially all of the criticisms you have of the game* are exactly aligned with the way I've articulated my own views about game design (e.g., "The Power of Puzzles" dev diary) -- which is to say, the criticisms would point not merely to a weakness in the game, but also a failure of principle. Given that that the review is extraordinary generous in its praise, the criticisms feel particularly credible, and warrant an answer.

The short answer, of course, is "Deepest thanks for the kind words and thoughtful assessment, and sorry for the ways we fell short." But I want to give a long answer in this case because you and I seem so aligned philosophically.

I'd first push back a bit on the choice and consequences point.  I place a high value of C&C (as I wrote in my long review of The Age of Decadence and in the dev diaries about "Fallen Gods," my slow-developing RPG), but it has never been a particular big part of adventure games and is essentially wholly absent from the Lucas Arts catalogue. With adventure games, more important than choice and consequence is maximizing the amount of the game spent actively figuring things out, rather than passive watching or grinding (e.g., through "puzzles" that consist of walking back and forth between distant points on a map). Adventure games that emphasize C&C through dialogues at the expense of the traditional puzzle-based gameplay are, IMO, selling the genre's gameplay short, not improving upon it.

While you describe Strangeland as linear, it is actually not very linear until near the end of the game. We spent quite a lot of time designing the puzzles to permit them to be solved in different ways, and in different order. And we made a point of not reducing (relative to Primordia) the number of puzzles that act as "locked doors," so that early on you can move freely through a relatively larger area than in Primordia, one that is continuous rather than broken into contained segments.

Thus, for instance:
[spoiler]To ascend the park in the first "act," you need to do two things: (1) get to the Valkyrie ride and (2) call the coaster car.  One player might get there by letting the dog kill him, getting the rocks, going back to the dog and picking up the spike, getting the "Beak" work order, making the spike into a knife, cutting open the rat to get the quarters, talking to Murmur, calling the car, getting the meat from the Scribe, using the knife to jimmy open the shooting gallery drawer, drugging the meat, and bypassing the dog.

Another player might go to the scribe, get the meat, and give the meat to the dog to get it to drop the spike. Use the spike to jimmy open the shooting gallery *controls* (it's not sharp enough for the drawer), slow down the shooting gallery by changing the settings, win the game, get the nepenthe, get another piece of meat, drug the dog, meet the Masquettes, and only then start down the route of making the dagger, getting the coins, etc. [/spoiler]

To me, having that kind of openness, parallel puzzles, and multiple solutions matters more than narrative consequences for you choices -- which are fine (we had them in Primordia) but are ultimately tangential to what I consider to be the core gameplay.

That said, if the puzzle difficulty is too low (as it sounds like it was for you -- though I hope at least the prophecy and starfish gave you a little pause!), then the multipath structure basically becomes invisible, since the lack of any apparent obstacles makes it all just feel like a straight path forward, rather than a variety of winding paths through the park.

I think Strangeland is easier than Primordia, but at least some of that increase in easiness flows from making it quite a bit easier to locate items and hotspots -- we generally wanted the player to be able to size up the situation quickly, and then focus on figuring out a resolution.  Still, it's kind of staggering to hear Strangeland described as the easiest WEG title.  Easier than Unavowed?  Oof!

Anyway, all of this is a roundabout way of saying that the criticisms you raise hit me particularly hard; it's one thing to fail to engage a player because you and the player have different philosophies, but it's much worse that you and the player agree, but you just don't execute well enough.  So it goes!

Well, let me just end with the short version again: grateful for your review, for your kind words, and perhaps most of all for the fact that you are fighting the same battle that I want to be fighting, and fighting it better. :)

(* The one criticism that I think is slightly off is the one about the commentary tracks. The *annotations* are very heavy on literary references, but the commentary tracks are a mix of anecdotes about making the game and, from me and Vic, autobiography about life experiences that led to the game's content. Mine have a few discussions of stories that inspired the game, but I would say that's probably less than a fifth of the commentary tracks.)
