author: {'steamid': '76561197993212193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1624526851}
review:
As a huge fan of point-and-click games in general and Wadjeteye games in specific, with Primordia being one of my all-time favorite games, I was definitely looking forward to this game well before its release. With that said, I keep an open mind when it comes to new games from a creative team that’s already produced a beloved game of mine, and Itry not to have preconceived expectations that a new game will have the same feel to it as a past one. Going in with this view helped me to get the most out of Strangeland, a hypnotic, tense, dark story that I thoroughly enjoyed.

Strangeland has a dark, heavy atmosphere that isn’t just from the landscape and surroundings. The visual stylings are often reminiscent of Primordia, with the scenes of bleak, broken-looking areas interspersed with shining, glinting features and glowing lights; it’s absolutely beautiful to look at and many scenes had me stopping for several minutes just to admire the art. But while Primordia’s post-apocalyptic look and situation were paired with a busy world full of energetic characters to meet and interact with, Strangeland is the story of a lonely wandererer. There is no saracastically chipper buddy to brighten the mood on this journey, and while the mood is very apt for what the main character is going through, I occasionally found myself wishing it wasn’t quite such an isolated journey. 

The other characters we meet along the way are both fascinating and horrifying, some so mesmerizing you can hardly look away and some so deformed that you shudder to imagine being in the same room with them. Whether glorious or hideous, I fully enjoyed the interactions with these strange creatures and wished that atleast one of them had a longer-term presence throughout the game.

Strangeland also feels somewhat shorter than its contemporaries in the genre, but this actually fits the game well. I’m the type of player that wants to hear all the descriptions the character will give me, to the extent of clicking on a chair to see what they’ll say about it. Descriptions can give insight into a character and they often really make the environment come alive for me. Here, there were very few extraneous things to click on, and descriptions were limited to things that were relevant to the plot. 

That wasn’t as much of a downside for me with Strangeland, though, because the main character is already very fleshed out through essential dialogue, and the story has such a well-crafted urgency to it. There is an ongoing tension that is kept up throughout the entire game, and it’s one of the most impressive things about Strangeland that it manages to do this and do it well. The playtime ended up feeling just right for me, and while I did still have the craving to explore the world further, I felt the story concluded at the ideal time.

Overall, I would recommend Strangeland both for its stunning visuals and for its story. It is a dark and cerebral experience, but for anyone who is open to a game with those elements, this is likely to be an intriguing and enjoyable one.
developer_response: This is a really wonderful review to wake up to -- obviously it's always nice to hear kind words about our game, and to hear them so well expressed is all the more so. I'm really glad that Strangeland clicked for you this way. Much love.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963707743', 'num_games_owned': 797, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1624390435}
review:
8/10

Another wonderful game by Wormwood. I thoroughly enjoyed Primordia when I first played it some years ago and was pleasantly surprised when I discovered that Strangeland was released last month! Just like Primordia, I enjoyed this game very much. 

While the game is overall shorter, there are multiple endings (which I still have to discover as I've only done a first playthrough and I intend to play through them all). The puzzles weren't too confusing but not extremely straightforward either so I enjoyed my time solving them.

The story itself was a bit confusing as I was experiencing it and I was left wondering "What did I just see?" when the credits rolled. After digging through some Steam discussion posts, the story clicked and I could see the pieces falling into place to put the full picture together. One of the few cons I had with the story/the game itself was it felt a little harder to connect with the characters in a meaningful way; It was a little rough to continue the motivations of the Stranger when I didn't connect with him as much as I did with Horatio in Primordia.

I also didn't understand what the big white bar was at the top of the inventory screen. I have some ideas but for the most part I ignored it while playing.

Overall, I loved this game and cant wait to dive into it again to learn more. Wormwood makes really inspiring games and actually had me wanting to make something similar to their games in the future. Keep bringing these games out guys! I really enjoy them.
developer_response: Thank you so much -- for the kind words, for playing both our adventures, and for encouraging us to make more. I hope we can continue to delight you, albeit at our rather tortoise-like pace. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198869901912', 'num_games_owned': 127, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1624515308}
review:
This game was fantastic. the atmosphere and imagery were intoxicating, and the story thoroughly engaged me right from the get-go. all the metaphors and allegorical elements were tons of fun to unravel and make sense of as the story progressed and i became privy to more information. The ending was amazing and had me in tears. this game deals with a lot of heavy themes and they were handled very tastefully. the positive message this game instills in the player by the end is fantastic. 
this game really left an impact on me and i will eagerly await and play whatever this team puts out next.
developer_response: Ah, music to my ears! It's wonderful that the allegories and metaphors worked so well for you (they don't for everyone, obviously), but above all, this line lit up my day: "The positive message this game instills in the player by the end is fantastic." It's a dark journey but I hoped it to be a game that brings light, rather than darkness, in the end. It's very good to hear that it did for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026510154', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1624486539}
review:
Overall easy enough game for folks like me who aren't usually point and click players. Dialogue is hammy to put it mildly but it clicks fairly quickly what the writer was trying to put across and it's simple to tune out the more flowery language.

Visuals are interesting but honestly I thought Primordia was more striking in that regard with the mechanical themes benefiting from the retro graphics in a way this more organic based art direction doesn't.

I also thought Horatio was much better characterised than The Stranger, which considering both games are about amnesiacs whose lost memories are pretty much core to the plot.... yeah. 

In short, artsy take on a dark subject, nothing new or groundbreaking but it keeps it short and too the point rather than wallowing in its own 'cleverness' like other attempts have done so it gets a pass. It's also not outright horrific to play like other such games (I'm looking at you Cat Lady).
developer_response: Well, I'm glad that on balance you liked it, even if not as much as Primordia! Thanks for playing both our games, and giving us such support. It's really appreciated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058197214', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1624304451}
review:
Tired schizophrenia-based story which makes the intended creepiness boring. Way too much fluff and metaphors in the dialogue. No character development or substance to the main character. Mostly uninteresting puzzles, except for one which was funny and clever.

The hint mechanics were nice.
developer_response: Sorry you didn't enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970956898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1624204177}
review:
I just didn't get this game. It isn't bad just not for everyone.

Graphics are not good, it is hard to spot crucial elements. The style You like it or not - You can see most interesting screenshots in game store preview.

Game is short(up to 4hrs top) there are only several interesting and nice levels and several more not interesting corridors/filler backgrounds.

I don't even remember the music.

Atmosphere is even more dark than You see on the screenshots, story is confusing, very metaphory, psychological. In the beginning i was sure it was some kind of purgatory, but then it seems more like fight withing his own head and coping with loss. Just couldn't resonate with it.


For the finish: puzzles. As in a game that is played inside Your head - there are some stretches. There are only few kinds of interesting puzzles, but most of the time You just push forward with obvious choices (use knife to cut sth, etc),  or because inventory and map is so limited You use everything on everything. There are few puzzles that felt totally out of place and illogical even for this world.
So i can't recommend buying this game just for puzzles.


PS.
In terms of user friendly UI it is a big step forward comparing to previous title. With mouse wheel You change items, You don't actualy need to walk whoel screen to move to another level etc.
developer_response: Very sorry you had such a bad experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561198064392148', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 231, 'playtime_forever': 768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 768, 'last_played': 1623000410}
review:
[i]"A man walks in a world of ghosts, and he wonders. Am I a dead man dreaming he's alive? Or a live man dreaming he's dead?"[/i]


Strangeland was quite a beautiful and emotional game to play. Fully-voiced, it tells a dark story about grief and the process of coping with the death of a loved one.

The player, named the "Stranger" in the game, enters a nightmarish carnival where no one can really die. With no memories of who he is or his past, he then witnesses a woman who keeps jumping to her death and feels determined to find and save her.

While exploring this strange land and meeting its very peculiar inhabitants, we learn more about ourself and will try to find answers about the reason we are here.

Visually and plotwise, the game is extremely rich. The writing is excellent and at times very poetic. Full of symbols, metaphors and cultural references, it might take several playthroughs to understand everything. I also recommend playing with commentaries on at least once to get more info about some  details that we might not have noticed on our own. It also tells some very personal stories that inspired the game.

Some players might wonder how similar this game is to the devs previous game. Strangeland is a very different game than Primordia. Different story, different universe, different everything. But as its predecessor, it is another gem that will touch us by its very moving tale. And now I am just curious to discover what the next work of the devs will be about...
developer_response: Thank you so much for this kind and beautiful review. I'm glad our games have connected with you like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000437490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1624387995}

developer_response: Glad you gave it a look, even if it turned out not to be your thing. I hope we can deliver something more to your liking next time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062094247', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1622894218}
review:
*Το Strangeland είναι ένα εξαιρετικό horror adventure το οποίο ξαφνιάζει και προκαλεί παραμένοντας πιστό στην ποιότητα των προηγούμενων τίτλων της εταιρείας. Σίγουρα δεν απευθύνεται σε όλους αυτός ο σουρεαλισμός αλλά αν είστε θιασώτες του συγκεκριμένου θέματος θα ενθουσιαστείτε! Αντλεί τη θεματολογία του από κλασικά μοτίβα της pop culture και πιο συγκεκριμένα του horror, επικρατεί μια μόνιμα αρνητική διάθεση με αποκορύφωμα το τέλος του ταξιδιού να αφήνει ερωτηματικά και ανοιχτότητα προς κάθε ερμηνεία. Μην το χάσετε με τίποτα!*

Μπορείτε να διαβάσετε ολόκληρο το review στο site: https://justgamer.gr/strangeland-the-review/
developer_response: Ευχαριστώ πολύ, τόσο για τη σύνοψή σας εδώ όσο και για τη μακρύτερη κριτική. Εκτιμούμε βαθιά την υποστήριξη και γνωρίζω ότι ο Τζέιμς είναι ιδιαίτερα ικανοποιημένος που διάβασε τόσο όμορφες σκέψεις στη μητρική του γλώσσα.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016808486', 'num_games_owned': 481, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1624047251}
review:
This was one of the best game experiences I've had, with Primordia being the bar, this game sets one right up next to it. For me, it sets it a bit above in the theme and message the writer wants to convey here. The atmosphere of Primordia and this game are different and incomparable, so they are both amazing. This game felt very very personal to me, and I felt certain elements in the game held special meaning to me with some symbols and the way the story goes. I also like the choice of the writer to include the characters in hospital garments, felt like an allusion to the entire mental health care system in America and how it feels like the carnival. The recurring jokes with the clown reminds me of doctors and how they actually talk sometimes. You guys could really do well if you wrote for Futurama, the game has so much meaning in the real world and also makes emotional feeling for the characters. 

One day I hope to be this talented as a writer, and maybe produce something on this level with meaningful messages and especially the social commentary. You guys also did an excellent job with the monomyth aspects and character/situational archetypes. It was so well done, as if I was reading Homer but in the modern iteration. You guys raised so many questions and used the best quotes from mythology and writing with the Fimbul Fambi character and then with Gershom.

The game did feel short, and I would love more, but there was so much included in the small details and the dialogue that I didn't mind the short game. Really felt like the level of writing in Futurama. It wasn't as challenging as Primordia either, but I did not mind becuase the game held personal meaning to me. I absolutely loved it, I can't wait for the next installment in the Wormwood saga. No pressure XD I hope it is something to do in space like human lust for exploration goes too far (I just came up with a cool idea I wanna share with Wormwood), or maybe something like District 9, or a Mayan temple? Egyptian mythology? Whatever they have planned I'm sure it will be genius, maybe we'll get some info in the next year or so <3 I love Wormwood
developer_response:
What a beautiful review.

I want to respond to one thing in particular: your mention about wanting to write something like it yourself. T.H. White has Merlin say, "Every word written is a blow against the devil." (This is apparently taken from a statement found by Jean Victor Duruy in the writings of a medieval abbot who supervised copyist monks in a scriptorium.) Not speaking theologically, but humanistically, I agree with the sentiment:  when you write (and I mean you specifically as well as others), you are adding something to the world. You never know whose life will be changed by it. For instance, your review moved me and brought a joyous end to a tough day.

In short: keep writing, and keep bringing that light into the world.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972295591', 'num_games_owned': 1746, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1624038909}
review:
This game oof, it hit hards, harder at the end and anyone who has suffered trauma will probably take a hit in this game, I know I did. It is respectfully written in that regard, and definitely with understanding to the self-image and self-hatred that comes with PTSD, the darkness and the light in constant turmoil.

Not to say that it is what the game is about, it is just where it hit me and I know I have a habit of linking stuff to my own experiences as we all do, but I enjoyed this adventure, a little short for the price of entry but I'm leaning towards overlooking that due to the full voice-acting, great artwork and personal messages in the story.

Great game, hope to see many more!
developer_response: Much love. I hope you were able to hear the game's message that even when the light and dark are in turmoil, that doesn't mean there isn't light -- your light shining for others, and others' shining for you. In my own darkest times, it's hard for me to hear or believe that, but I do think it's true, especially in those darkest times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014182958', 'num_games_owned': 724, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1623768882}
review: Primordia is probably my favourite point'n'click adventure, so I was very excited about Strangeland and I can confidently say it did not disappoint. The game is a little shorter and smaller scale, but it is a different story that needs to be told in a different way, so I don't see it as a problem. The themes of the story were realised well and the puzzles were good, they were clever enough to require actual thinking, but never bad enough to need an external walkthrough. Overall another great adventure game from Wormood Studios.
developer_response: Thanks, Malkata -- so glad that you enjoyed both games *for* the differences rather than despite them. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198005376219', 'num_games_owned': 795, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1623992908}
review:
I enjoyed Strangeland, but I'm not sure if it's something I would easily recommend.  The story heavily uses metaphysical and psychological elements, similar to The Charnel House Trilogy or Silent Hill. But it doesn't break new ground in terms of story - don't expect major plot twists.

Graphics wise - it's alright. The backgrounds and setting seem to be inspired by HR Giger and/or Dark Seed. Though the colors are all pretty brown/gray/black and 640x360 seems like a pretty stingy resolution in 2021, even for a point-and-click adventure game.

The game isn't long or hard - my first blind playthrough took around 3.5 hours. The puzzles make sense for the most part. It's a lot easier than Primordia - there's plenty of hints and a built-in helpling (dial 0). I never got stuck at any section for more than a few minutes.

Overall I would give the game a 6.5/10. I had fun with it for the most part, but I wouldn't say it's a must play (or even a must watch on Twitch/YouTube).
developer_response: Thanks for giving it a look, and for leaving a review -- always appreciate the feedback.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981255520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1623530923}
review:
Really thought I would like this game and so I bought it the second I saw it pop up. I love the art and the atmosphere of the game, but that's where it stops. The game piously tells you that you can deduce everything by just thinking deeply where you're standing while simultaneously implementing "puzzles" that allow for plenty ambiguity and mocks you while doing so. It's really weird because all the nooks of the game ooze of quality (voice-over etc), but it does not seem sufficiently stitched together.

Edit: I don't think this deserves 'not recommended'; I simply mean to say that the game was not as compatible with me as I expected and I think many would enjoy this game. (I was there, 3000 years ago, with  king's quest and DoTT, Torin's passage). In editing this I realize Steam does not provide an option for a  neutral score. This binary does not represent my opinion of this game. If you read this far then the gradation of the post is irrelevant.
developer_response:
Sorry you had such a bad experience with the game!

The intended message of the How to Play section was not that the player would always be able to solve puzzles by thinking deeply about them, but to encourage players to try to reason through puzzles as a first resort rather than taking a "try every possible combination" approach, which in our experience isn't a very fun way to play adventures. The game provides a built-in hint system for when players get stuck; the fact that the voice on the other end is caustic isn't meant to be the *game* mocking you, but rather the antagonist doing so. 

But developer intention is entirely secondary to player experience, and the fact is that you didn't enjoy the game. No excuses or explanations for that; it's just the game coming up short for you, for which I sincerely apologize.

author: {'steamid': '76561198846117864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1622140869}
review:
I enjoyed Primordia and I was looking forward to playing another game by the same development team.  I eagerly snapped it up for a slight discount as soon as it was released.  Overall I did enjoy playing it but felt strangely unsatisfied by the end.

PROS:
-  It looks gorgeous.  The design of Strangeland mixes a creepy, surreal carnival with elements from Norse mythology and uses a careful palette of yellows and purples to create an uneasy atmosphere.  The pixel-art animations are also top-notch.
-  The music / sound design compliments the atmosphere and the voice acting is also high-quality, featuring a few Wadjet Eye regulars.
-  The controls are slick and intuitive, and even the aesthetics of the UI add to the game's atmosphere
-  The vast majority of puzzles are well-implemented and feel like they make sense within the game's surreal setting without being too 'moon logic' for the player to work out.  And if you really get stuck then there's an in-built hint system.

CONS:
-  The main letdown is the writing.  As other reviewers have noted, Strangeland is built around a central, intriguing conceit which becomes apparent at the beginning of the game.  I kept hoping for the story to expand, to flesh out the characters or to give more detailed meaning to its metaphors, but it never did.  It ends up telling a rather generalised story about grief and guilt which never quite moved me because the characters still felt like ciphers rather than real people.  It might have been the designers' intentions to keep things vague / metaphorical so that the player can project their own experiences, but the very nature of the game's setting doesn't mesh well with that approach.
-  One or two frustrating puzzles (one in particular which I wouldn't have guessed without the in-built hint system; even when I retroactively realised the clues they'd laid out for me, I still felt a little cheated)

Overall I'd still recommend the game because this dev team continue to put an immense amount of effort into their work and to try interesting new stories with the point 'n' click adventure format, so for all its flaws Strangeland is still a rich and enjoyable experience and comes from a team well worth supporting.
developer_response: Sorry you were disappointed! We very much appreciate your support, especially given that disappointment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027953022', 'num_games_owned': 431, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1622257563}

author: {'steamid': '76561198010167939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1623878278}
review:
Having just finished playing, and loving, this team's first game, "Primordia", I was eager to pick this up. Does this game live up to Primordia? 

Story: Absolutely Not. The story is as transparent as glass. You know exactly where you are and what the ending is going to be at about minute 2, making a lot of this game feel a bit like a slog. You keep hoping they're going to throw in a twist or expand upon this already done to death idea, but, nope. 

Puzzles: Puzzles were about on par with their first game. A couple of more difficult ones that you need to pay close attention to get, and a lot of fun not to hard, not to easy, ones to fill out the game. 

Art: Although I didn't enjoy the setting as much this time around, the art was well done and interesting to look at. 

Length: I finished this in about half the time I spent in Primordia, yet paid an extra 5 bucks to play it. 

Overall, it's a fine point and click adventure with decent puzzles. I would recommend playing this one first, then going and playing the superior Primordia. Otherwise, this one feels pretty bleh by comparison.
developer_response: Thanks for the review -- sorry it didn't live up to Primordia for you, but glad you enjoyed it all the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034661081', 'num_games_owned': 443, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1623447413}
review:
Um adventure bem diferente do que costumamos ver, que deve agradar fãs de jogos como Sanitarium ou dos adventures da Harvester Games.

Duração perfeita para a história que está sendo contada (3~4 horas), dificuldade bem balanceada nos puzzles - com um sistema de dicas integrado no jogo e uma arte maravilhosa.

Confesso que gostaria de ver essa arte em uma resolução maior, mas é mais questão de gosto que uma crítica

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YDU-FVBS6gI&t=12s
developer_response: Muito obrigado pelas amáveis palavras. Este foi um grande salto de resolução do Primordia; talvez um dia possamos fazer um com resolução muito alta, mas torna o trabalho do sprite extremamente difícil. (Os planos de fundo provavelmente são um pouco mais fáceis em resoluções mais altas.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198009575730', 'num_games_owned': 2402, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1624035774}
review:
Considering how strange our world is nowadays, it's a real relief to play this amazing game.

This game is a Lynchian adventure, and at first it's pretty confusing what's happening to your protagonist.

Little by little you start exploring this strange world and understand its rules and how it works.

Surprisingly enough there's basically no moon logic and the puzzles make sense.

This is one of my most favorite point and click adventures in a long time.

Thanks to the developers for a fantastic piece of art.

Embrace the strangeness!
developer_response: Love this review. Thank you so much for it, and for playing our game. :) Embrace the strangeness, indeed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099124067', 'num_games_owned': 595, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1624641940}
review:
It's a very well-made point n click adventure.
The story has some interesting plot twists and the puzzles are very friendly while not being no-brainers.
Also great voice actings.
For me it's quite enjoyable as a change of pace, maybe even therapeutic.

Although there were likely a lot of metaphors and symbolisms that I missed or couldn't recognize.
Hopefully a second play through with annotations and commentaries will fulfill my curiosity.

P.S.: Is it possible to keep the game "talking" when the window is not on focus?
This might come in handy in a second play through with long commentaries I guess.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words. I don't believe it's possible for audio to play while it's not focused -- I mean, it could be coded that way, but we went with the opposite approach since ordinarily when someone tabs out, they want the game to freeze. Sorry!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053451908', 'num_games_owned': 1146, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1623703956}
review:
Highly recommend this and all other games by Wadjet and Wormwood - always high quality, well written and directed point and click games. This one probably the most trippy and surreal story of all - i'm still processing it - but it flows so nicely, doesn't overstay its welcome, and help is literally a quick phone call away ;)

Can't wait for the next one!
developer_response: Thank you so much! We're grateful for your kind words, and glad that the game worked so well for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049229073', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1674864145}
review: Strangeland is another excellent point and click adventure from Wadjeteye's already impressive catalog and a worthy successor to Wormwood Studio's previous game Primordia.  The story clearly comes from a deeply personal place and deals with heavy themes like grief and loss of self, but it maintains a dark sense of humor throughout it's 4-5 hour run time.  The artwork and voice acting are superb with a standout performance by Wadjeteye veteran Abe Goldfarb as the protagonist.  A gruesome little puzzle box populated by bizarre and hostile characters, Strangeland is definitely worth your time.  Highly recommended.
developer_response: "A gruesome little puzzle box populated by bizarre and hostile characters..."  Love it. :) Your review was very kind, thanks for leaving it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989807190', 'num_games_owned': 2273, 'num_reviews': 596, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1623690908}
review:
When I’ve played Primordia a few years ago, quite late for the game originally from 2012, I liked it quite a lot, yet it remained a title that I was hesitant to outright recommend. Check out, pay attention to, maybe get it if you’re in the mood, sure. But not drop everything and get it. With Strangeland I was hoping to have a more definite “heck yeah, get it” recommendation. Yet, while I did have a more enjoyable experience with the title overall, and did really like it, I still didn’t like it quite enough.

Strangeland is a 2D point and click adventure game made on Adventure Game Studio, just like with all the titles Wadjet Eye Games tends to publish and just like the previous Wormwood Studios’ game Primordia. Also just like Primordia, this title is incredibly gorgeous – the visuals and how they animate and transition is unlike anything I’ve seen with these AGS games. The voice acting is terrific, music is great – less outside the game, but phenomenal inside the game, – and the gameplay is stripped down to the most fun basics, with some really nice quality of life features and ideas.

It’s not without flaws, one of the very early puzzles was absolutely horrible in concept and execution and I bet if the game ever gets localized, the localization teams will woe the day they decided to take this task. Yet it was also probably the only spot in the game that felt rough, the rest of the game following surreal, yet understandable logic. A few moments here and there felt a bit “eh, this actually makes sense as a solution, but it doesn’t work”. And there were a few moments where you could fail (there’s no Game Over in this game) and get punished by waiting through animations and walking until you can try again. But otherwise, the experience of playing Strangeland was really tight and considerably better paced than Primordia.

Where the game will or won’t click with you, though, is with its story, the themes and how those are handled. Without going into spoilers, this game has the main character go through dark psychological issues and a lot of imagery, text and scenes borders on feeling E D G Y just for the sake of it. It’s always a problem with any type of storytelling dealing with depression or related issues, be it a song, a story, a game or whatever else, where unless it clicks with you on a more than “I get what it’s about” level, you can almost get giggly about how silly it seems. Now, Strangeland in particular, in my opinion, balanced on that line really well, unlike something far more “edgy” like The Cat Lady, or something disgustingly style and drama over substance like Distraint. This game feels sincere in what it’s going for (not that the other titles mentioned weren’t, but they don’t come across as sincere in comparison). But despite that, you might not really care about what it’s going for, for the characters, for the allegories, for the story. Which isn’t helped by the fact, that there isn’t really that much of a journey through the darkness happening, rather a “weird stroll through a, well, Strange Land”.

So, I would definitely suggest being aware of Strangeland and consider getting it when you’re in the mood to play this kind of title. Because if you’re not in the mood, it might completely ruin your experience. I liked it. Not as much as I hoped I would. Not without thinking about Planescape: Torment a bit more often than I’ve expected. But still, liked it. And definitely interested in seeing what Wormwood Studios will do next.
developer_response: Thanks for the thoughtful reaction, and the thorough review -- and for playing both our games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198301417354', 'num_games_owned': 866, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 883, 'last_played': 1622828146}
review:
A point & click adventure into a surreal world - an amazing experience.   

As if waking from a dream, you are in another kind of reality, this absurd carnival, where you see a woman jumping into a well ... you want to stop that, but cannot and have to relive it over and over.  Soon you realize, you cannot win against all the odds in your way. But, you will not give up. Finding allies or just figures, who speak in riddles, you will persist in your struggle to save that woman. And piece by piece the player gets an idea, that this fight is more than just a fictional story. 

I was very touched by it, as I could relate 
Loved every minute in the game !
developer_response: What a beautiful review. Thank you so much, Sylvia!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002843186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1623520558}
review: gud gaem, but too short
developer_response: Glad you liked it! There's some replayability from alternative paths through puzzles/dialogues/ending and through the commentary, but you're right, it's fairly short even as modern adventures go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013697341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1622060935}
review:
God bless Wormwood Studios and Wadjet Eye. (I mostly played the game offline, therefore the short playtime)
Very good writing, the ambiguous characters at times appearing to be archetypes, horror genre tropes, manifestations of inner turmoil, otherworldly forces, surreal figments of fantasy etc. Everything is left to interpretation in a story, that makes sense enclosed in its weird logic. Very unique and probably only comparable to Bad Seed, Fran Bow and some parts of Memoria.
As an adventure game enthusiast, I would have wished it to be longer than a day at the carnival. Also, sadly, the second area of the game is smaller than the first, with less characters and objects to interact with, thus making it easier.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed it so much! We'll go for something longer for our next adventure, but with this story/set-up, we thought this was the right amount. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197997602081', 'num_games_owned': 589, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1623505693}
review:
Ru/En

Новая, долгожданная игра от студии, подарившей нам Primordia. В отличие от неё, Strangeland несколько короче, но всё ещё демонстрирует высокий уровень внимания к деталям и любви разработчиков к своему творению. Не стоит, однако, ожидать тех же эмоций и впечатлений – в этот раз нам представлена трагедия лишь одного человека в чужом краю, не целого футуристического общества на пороге гибели. Весёлого спутника тоже не завезли. Тем не менее, это приятная адвенчура с полностью озвученными (очень качественно, должен сказать) диалогами, вариативностью в решении загадок и классическим артстайлом студии. Моей единственной жалобой будет именно продолжительность игры – понимаемо, что большая часть ресурсов пошла на создание высококачественного продукта, но лично меня не покидает ощущение, что игре можно было бы добавить ещё один-два слоя. Ставлю игре семь с половиной примордий из десяти.

A brand new, long-awaited game from the studio that gifted us Primordia. Unlike it, Strangeland is somewhat shorter, but still displays a high level of attention to details and developer’s love for their creation. However, this time we are presented with the tragedy of only one man in a strange land, not a whole futuristic society on the verge of destruction, so don’t expect same experience and emotions. No quirky loveable sidekick this time, too. Nevertheless, this is a pleasant point’n’click adventure game with fully voiced dialogues (and VA’s did a great job, i must say), several ways of solving puzzles and the classic Wormwood studios art style. My only complaint is with the length of the game – i understand that the majority of the resources went to creating a high-quality product, but personally I have a feeling that the game could’ve used one or two additional layers. Overall i rate Strangeland seven and a half primordias out of ten.
developer_response: Great review. Made me smile, then laugh. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198007098487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1623483464}
review:
Dark, stylish point’n’click with heavy themes explored through surrealistic horror.

You’re awaken in a straitjacket in what seems to be abandoned, neon-lit carnival in hell. It’s a great start already, but let’s not stop there – you also realize that you have no idea who are you, why are you there, and who is this mysterious woman that keeps jumping in the well as you helplessly watch her for the umpteenth time. Increasingly bleak atmosphere and the universe full of bizarre creatures and odd, chill-inducing rides makes you think that straitjacket just might be a smaller part of your problems…

The narration of “Strangeland” is as surrealistic as the overall plot. It’s expressed through cryptic writing full of aphorisms, riddle-like statements, allegories, metaphors upon metaphors, and while it’s almost poetic, it also can be quite dense at times. There are references to religious writings, Norse mythology, historical places and many literary works abound to make you ponder and overwhelm a bit.  All the dialogues, including internal, appropriately support dream-like plot and are intelligent and thought-provoking but might not quite be as easily digestible, layered on top of the already odd story. The core of which, by the way, will always be partially dipped in confusion. You’re going… somewhere, saving (or are you?) … someone and talking to … some creatures to move on to another bizarre level of the Strangeland. There’s a thread that makes you keep going forward (and things somewhat coherent), though, so you never entirely lost in the grand scheme of things, but still, be prepared to float in a weird dimension where some things are so strange that there’s no point of trying to make sense of them, but rather marvel at them and experience everything as a part of the dark journey which will be extremely personal, yet open to many interpretations.

Puzzle element is nicely balanced, although a seasoned adventurer might yearn for a bit more challenge from developers of “Primordia”. There are classic inventory and environment manipulations, a few logic-based ones, and some fun (although out of place in some instances) puzzles based on wordplay. All of them combined provide for a smooth uninterrupted flow of the gameplay – not too difficult to stump for long, not too easy to just breeze through already rather short adventure, but just right. A few tasks will be of the same disturbing nature as the surrounding universe, so be prepared to do quite grotesque and unsettling things to move forward.

Grotesque and unsettling are the words that could describe pretty much 90% of “Strangeland”, starting from plot down to actions of the Stranger and visuals. And these visuals are fantastic and dark and horrifying and beautiful, pushing AGS to its very limits and, quite probably, taking it beyond. Despite the game's largely muted colors fitting to a gloomy atmosphere full of despair, bright purples and yellows in neon-lit lights bring an interesting element to awe-inspiring pixel art, and even intense macabre creations have an underlying beauty to them.  Smooth animations and overall dream-like liquidity of the picture make it a homerun for Wormwood Studios in a graphics department.

There’s  quite splendid, high-quality voice-over work present, and every actor did great job with their part. The nature of dialogues (dream-like, highly allegorical base that underlines them), however, might make certain statements from a main hero seem a bit too dramatically mechanical (or maybe mechanically dramatical) as the Stranger traverses this bizarre land, full of peculiar beings, but it is easily offset by phenomenal voice-work behind the character of clown head and all the supporting cast. Soundscape in “Strangeland” is quite minimal, but whatever is there works wonderfully. Slow, ominous electro-synthesized tracks and sounds underline heavy atmosphere yet keep it stylish, just like the lit-up signs strewn around this dark carnival do. It’s a moody, disquieting musical component that can equally disturb or plunge you into a melancholy. More of it would seem like an obvious request, but the nature of the game might actually be complete precisely with this minimal level of the top-notch sound.

“Strangeland” is beautiful, well-made by a talented team point’n’click that nonetheless won’t be for everyone.  Disturbing atmosphere calls for many actions that would be fitting only to that nightmarish world, and the overall darkness of the themes explored (nothing is explicitly stated unless you’ll be playing with commentary and annotations) could be too heavy for some. There’s intelligent writing chock-full of metaphors and allegories that might either prompt research and deep discussions or seem quite burdensome to get through, depending on your preference and even mood. “Strangeland” is a gorgeous work of oppressive art, polished and wholesome, but in this case, such is the world of the game that recommendations are largely secondary to the way you feel reading about it or looking at the screenshots. If you do decide to take up this surrealistic, chilling journey alongside the Stranger – remember, you also have his fate in your hands, and it’s a responsibility even he himself shunned for a long time, so proceed at your own risk.
developer_response: This is a really beautiful review. Thank you, from the bottom of my heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059613438', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1622597636}
review:
After Primordia introduced me to the amazing world of Wormwood Studios and PnC games in general, I couldn't resist Strangeland. It's a beautifully bizarre, phenomenal game that I found myself unable to pull away from. The writing is fantastic and the world is creepy, enthralling, and unique. It takes itself seriously just the right amount of the time. The puzzles are really fun to solve. 

I have a few nitpicks here and there (the cliches of "save the troubled girlfriend" and "amnesia/stranger in a strange land" are a bit tired, even if this game does some interesting things with both themes), but I would still wholeheartedly recommend it.
developer_response: Not much more I could ask for in a review than such high praise *and* being told that Primordia introduced you to point-and-clicks. It's a wonderful genre, and lucky to have a fan like you playing in it. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198038094797', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1623383330}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999413011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1623428655}
review:
A blind man sits beneath a tree, writing. Nearby, a raven (a raven, not a crow!) is perched on a branch. It is said of Odin, he who sacrificed an eye in pursuit of knowledge, that he hang himself on the great tree Yggdrasil - sacrificing "himself to himself" - which ordeal granted him the knowledge of runes. Of Writing.
This man, he says how he "writes to forget". In Plato's dialogue "Phaedrus" there is briefly recounted Egyptian legend in which the god Toth presents the gift of writing to king Thamus. Writing is supposed to enhance men's memory by allowing them to record it. Thamus, however, recognizes the ambiguity of the gift: men's memory and wisdom will decrease for they shall rely on this external crutch, this Supplement, rather than having to remember by themselves. Here we've got the logic of the supplement. Banal example: consider how in Dark Souls you can grind and seek superior equipment rather than, and forgive me for this, "gitting gud". The supplement that both extends and weakens, makes dependant on. Ambiguous, like the Greek word "pharmakon", a cure and a poison. (Related word: pharmakos. Scapegoat, exile, impure, excised.) 
And the raven? Do we not see them as the feeders on the dead, on the energy of others. They who disperse others. 
To write to forget. To lose oneself in the endless surface-play of signs. Signs, by themselves, leading only to signs. Signified becoming signifier, depth becoming surface. Text pointing to another text. Could one not hide in this endless play, drown therein? (Can one not quote and regurgitate the words of others rather than think oneself?) But what if the story is really very simple, if the Real is so very simple. But one would rather disperse, for the real is painful. Yet, as one more than usually devilish Frenchman said, the real is like the chewing gum that attaches itself to one's shoe. Not too easy to rid oneself of it. 

The story of this game really is simple. This was a distraction. But it really is about distractions too. 

Anyway, the relevant stuff: this is an excellent adventure game, with superb artwork and music. You really should play it. It also contains giant, loquacious cicadas discoursing on Lacan.
developer_response: Helluva review. Love the Egyptian myth, which I was unaware of.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970563925', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 273, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1623421329}

author: {'steamid': '76561198089919127', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1623335451}

author: {'steamid': '76561197966079388', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1676502531}
review:
I played Strangeland in a single sitting on launch day. I'm not sure I can give a much better recommendation than that.

Strangeland is a dark, creepy and interesting place to explore and offered no significant barriers (lots of polish, puzzles aren't too hard, nothing unfair), so it was easy to just keep playing until it was over. Toward the end I was into the game hook, line and sinker.

The story and setting is interesting, the voice acting is great and the puzzles are light to medium in difficulty and there's a built in hint system. I used the hint system 3 times or so (and wish I'd held off longer and not cheated myself).

I finished the game in about 4.5 hours but if I'd had more discipline and held off on the in game hints it would have been at least a couple longer.

If you like point & click adventures at all then Strangeland is a no-brainer and it's worth your time and your money.
developer_response: Thanks, George. I owe you for a lot of very happy gaming memories, without which I doubt Strangeland would ever have come into existence. It's quite something to read your kind words about this little adventure. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198072182182', 'num_games_owned': 2862, 'num_reviews': 352, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1623295170}
review: I can certainly recommend the game on the basis of its wonderful art, great puzzles, and fine voice acting, but I'd be lying if I said the heavy-handed metaphor didn't sour the whole experience for me a little.  Yes, I know -- it's glaringly obvious in the first [i]minute[/i] what kind of world this is, but I kept hoping against hope they'd do something novel with the narrative.  They did not.
developer_response: Well, I'm glad it only soured you a little, and you were still able to enjoy it. Sorry we let you down.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970339916', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1623202329}

developer_response: Thank you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035919382', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1622502646}
review:
Great experience, the art is amazing. You can have different endings depending on what you choose to do. The only thing I can complain about is that it is a short game. I wouldn't mind getting more places to go and more characters to meet.
I'm looking forward to see the next game by Wormwood Studios <3
developer_response: Thank you so much! It takes us a long time to develop games, but we've got a few irons in the fire. I'm not sure if you've played Primordia yet, but if you haven't, you might enjoy it given your positive reaction to Strangeland.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058990037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1667437969}
review:
This game is awesome. As a previous Primordia player, I can now say with certainty that Wormwood studios are on the right track, and their games are thought provoking, engaging and fantastic.

Being highly atmospheric and featuring beautiful art, this game is well worth the price. It tells a unique story with a main protagonist who is visiting the mysterious Strangeland. The puzzles aren't arbitrary, and are perfectly woven into the story-line it tries to tell. I am not too big into point-and-click, or puzzle aspects of the games, but dying to know more about the what's happening kept me going, which I guess how this genre is supposed to feel.

You can tell that the game is written by someone who is well educated and knows the human condition well, as the philosophy of it doesn't feel rushed, oversimplified or pretentious. This is one of those games, where I play it, finish playing, and then think about what just happened for an hour. I wish there were more games by this studio.

I highly recommend finishing the game, and then replaying it with the commentary on, so you understand all the references. The games dark topics might not be for everyone, but I strongly recommend that you give it a try, as it has multiple endings. 10/10!
developer_response: Thank you for this generous and beautiful review. I'm so glad you liked Strangeland and Primordia. I hope we can continue to engage you and entertain you with games to come! Much love!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993315270', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1623182796}
review: I wish there was more new quests like this! Love every single bit of it. A little bit short and puzzles are too easy though.
developer_response: Thanks -- glad you liked it, despite finding the puzzles too easy. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198069473319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1623233515}

author: {'steamid': '76561198021923033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1623214661}
review: Words really don't do Strangeland justice, but for what it's worth, this is a sublime, gorgeous nightmare of a game. Deeply unsettling, with a core of raw emotion that must be experienced to be understood. Definitely worth playing through multiple times, whether to contemplate the layers upon layers of meaning and allegory or just to try and find all the different possible solutions to the puzzles. Despite its alien aesthetic, this game is, at its heart, about being human.
developer_response: Your beautiful review lit up my morning. Thank you so much -- for playing our game, for engaging with it, and for sharing your kind words.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015327809', 'num_games_owned': 1108, 'num_reviews': 352, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1622142703}
review:
Strangeland is like a modern spritual successor to Sanitarium and Darkseed in atmosphere and tone. The atmosphere is great and the puzzles are mostly pretty good except for breaking one of the cardinal rules of adventure game design and having a MI2 monkey wrench type puzzle. There is a good hint system though if you get stuck, but that shouldn't be a problem most of the time. The narrative is just kind of standard "MC trapped in mind purgatory" plot that is a bit old hat for horror games but it works. The voice-acting like all WadjetEye published/developed is very good though and helps strengthen the game.

Overall Strangeland is a very solid adventure game, I don't think its one of the modern greats and I liked Primordia a bit more, but I definitely recommend it.
developer_response:
Thanks so much (for the review, and for playing both our games)! Grateful for your kind words, and above all the time you put into the games.

I'm curious -- which puzzle is the one you're alluding to? I'm having trouble thinking which it could be, though there are certainly puzzles that have annoyed some players. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197993210872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1621987584}
review: I like it when a game goes old-school and has a great storyline to support the retro foundation.  Strangeland is one of those.  The creator, Wormwood Studios, made one of my previously fav games called Primordia.  This has the same bleak and dystopian shiny, drippy, orange, foggy, wonderful feel of Primordia but adds an unsettling premise and downright haunting visuals.  I think the length was just fine but I will say I used the "cheat phone" way too much since it was so easy to click.  Hints were strategically and uniquely dealt out, although I really got stuck a couple times even with the hints.  Highly recommend to people who liked Primordia, Gemini Rue, Sanitarium, Dark Seed, and of course I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream.
developer_response: Thank you so much for your kind words about both Strangeland and Primordia, and more generally for your fondness for classic adventures. We're glad to do our part to keep the genre chugging, but we absolutely couldn't do it without players like you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004390658', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 768, 'last_played': 1657215228}
review:
"Cicadas crawl through the dark for 6,000 days, all for a few brief weeks of light and love. Do not waste your wings." It's a cicada emergence right now. Just serendipitous that I recently played this.

Just learned that this evening and the talk with The Cicada in Strangeland is what hit with me hardest.
developer_response:
Thank you so much!

I was 7 when Brood X emerged in Washington, D.C. in 1987 and the memory of it has stuck with me ever since: an image of a world that is both natural and supernatural, short-lived and eternally cyclical, horrifying and beautiful. All of Strangeland could be packed into one of those bugs: digging their way up from the earth, bursting from their nightmarish shells as a perlescent imago, then grow hard and strong and dark and taking to the air for a desperate bid at love. God knows what it means, but it must mean something.

Anyway, I'm grateful you played the game, and took the time to share your kind thoughts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043639327', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1623185503}
review:
I don't write reviews but this game was really unique and I felt I had to. Really engrossing abstract story, very cool visual style, creepy and uncomfortable experience but not horrifying.

The puzzles are pretty good, with very limited point-and-click bullshit (no endlessly combining items or clicking items on to random crap in the environment). It also has in-narrative hints and a help feature which is fully-voiced and intertwined in the story (it doesn't even feel like looking for help). 

The story is really engrossing and abstract. It is quite interpretive, so if you like clear cut and well spelled out stories, I don't think this game is for you.

Strong recommendation.
developer_response: Thank you so much for deciding to write a review for our game -- and for writing such a kind one!

author: {'steamid': '76561198096606179', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1623164651}
review:
+短小精悍，剧情紧凑
+解密难度适中
+美术风格非常非常有想象力
+配音不错
-没有中文

整体略逊于<Primodia>吧，希望primodia和strangeland以后都有机会中文化。

Hope Primodia and Strangeland will have a chinese localization one day
developer_response:
我们当然希望有一天能够这样做。 中国游戏市场是一个庞大而重要的市场，我们很乐意与它分享我们的游戏。 然而，从 26 个字母的罗马字母到巨大的汉字字母，存在一些重大的技术挑战。 即使我们能解决这些技术问题，游戏文本即使翻译成非常接近英语的语言（例如法语和德语）也不容易。

但我仍然梦想有一天我们会这样做。 几年前我在中国生活了几周，我所到之处都受到了热烈的欢迎和友善，这让我希望我们的小游戏能帮助我与其他国家的玩家建立联系 语言。 显然有很多中国玩家会说一口流利的英语（比如你），但如果可能的话，我想克服语言障碍。 :) 

[Hopefully Google Translate did not make too much of a mess of that!]

author: {'steamid': '76561198009351597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1622958334}
review:
This game was quite a journey, it's very dark and macabre so keep that in mind but it's a very good game if you enjoy such things. The built in hint system was actually rather useful. Playtime was roughly 6-7 hours for me, your mileage may vary. I did a second play through with the annotations and commentary turned on and it was neat to learn about the inspirations and themes of the game and also learn just how much research they'd done.

I will mention as a trigger warning this game deals with some creepy things, death, suicide and weird imagery.
developer_response: Thanks, Greg. So glad you enjoyed it! "Quite a journey" is exactly what we were shooting for. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197963928308', 'num_games_owned': 501, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1622145616}
review: Take it from an old Point and clicker.  (1st point and click game I completed was quest for glory on DOS)  This game does not disappoint! We have so very few truly well done games with very dark themes.  Strangeland reminds me of Sanitarium in the best way.  If you like dark themes/mental health struggle or just point and click games in general this game is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034402756', 'num_games_owned': 3341, 'num_reviews': 364, 'playtime_forever': 1445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1445, 'last_played': 1623103818}
review:
Sublime, fully voiced point & click! Very player minded, disturbingly surreal and anxious; a must for lovers of the genre! 

[h2]Story of Strangeland?[/h2]
Our protagonist spawns at the end of a dead-end road, with a big directional sign 'Strangeland' next to him. Next to the road is nothing... a void. He has no idea who he is, so some people call him 'The Stranger'. He walks down the path, where he encounters a gate, which is also a giant mouth of a clown, who tells him a joke? You know, those gates that can be found in amusement parks or a carnival. The stranger sees no other way than directly into the mouth, with a plethora of signs to convince him that that is indeed the correct way! He walks over the clowns tongue into a room with in the centre a well, and a woman. The Stranger feels he has to save her, but the woman throws herself down the well! A crow tells that the woman keeps on returning, in order to to throw herself in the well, over and over, to save him?? Our Stranger is determined to save the woman, and the rest of this story filled with mindgames and metaphors I'll leave for you to find out! 

[h2]Very player minded [/h2]
The game is very smooth, almost all of time it's clear what needs to be done, and if you're unsure what to do, you can dial 0 on a payphone to receive a hint. Basically a walkthrough inside the game. Your inventory is kept pretty small, so there is not a lot to combine. Everything that can be carried has a function. 
The game has a standard P&C structure: at first you can choose or find several objectives that can be done in any order, and after that the story becomes linear. You never have to travel far, and even then you still have the option to skip the walking animation by clicking two times on the next zone. Pretty neat feature! 

[h2]Audial and visual design [/h2]
The voice acting is wonderful! It's of a very solid quality! It makes it so much easier to follow and enjoy the story! The sound effects are good, and the music is pure atmospherical I think, I can't remember any melody, except a maddening organ tune. Everything fits really well. 
The pixelart is good, but many parts are obscure, which is absolutely fine. The cinematics are not fully animated, but that's not needed either. 

[h2]Involved developers [/h2]
The devs respond alot to discussion topics, but I have also seen them in a stream I always watch that covered the game briefly. And I have played this with a group of players, with them reading our reactions and providing help where requested. 

[h2]Conclusions [/h2]
I love this game, even though I had some problems with acquiring the achievements. Some demand being done in one playthrough for example, while not stated in the achievement, and one requires reflexes of a competitive FPS game. I am certain they will finetune this in the upcoming weeks. 
This game is carefully polished, and knowing that Wormwood Studios consists of only three people, chapeau! 
Some people might find it a bit short with an average playthrough of 5-6 hours, but I personally like that. The price reflects that, I think. You could also criticise that the story is slightly generic. For me this game is an instant classic, especially because of the voice acting! 

89/100

[table]
[tr]
[td]
[i]If you're interested in playing games like this simultaneous with other friendly and mature people on a scheduled basis, drop a line in the comments below!  [/i][/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[td]
[i]More reviews at [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/39546715/]Omnivore Gamer[/url], games that are easy to control (for handicapped gamers). [/i][/td]
[/tr]
[/table]
developer_response: Thanks so much -- it's easy to be an engaged developer when you have such engaged players. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198389640481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1623098129}
review:
So far, I have played a total of four games from Wadjet Eye studio: Primordia, Shardlight, Unavowed, and of course Strangeland. And I have to say that, since 2017, when I played the first, I have never been disappointed, not for a single instant. All these 4 games are true masterpieces, not less. Every single one of them is a 10/10 for me, and I am not even exaggerating. Primordia is virtually perfect both in visuals and storytelling, Shardlight has a great and unique atmosphere, Unavowed is even better than Primordia, it is full of characters so well characterized that they almost seem alive, and finally... Strangeland is the Gigerian nightmare I was anxiously looking for. The visuals of this game are so beautiful, creepy, alien, dark, gothic, surreal and nightmarish that, while playing, I had the sensation to be looking at one of H. R. Giger's artbooks. The ambience STRONGLY resembles the alien wrecked ship you can see in the first "Alien" movie, and also the gloomy atmosphere is VERY similar, to the point that you almost expect to suddenly see a xenomorph jump at you from nowhere! But of course the plot is fully original, and very clever in my opinion. It is somewhat different from the usual stories from these devs, which are usually very intricate and based on carismatic characters whom you slowly learn to love as they were alive. In this game, both the plot and the characters are cryptic and mysteryous to say the least. You won't understand a thing until you finish the game, no kidding. But when you reach the end... oh, the blast! The blast! You fully understand the real purpose of all that mystery. And your mind blows! I'll say no more, I'd ruin your experience. Let's just say that this game is... a true nightmare. Literally. In a nightmare, you feel helpless, even hopeless sometimes, in the worst cases you feel scared, but in general you simply don't understand where you are and what you are supposed to do. And everything looks threatening and horrific to you. That's why you start feeling panick and sweating in real life! This game is all that. And much more. And the puzzles? This game is a classic point and click adventure (right from the 90's!), so it is obviously full of puzzles. Like in the other games from Wadjet Eye, they are a bit difficult, but nothing exaggerated. I'd say they are intelligently balanced. AND, if you find yourself stuck (as I did many many times!), don't worry at all: there's a hint system which literally tells you what to do if you insist questioning it for a while. So you don't even need a guide, you can fully and freely enjoy the plot and the art of the game without pausing every minute to go look for a solution on Steam or the internet. And some of the puzzles are really really clever, I was truly impressed in some occasions. To summarize, let's say that I liked this game as much as Primordia and Unavowed, unforgettable masterpieces of modern graphic adventures. That's the best thing about these games. You'll never forget them. They will always be in your heart for the time to come, either for their astonishing artwork, or for their incredibly human characters (even if they're actually robots, like in Primordia!). So, well... do yourself a precious gift: play these four games I told you about. Play them, and get ready to feel something unique you will always remember with great affection. Thank you Wadjet Eye, I mean it.
Cheers guys!
developer_response: Thank you so much for the effusive praise, and for playing not just Strangeland and our other game Primordia, but the sister games that WEG has published and developed. :) It's great to have such fans!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011581319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1666044115}
review: I highly recommend Strangeland if you are in the mood for a short, dense and visually stunning point and click adventure game.  The Story is both unsettling and thought provoking in equal measure. Very strong Dark Seed, Sanitarium and I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream vibes if you are in the mood for that.  Also Wadjet Eye always bring their best voice work to the table to bring each character to life. Check it out if you like your adventure games dark and introspective!
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words, and the comparison to those classic games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013110518', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1622400685}
review:
Did I hate playing Strangeland? Not really, no. The atmosphere sucked me in, the various bizarre characters were fun to converse with and the voice acting was also quite pleasant. So there’s that. I’ve played worse games. Trust me, I have. Heck, I could’ve even overlooked the relatively straightforward puzzle design, although I’m sure veteran puzzle-solvers will find the game frustratingly easy. But most important of all, I really wish the game actually told you an intriguing, fleshed-out story with characters you learned to love and care about – instead, it tosses you the cliff notes edition of their tragedy before abruptly rolling the credits.

For more honest indie game reviews, check out our Curator page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/6481290-GTOGG/
developer_response: Sorry you had a bad experience -- definitely not a game everyone will love, but I'm glad you at least spent only your time and not your money on something you didn't enjoy, though ultimately I find that disappointment is disappointment, regardless of whether I paid for that disappointed. :/

author: {'steamid': '76561198002563765', 'num_games_owned': 559, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1623062437}
review:
Pick this one up for sure. While I only spent 3 hours or so I did beat the game but I tend to read far ahead of the voice acting and I rarely hit any roadblocks which I often do in this genre.

The subject matter was definitely on the heavy side and hit me on a personal level for multiple reasons which I won't dig into because this is a Steam review, not a dissertation on my personal life, and also because divulging any details could absolutely spoil the story.

If I didn't burn through the game at an rapid pace I'd say this game is a solid 5 hours, and for the $15 price point I'd say that's more than reasonable. I know there are multiple paths you can take to explore more of the game as well which could extend that playtime a bit if that's your concern. It's not for me, however, since I approach games like this like I would a good book; if it's a solid read, I don't really care how many pages it has.

For those of you that might have reservations about playing this because it suggests it's a horror game; it's really not. There are no jump scares -- audio or visual -- and any of the grotesque creepiness is less about monsters or HP Lovecraft and more about the tragedy of the human condition/mortality. Other than a few moments of "damn, gross" you're not going to be frightened.

Now that I've got all of that out of the way, the art direction, sound design, writing, and intuitiveness (I'll elaborate in a moment) are excellent. My critiques were few and far between but in order to give this a fair analysis I'll include them (really, your team did a fantastic job). The first minor issue I had was with the level of obscurity in the writing, then a "boss fight" that was so on the nose it was hard to take seriously. It was a strange contrast; from abstract storytelling to a symbolic sledgehammer in minutes (edit: this statement was a little too harsh so I toned it down a bit).

Lastly, regardless of what the How to Play might suggest, definitely write things down if they seem important; it skipped some steps in a process of elimination puzzle and kept things a lot easier to track in other places. If you want to revisit the same dialogue multiple times in different areas because you refused to write it down, that's all you. You also will have at least one moment where you just start randomly combining things in your inventory (despite the How to Play suggestion that you shouldn't) because there are easily 2 combinations that I would have never intuitively figured out. But this is subjective; your results may vary!

As far as intuitiveness, across the board I rarely got stuck outside of the random combo moments, and I had a pretty clear direction where to go even if I had a few minutes of hesitation. For me that's kind of a big deal because I started point and clicks in the old school days of King's Quest where you'd combine the Owl Scrotum with the Purple Feather to make a concoction for the Alchemist but only at night or some such ridiculous bullshit that always infuriated me. This game did not go the obscure approach and kept it almost exclusively logical while still providing some rewarding "ah-ha" moments.

If you're looking for a good modern adventure game with a very dark theme; seriously it's pretty dark and not in a spooky way, this is a great game to pick up. In fact, I'll probably double down and pick up their earlier release, Primordia because I was so impressed with this one.
developer_response: So glad it had that personal meaning for you. And many thanks for the thorough, thoughtful review. If you wind up giving Primordia a try, I hope you like it too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048885385', 'num_games_owned': 1332, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1622950178}
review:

The story is executed well IMO even though it feels a bit played out at times. 

Gameplaywise it is a standard point and click adventure game focused mostly on inventory puzzles, the puzzles are clear and straightforward and at no point I felt some moon logic was required.

In general, it is an excellent game, going to get primordia as soon as I can and can’t wait to hear what the team has in mind next.
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198442230810', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1622999285}
review:
[h1]Strangeland[/h1]

Review written after completing game.

[b] This is a Point and Click game - done right![/b]
[hr]										[/hr]
[list]
[*] Beautiful graphics
[*] Complimentary music that sets the scenes tone and atmosphere
[*] Story, story, story. There is a lot of it here. My emotions ran the gamut whilst playing this.
[*] Mechanics. No wheels were reinvented
[*] Manual and an autosave spot! You have unlimited saves.

Step into a surreal carnival and test your emotional mettle. Oh, and get ready to die, a lot. That is intended. 

The devs game summary on the sales page is accurate so I will not reiterate here.

The writing is superb. It would be easy to blast through the game, do take some time to enjoy and decipher the writing.

Voice overs include the always fabulous Abe Goldfarb and Ivy Dupler.

No walk-through needed! Puzzles are fair to the player and spaced well; if you missed a clue, you can always call your friendly telephone operator for a nudge in the right direction.

There are a lot of life’s truths in this game; I quite enjoyed it but cringed a few times :-), crying at the end. Crying at the credits of all things :)-))

I play a lot of games. Few make me feel satisfied; this game did.

My play time was about six hours.
developer_response:
Thank you so much for the review! Means a ton to read it.

(We did add the inventory wheel, so there's that!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198018505999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1622946752}
review: I rarely play anything labeled as "horror" but trust that anything Wadjet Eye puts out will be worth playing, and I'm really glad to have given Strangeland a chance. The eerie visuals/atmosphere and dream-like feel of most of the story combine to make a truly memorable trip into the darkness of intense grief and depression. I found the puzzles to be just challenging enough  that I had to stop and think about them without being so hard that I got frustrated or completely taken out of the flow of the story. Looking forward to playing with the commentary on soon!
developer_response:
Thank you so much for this beautiful review -- a little balm of Gilead when it's needed. :)

I'm curious to read what you think of the commentary!

author: {'steamid': '76561197990712811', 'num_games_owned': 911, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1622925321}
review: A little bit short, and a maybe too easy, but overall a pleasant surprise and a well worth it.
