author: {'steamid': '76561198057386857', 'num_games_owned': 4154, 'num_reviews': 816, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1622914968}
review:
Well, I did not like the game in the end. Although the game is definitely not for me, mostly because of the ideas it carries, I must say that, as far as I can tell, it took a step forward from a game design perspective. The subjective shortcomings I noticed are perfectly described in other reviews and I will not expand on them much:
[list]
[*] The convoluted presentation does not help the narrative, in my humble opinion.
[*] The character is somehow disconnected from the apparent surroundings: for a person living a nightmare he is being too distant and underreacting a lot.
[*] The character's behavior occasionally looks inadequate. Almost all adventure characters I like (April Ryan, Victoria McPherson, Azriel Odin, to name a few) are or, I would say, have to be a little cynical and humorous to naturally blurt out, "No way I want to burn this," when trying to use a gas-burner on a random TV. Unfortunately, these kinds of remarks feel stilted in "Strangeland".
[/list]
What really ruined the experience for me, is the focus on the concept of loss and finding a way of living through with it. The developer got a bit cheesy in the in-game comments, and I would allow myself to do the same. I personally perceive loss in all its glorious irreversibility as a great monument to life's naturalness, absurdity, and also humans' transience, which does not help with understanding the character who is struggling against it for almost all of the story. This, in turn, brings me to the main pain point — the endings. Spoilers ahead. [spoiler]In the end you have an option to escape (to jump), to escape efficiently (to kill yourself), to escape inefficiently (to try fighting), and to escape by evolving (to use wings).[/spoiler]
Where is the option to do literally nothing? The authors that influenced my current self the most are Kafka, Camus, Kawabata, and, maybe, Bates, so it comes as no surprise that I ask again, "Where is the option to do absolutely nothing? (Because the boundary between depression and melancholy is an ephemeral one, there is no significant difference between dying on your knees or fighting, because there is no significant difference among the absurdities of life in the first place.)
Do not mind me though, "Strangeland" is a great game overall.
developer_response:
Ha! You know you're in for something special when a negative review concludes with "'Strangeland' is a great game overall." What you wrote is nuanced and erudite, and it's too bad that the great algorithm in the sky will simply reduce this to a downvote on the game. Such is life in the zone.

It's always interesting to find oneself the Bizarro to a Superman, and that is what strikes me most about this review. Obviously we have a shared fondness for adventures (like me, you comfortably rattle off adventure game protagonists -- but the ones you list are all among my least favorite!), similar literary tastes (Kafka in particular), and a similar interest in the thematic content of games. Yet I see the world in the opposite terms that you do. As you know from the commentary, to me the line between melancholy and depression (at least as I think we're both using those terms) is fundamental. I refuse to believe that the proper reaction to the world's outrages and absurdities is to give in; this is not to say I've never given in, only that I don't view life as one in which there are "no significant differences" in whether one acts with love, dignity, restraint, compassion, etc. or not.

However, I do think you have misperceived the endings -- which is to say, I did not convey the ending options clearly enough, since the fault is always with the designer and not the player.

[spoiler]Jumping back into the park is absolutely not escape. It is surrender to inertia. Hence the clown's joke at the end indicating that you're exactly back where you started, unchanged. Of course jumping is not "doing nothing"; I suppose a player who truly wants to "do nothing" can just quit the game or leave it running without interacting with it. But from a gameplay standpoint, you need to offer an action to represent even inaction. The two knife options also strike me as categorically different. One is reflects a fundamental misunderstanding of how to overcome your problem, but it is an effort to overcome it. The other is just an effort to end it all.[/spoiler]

Anyway, there is no doubt you gave the game every opportunity to make you like it, and it failed (which is to say, I failed, since the code, art, music have nothing to do with your dislike). I still find myself rolling around the contrast of the review's ending, but let me end this comment unambiguously: your review is great, and I liked it. I'm glad there are gamers like you. Some day Bizarro and Superman may come to grips, but today I'd rather just grab a coffee and trade thoughts.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976955550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1622912703}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995059892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1623456025}
review: It's short. I'll give it that. That is a plus. It does not overstay its welcome. The pacing is very good. It tells its story and it tells it wonderfully. At first I thought it would be a typical, cheesy horror thing due to the carnival themes, but thankfully it shattered those expectations. The horror in this game is very personal. And I think it's personal to a lot of people. And that's why I'd recommend it. It goes into themes we will all inevitably get intimate with, and it does it so quite well. I recommend it. I look forward to see more from this studio.
developer_response:
Ah, this review is music to my ears -- particularly your take that the horror is both a "personal" one and one that many of us have experienced.

Our prior game is Primordia, which is sci-fi not horror, and is a little rougher around the edges, but you might enjoy it (it has generally been well-liked by players)!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000248322', 'num_games_owned': 1220, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1622530355}
review:
Yes I like this game...BUT
Strangeland is a trippy, creepy, and chuckle worthy point and click adventure game that has some neat abstract and surreal elements to keep it interesting. Although at times it seems to either get lost in itself (or I'm just too dumb to get it) but it's still a good experience and scratches the itch for point and click nostalgia. 

Pros: 
- The art style is creepy and really cool. It kind of gives the whole atmosphere a very surreal feeling that just has you tilting your head going "whaaa?" 
- The puzzles are decently balanced. There weren't too many times I thought "ooookay how was I supposed to know/think that?" 
- Voice acting is pretty solid. I think there might be a couple of audio clipping issues here and there, but ultimately it's not bad. Initially the main character's intonation felt weird, but I realized it's because the character was reading a sign and not just speaking. Pretty neat! 

Cons - 
- Level design. While the art is amazing, I find the world to be a bit cramped. There's only a small handful of screens and it adopts almost this looping hallway mechanic which I'm beyond tired of. It's not really bad here, but it feels a bit claustrophobic. 
- Story. As I said, it could be me being too dumb to get it, BUT there's sections of the beginning that feel....pretentious? Like my eyes just glazed over as I'm hearing some characters drone on and it's all just noise to me at a certain point. But (no spoilers) the end comes around and it REALLY hammers on a very simple story ending. It's almost like the game knew I wasn't getting it and then it attacked me with a "This story for dummies" manual. Fair enough I suppose. 

TLDR; Great art design, atmosphere, voice acting. Story/dialogue in the beginning seems a bit convoluted and then real dumbed down by the end and it could do with a bit more variety in the world. Not my favorite point and click, but definitely better than some others out there.
developer_response: Thanks for the balanced, thorough review. The differences in tone throughout the course of the story reflect, in part, the protagonist's growing self-understanding -- as the layers of masks are stripped away, the situation becomes clearer. (Obviously, the approach didn't exactly work for you, though!) If you're curious about the earlier references, you can always speedrun with annotations on, and they explain how the various images and metaphors fit together. Not for everyone, of course.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066049963', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1622855136}

author: {'steamid': '76561198005630213', 'num_games_owned': 774, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1622844831}
review:
Ah, such a little gem. Blending childhood nostalgia, with great art and music and a very interesting story. I gotta say, I missed most of the symbology in my first run and indeed I was trying to interpret the story the absurd way (as three mad men doing weird experiment on a woman and one of them regretting it to the point of amnesia and delusions ["I gotta be Alberich, how was it spelled? That has to be my name, right? Oh silly input"]) 

And then I played my second run with commentaries and notes and, it becomes a deeper and richer narration (indeed, to create a horror game but with no blood. Genius!), soooo many references that I had no idea about, parallelisms, homophones, contrasts - is just a delight to absorb. Like having a good time hearing a friend who's so passionate about a theme that wakes my curiosity up, makes me appreciate the game way more. And of course, all these intimate comments of melancholic feelings and thoughts, that makes me feel lucky to be a confidant of. It requires a lot of bravery, I'm not sure I would be able to do it. I guess I'm one of these ppl who don't have a sibilant super-ego whispering to my ear, so it's totally insightful to see through the *eyes* of others. And in this case, it just enriches the whole experience of playing a great game. 

So many thanks for this game!

Edit: Oh! And the voice cast of this game...! Is SO good! The raven on the tree really gave me shivers when reciting the words.
developer_response: Darius -- Thank you for this beautiful, touching review. I'm glad you have no Super Ego calling you. :) And if he ever should, let me say that you have brought light to the entire development team by your kind words, which has to be worth something karmically!

author: {'steamid': '76561198319303847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1622837991}
review:
Wormwood studios and all the included develeopers of this game. You my friends are absolute genious and i much enjoyed this game as did i also enjoy all of your previous released games. primordia was the first game i played and since then i have played thru almost all other games you have produced and i truly loved them all.

I love the underlying sometimes almost poetic narration , depth and wonderful artstyle in this particular game. The surreal surroundings and quite intuitive controls and logical proggresion rate is spot on and fenomenaly executed. I have played a LOT of games in this genre and i must say that you absolutely nailed everything about it with the music, gameplay, character creation and i could go on and on. but suffice to say in my book this game is a pure masterpieces.

if someone reads this i can gladly recommend anyone who like point and cklick adventure games to buy this game and i can promise that you will like it.

Keep doing what you do best and the sky is the limit for all of you and the exellent games you make. 

The only drawback i feel now after completing the game is that its over but i liked every moment.

i very much look forward to your next games with excitemnet and for me  this is a 20 out of 10.

hail to the people you meantioned that left us too soon. may they look down on you  all with much pride and love and rest assure you will unite with them once again someday somewhere :)
developer_response: Thank you so much for this heartfelt -- and felt again in my heart -- review of our game. It means the world.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972445688', 'num_games_owned': 426, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1622827125}
review:
I was a big fan of Primordia and it was Primordia that first introduced me to Wadjet Eye Games so I knew I had to play this game, even though I don't really like these sort of stories (see below). My review will be more of a post-play discussion so if you want an absolutely no spoiler review then I will say buy this game if you liked Primordia but be prepared for a very different type of story and I think this game is kind of dark. So if you play games for happiness you may not wish to play this game.

Also in the commentary I believe I heard several times they refer to it as a horror game, but I would disagree. Depends how you interpret that word horror, but for me, if I am not afraid, it wasn't really a horror game. This game has dark themes but I wouldn't consider it horrifying or scary. Games like Alien Isolation, Dead Space - those are what I class as horror games. So if you're worried you'll be too scared to play it - don't be worried and buy!

[spoiler]By "these sorts of stories" I mean allegorical stories where there is no real story, it's "all in your head". Double-fake as the lead writer puts it in the dev commentary. Speaking of the commentary, I found I understood the allegories a lot more from the commentary than from the game itself. Maybe that's because I'm an uncultured swine though. And culture is another important point - unless you are well-read in multiple forms of classic literature ranging from T.S. Eliot to the Holy Bible and Norse mythology (aka "stuff that was written long before you were born" most of the allegories will fly write over your head like they did mine, until explained in the dev commentary.

In terms of puzzles I definitely enjoyed the "logic box" approach and the only time I ever got stuck and called the phone line for a hint was because I didn't actually realise there was a hole in the tent that could be peeked through to get the dead rat and the coins. The puzzle that I think gave me the most satisfaction to solve was probably the 1 wanton 1 puzzle. 

My fav room was the one with the mecha-mermaid and the telepathic starfish, which also made me long for a literal storyline where we explore some creepy ocean-realm inhabited by such creatures. Alas, it's allegory all the way down in this tale.

The mirror finale section I know was said in the commentary that it was worked on last, and underwent several revisions until it felt right. I'm of the opinion it still doesn't feel right. I think this is mainly because of what was said in another commentary though, because the logic box concept was ditched for the final section and a more linear approach used.

I was surprised to learn AGS has so many flaws and the programmer had to implement so many strategies to work around them, causing people to express amazement that it is even on the AGS engine - which must be very satisfying to hear. I'm surprised with this very old-style games that things such as lag and memory are still an issue! It makes me wonder if there are other engines out there that could be considered for future projects to take the next adventure game to even new heights of modern tech in the retro style? (But please never abandon the 2D pixelart! I was quite dismayed to hear that Technobabylon 2 was opting to ditch it for 3D - it just doesn't stoke the same fires of nostalgia!)

Speaking of art and music, I can't say much because I all I know is how little I know in these fields. The distinct artstyle from Primordia is very apparent to my untrained eye, however, and I look forward to seeing more of it in future projects. It was interesting to hear in the commentary how the music is made, but no track made any particular imprint into my brain. But neither did any music stand out to me as being out of place. And maybe that is the best type of music a game like this needs? Working unnoticed behind the scenes of your mind to put you into the same mental state as the Stranger.

The Stranger, you poor soul. I myself have experienced grief very rarely and in circumstances where grief is perhaps not even the right word. Should one grieve for the loss of their grandmother after she had lived a full life and died in her sleep? Is that not the best ending we all should hope for? Yet despite the inevitability of death, all but the machine-men among us are affected by it in an upsetting way. And as we all shuffle down the mortal coil, we are assaulted with its inevitability again and again until at last our own turn comes.

And in those twilight years you are asking yourself absurd questions, like is it better to be the first one to die, so you don't have to witness the death of your loved ones one by one? Or is it better to be the last, and thus spare them from that pain, taking the burden on yourself? Fortunately for most of us, we do not have to make that choice. Death comes when it comes. Though as euthanasia becomes more commonplace among 1st world countries, perhaps we will have to face that tough choice after all.

Yet what has happened to the Stranger, and to many of those less fortunate than us, such as the coach in the commentary, is death or disease comes far earlier than feels fair. Suddenly, that dreadful thing we knew we'd have to deal with SOMEday becomes TOday. This is when grief can evolve into depression as you rage against a world that has already taken so much is taking even more, and far sooner than was promised. This is the fate of the Stranger, dealing with his wife's death from cancer after unsuccessful attempts at treatment (at which I heard the late Christopher Hitchens once say - the cure is worse than the disease).

To deal with this tragedy, the Stranger goes into some elaborate carnival mind-palace like Benedict Cumberbatch as Sherlock Holmes, going deeper and deeper into his mind like Christopher Nolan's Inception, but does this ever actually happen in real life? I think that's why I find these sort of "it was all in his head" stories unappealing, because has any human in the history of forever ACTUALLY done this? Yes, artists have been inspired by tragedy to create some incredible things, but are homo sapiens actually capable of creating mind palaces this intricate to shield themselves from harsh truths of reality? I think it's just something that exists in fiction, and not something humans can actually do. But I'd be interested to read research that says otherwise!

As for the endings, I will say what I wish there was was one more ending. Because let's break the endings down here. We've got basically one good 'canon' ending and a bunch of bad endings. We have fly away and escape your mind palace and embrace the harsh reality of your wife's death (good ending) (as an aside, i wish we'd gotten just ONE more scene of him waking up at the hospital or something, just so we could have got one tiny glimpse at the REAL world of Strangeland). We have stab yourself with a knife (what exactly is going on here, does this mean I'm willing my heart to stop beating in actuality or something?) We have jump off the cliff and return to Strangeland (presumably the worst of the endings, as this is the only one where your spouse objects to you doing so), where you presumably will just be stuck in the endless loop of being stuck in your mind palace. And then we have attack the Dark Thing in a doomed attempt to kill him, but he just kills you (again, like with the stabbing of the knife, I'm not sure what this means literally to the Stranger's physical body and allegorically what it means, that you were defeated by your depression? Isn't that kind of like the stab-yourself ending?)

Now break these endings down what have you really got? (1) good ending (2) suicide by knife (3) suicide by falling, (4) suicide by doomed charge at your foe. So really it's just 2 endings, one of which has 3 flavours of suicide. I would have one more ending, just for a bit more variety...[/spoiler]

I ran out of characters LOL - see comments for the rest.
developer_response:
Very lovely review! I'm grateful for it, and for the time you spent in Strangeland, despite your aversion to allegorical / inward-looking stories. A few spoiler reactions!

[spoiler]The ending you mention was actually one that I contemplated, but ultimately I decided that it didn't really make any sense. Perhaps an interaction where you try to bargain with the DT to take the orb in exchange for leaving you alone; but that bargain doesn't work. You can hand over your last hope to despair and expect the despair to go away as a result!

Regarding whether anyone ever actually inhabits a space like this, I would say: (1) to some extent in dreams but (2) generally, no. But the only way to merge adventure gameplay with introspection is to externalize the internal -- otherwise, you just end up with a lot of dialogues, cutscenes, etc. in which your character explains his self-doubts, griefs, traumas, etc. You then wind up with a disconnect between the ostensibly inward-looking narrative and the gameplay. None of the "verbs" by which you play the game would relate to the "action" of the internal narrative. So, this seemed like a solution to bridge the gameplay and narrative. It seems to have worked for some, not for others.

But, ultimately, I was driven by two imperatives: I needed to tell a story about these themes, and I am committed to adventure games in which the gameplay drives the narrative, rather than being detached from it. So even knowing that it would be a hit-or-miss product, it's the one I had to make. :P[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198039131560', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1622751149}
review:
This is a difficult game to review. The main thing that made me buy it was the developer's previous title, Primordia, which I have very much enjoyed and recommended thoroughly. It is not an easy sell this time, but I still think there's enough to like to tilt my vote towards "recommend".

[h1]Gameplay and performance[/h1]

The gameplay hasn't changed much. It's still a very standard point-and-click adventure puzzle game. It's not especially difficult, but unlike Primordia the world sometimes works on crazy logic, so don't expect it to be straightforward all the time. This is justified narratively of course, but still don't be afraid to use the game's nice narrative hint system if you need it. Whatever engine the devs are using must have gotten an update since Primordia because it works much better with modern resolutions now and doesn't panic when you dare to minimize the window. The only issue I encountered was that once the game refused to close. So overall: runs well, plays well.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]

This is easily the game's strongest point. The artist(s) did a fantastic job adapting their already striking style to the nightmarish imagery of the world. The art is full of detail, meaning, and character. This only gets more intense in the second part of the game where they pull out all the stops and embrace the amped up insanity of their setting. The sound manages to not disappoint either. Strangeland has some fantastic music that fits the tone of the game. This time around the standout track was The Yew. It's a shame it's so short. I'd love to hear an extended version. I will criticise some of the voice acting. There are absolutely great performances like Eight-Three, but some were lacking, like [spoiler]the Woman[/spoiler]. (As a side note, I don't necessarily blame the actors here. There is a lot that goes into how their voice comes out in the context of the game. It could be any number of things.) Most fall somewhere in the middle with more on the good side than bad.

[h1]Story[/h1]

Well, this is going to be difficult to do without spoilers, but it's also where most of my issues with the game are. Strangeland doesn't have a bad story, but it doesn't have a great one either. Where Primordia took inspiration from classical sci-fi, Strangeland seems (at least to this uninformed observer) inspired by psychological horror. Unfortunately, this makes it fall into some traps of the genre. Because so much of the world is surreal, it's hard to get attached to anyone or anything. Character development or growth is not really present. Half the characters are walking metaphors and the other half spout the same riddles over and over. The answers you will likely figure out far before the protagonist does. It all does tie together into a simple yet emotional story with a powerful message in the end. There is still enough there for a good plot. It's just that it's built on a bare-bones foundation.

On a technical level, I can praise the clever use of metaphors, especially when they are supported by the art. The use of different mythologies was also intriguing, and I have to give props to the effectiveness of the occasional dose of twisted dark humour. However, I can't ignore just how wordy the game can get at times. There are several points where the characters just keep repeating the same thing over and over again in different elaborate ways, as if the writer couldn't choose between four different metaphors and decided to write them all out in a row. Also, the irony of saying this in such a long-winded review that most people will probably never fully read it doesn't escape me, but that's just because I'm bad at this. Still, I will do a full-spoiler addedndum at the end that goes more in depth on my feelings about specifics of the plot and how they shaped the experience.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Strangeland is a good game, if you like what you see on the tin. It will supply a good amount of excellently-crafted horror art, which may be its main sell. It's competent at being a point-and-click puzzle game. And the story follows the themes you'd expect here. The writing has issues in terms of characterization and a lack of brevity, but the plot still holds together and delivers a satisfying conclusion. In my opinion it doesn't live up to the legacy of Primordia, but it doesn't have to. Probably worth the asking price, but if you're not sure about how much you would enjoy a psychological horror point-and-click in a nightmarish world, I wouldn't blame you for waiting for a sale.

[h1]SPOILER CRITIQUE[/h1]

[spoiler]This is mainly for the devloper and anyone else who—for some reason—wants to hear my take on the story. So the issue I danced around in my Story section is that everything that's going on is in the protagonist's head. This isn't a bad trope by itself, but it creates some challenges that Strangeland, in my opinion, failed to overcome. The main one being: you essentially have one character, two if you count the Woman. And when you fail to develop that one character, and write off your setting as just the protagonist's head, you are left with nothing but the motions of the plot. The problem is we learn very little about the Stranger beyond his self-loathing and his love for the Woman. We don't even get to see how their love came to be or what it was that held them together. There are plenty of metaphors but like the clever giant Cancer Crab, most of them are striking metaphors of events, not insights into who these people are.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]The game reminds me of Jacob's Ladder and Silent Hill 2, but with all the side characters taken out and with way less insight into the main character's past. I wanted to be intrigued by this world. I enjoyed talking to Nineveh and Eight-Three. I loved untangling the convoluted ball of Norse symbolism. I liked applying my (limited) knowledge of tarot to answer Murmur's questions in the way I thought fit best. I don't want this critique to sound like I'm ripping the game's story to shreds. It's just that once you see the main message, once you realize that every single character and every single conversation without exception is tied into death and loss, those characters that intrigued you become hollow shells that you feel silly for expecting more from. They're not just made up, which would have been fine. They're all reduced to a single metaphor. This story had strong emotion. It had a personal message. It had a beautiful depiction of internal struggle. The problem is that it had essentially nothing else.[/spoiler]
developer_response:
This is a thoughtful take on the game, and I very much appreciate you having played and spoken kindly of both our games. 

In terms of the spoiler text, I suppose I would say that the intention is actually to address two related themes:
[spoiler]An underlying lifelong despair and sense of inadequacy, which was held back to some degree by the light that love brought to the widower's life--and then the consequences of losing that light, and having the darkness come crashing back (with amplification) after the widower was unable to find a way to stop the cancer that killed his wife. Some of the symbols (like masks, mirrors, blindness, flying, etc.), are really more directed toward the former theme, while others (like crabs, poison, the woman falling into the well) are more directed at the latter. I'm not sure this changes your critique, but I figured I'd share it.[/spoiler]

To the extent you enjoyed unraveling imagery and references, you might enjoy the discussion/explication of them in the annotations and commentary tracks, though those aren't everyone's cup of tea.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030952840', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1633261184}
review:
While being only around 5 hours long, this is probably the most polished adventure game in the last years. The stunning art, the visual effects, the little details in the animation, the good amount of dialog as reaction to attempted actions... so much effort was put into making a beautiful thing that the engine was revamped in several aspects just to support the wanted features.

The puzzles are also natural, with a handful that are particularly bright.

The game also includes an extense audio commentary and notes explaining the references in the game.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this lovely review -- we did spend AGES on polishing stuff (actually the rough content doesn't take nearly so long to make), so it means the world when someone notices. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198024019407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 587, 'last_played': 1622702033}
review:
As much as you or I may have gotten into this because of Primordia, this isn't it and never tries to be it and is better for it.

Mild-ish spoilers ahead:

It's the heartfelt story of a man working through his grief and pain despite however much he might fight himself along the way. It's a tale of a man's struggles as a means to tell the tale of Wormwood's grandparents and what their story meant to him. It's a wonderful story and I enjoyed it from start to finish.

I loved the strange, macabre art style and what it meant for this man's twisted and broken psyche. The art was twisted, but wonderful and the game would never be the same without the surreal, nightmare quality it leant to the story and setting.

My point is it's good game please buy it. I can't recommend it enough if you want something both bizarre and heartfelt. It was fun and wonderful.  

Also the dev told me to say Primordia is better but don't listen to him he's fulla shit. I'm part of team Sir Cada too.
developer_response: Ha, thank you so much for streaming the game and for these words. (Including the joke at the end.) I'm glad that you appreciated the game as something very different from Primordia -- we wanted to explore something different, and I realize that has disappointed some players, but I'm glad it engaged you completely!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995662125', 'num_games_owned': 978, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1641835117}
review:
2012 tarihli Primordia, Wormwood Studios'un ilk oyunu olmasına rağmen gerçekten de oldukça üst düzey bir point 'n click adventure oyunuydu. Bir kere senaryosu cidden çok iyiydi, hikayeyi anlatım biçimi harikaydı, göndermeleri dört dörtlüktü, karakterleri oyuncuda yer ediyordu. Üstelik tam 7 farklı sonu vardı ve bu sonların hiçbirisi de öyle laf olsun diye hazırlanmış sonlar değildi.

Hal böyle olunca da Wormwood'un yeni oyunu Strangeland'i duyduğum andan beri büyük bir beklenti içine girmiştim. Paylaşılan ilk ekran görüntüleri ve hikaye detaylarından bizi oldukça tuhaf bir oyunun beklediği belliydi. Strangeland oldukça karanlık ve tuhaf bir hikaye anlatacaktı ki sırf bu bile oyunu sevmem için yeterli bir sebepti aslında. 

Son zamanlarda bir çok kaliteli adventure oyunu çıkıyor ama sürüden farklı temalara değinen oyun sayısı bir elin parmağını geçmez. Gönül istiyor ki Dark Seed gibi, Sanitarium gibi, I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream gibi uç hikayeler anlatan daha fazla oyun görelim. Strangeland'e başlayıp da kendimi deli ceketi giymiş halde o ışıklı Strangeland tabelasının önünde görür görmez "aha" dedim, "işte o oyun, bu oyun".

Strangeland bir karnaval dünyası, ama çarpık bir karnaval dünyası diyelim. Bu dünyada sirk çadırının girişini oluşturan dev palyaço kafası size karanlık espriler yapıyor, kuzgunlar konuşuyor, kör bir adam duyduğu kelimeleri kağıtlara karalıyor, telefonda sizin başka bir versiyonunuz size bolca kızıyor... Ve bir kadın çadırın ortasındaki kuyudan aşağı atıyor kendini. Hem de defalarca. Ve biz o kadını durduramıyoruz. Oyunun hikayesi de zaten buradan çıkıyor. O kadın kim, biz kimiz, ölmesini nasıl engelleyebiliriz? 

Strangeland baştan sona kadar metaforlar ve grotesk görüntülerle dolu bir oyun. Spoiler olabilecek hiçbir şey söylemeyeceğim, ama oyundaki neredeyse karşılaştığınız her karakter, her tuhaf yaratık aslında hayatınızdan bir parçayı temsil ediyor. Belki delirmiş, kafayı sıyırmış birinin beyninin içindeyizdir, kim bilir? Bu oyunda hata yapmak diye bir şey yok, ama ölmek var. Hani eski Sierra adventure oyunlarında hiç beklenmedik anda ölürdük ve oyuna sona ererdi ya (hey gidi günler), Strangeland'de ise ölmek bazen ilerlemek anlamına geliyor. Her öldüğümüzde kendimizi o ilk tabelanın altında buluyor ve bazen de bu sayede bulmacanın bir parçasını kafamızda çözmüş oluyoruz.

Tüm bu karanlık tema, oldukça başarılı bir grafik tarzıyla, buram buram H.R.Giger kokan görsellerle sunuluyor bize. Bu dünyada organik ile inorganik, canlılarla makineler, ölüler ve yaşayanlar, hayvanlar ve yaratıklar iç içe geçmiş durumda. Yakın çekim karakter görselleri de son derece detaylı ve animasyonlu. Buraya kadar her şey dört dörtlük.

Ancak oyun işin 'oynanış' kısmına geldiğinde Primordia'daki başarıyı sergileyemiyor bence. Bir kere kullanılan renk paletinden dolayı işimize yarayacak bazı eşyaları tespit etmek biraz zorlaşmış. Buna örnek olarak bir metal çubuğu ve bir cam parçasını verebilirim. Oyunda benzeri diğer oyunlardaki gibi bir "hotspot" tuşu yok, yani eski usül 'piksel avı' yapmanız gerekiyor çok takıldığınız durumlarda. 

Bu kadar orijinal bir tarzı ve hikayesi olan bir oyunun bulmaca konusunda sınıfta kalmış olmasıysa üzücü. Yani hala daha "iple kancayı birleştir, al sana tutma kancası" bulmacasının bir zorluğu olduğunu mu düşünüyor yapımcılar? Kapının altına kağıt koyup anahtarı üzerine düşürme bulmacası yok neyse ki. Gönül isterdi ki bulmacaları daha fazla ve daha zor olsun, ama baştan sona kadar takıldığım tek bir nokta bile olmadı. Mekaniksel bulmacalar ise (mesela bir ışığa basınca etrafındakiler söner, hepsini yakmaya çalışırsınız) atmosfere pek de uygun düşmemiş. Daha orijinal bir şeyler beklerdim. Takıldığınız bir yer olduğu takdirde de telefondan 0 numarasını çeviriyor ve o an sıradaki yapmanız gereken şeye dair ipucu alıyorsunuz. Yani oyun aslında sizin pek de bir yere takılıp zaman kaybetmenizi istemiyor, derdi hikayesini anlatmak.

Hikaye demişken... Strangeland ölümle, intiharla, yasla, kendine zarar vermekle, suçluluk duygusuyla ve benzer temalarla dolu. Zaten oyunun Steam sayfasında da bu uyarı yapılmış. Yeri geliyor bir bıçağı kendinize saplıyor, yeri geliyor kendinizi boşluğa bırakıveriyorsunuz. Yani bu tür temalardan etkilenen biriyseniz bunun pek de size göre bir oyun olmadığını söyleyebilirim.

Oyunun başında kafanızda kurduğunuz hikaye ile sonlara doğru kavradığınız hikaye birbirinden farklı olacak. Bu da oyunun anlatımdaki başarılarından biri aslında. Ancak oyunun süresinin kısa oluşu (yaklaşık 4 saat), bu farklı adventure oyunu deneyiminin tadının damakta kalmasına neden oluyor.

Aynı Primordia'da olduğu gibi Strangeland'de de birden fazla son var. Bunların üçü için kötü demek mümkün, ama tüm sonları görmek için oyunu baştan oynamanızı gerektirmiyor oyun. Tüm sonlar, oyunun finalinde vereceğiniz kararla belirleniyor ve bu sayede de önceki kaydınızı yükleyip tümünü görebiliyorsunuz. Bu farklı son olayının Primordia'nın bir adım gerisinde kaldığını söylemem lazım.

Eksiklerine veya 'daha iyi olabilecek' kısımlarına rağmen Strangeland kesinlikle oynanması gereken bir adventure oyunu bence. Özellikle de farklı türde, rahatsız edici içeriğe sahip, karanlık bir macera oyunu arıyorsanız Strangeland çok doğru bir seçim. Hele bu fiyata, Wormwood Studios gibi hevesli ve yaratıcı bir ekibe destek olmamak ayıp olur. Umuyorum ki Wormwood bir sonraki oyununda bundan da edindiği deneyimlerin üstüne koyacak ve Primordia'yı da geçecek bir oyunla karşımıza çıkacak.

+
Karanlık macera oyunlarına hasret kalmıştık
Seslendirmeler cidden çok başarılı
Wormwood gerçekten de orijinal hikayeler buluyor
Oyunun görsel yanı kuvvetli
Kaçırılmayacak derecede uygun bir fiyatı var

-
Bulmacalar konusunda daha özenli olunabilirdi
Oyunun sonu çoğu soru işaretini silmiyor
Hikayede daha fazla detaya yer verilip oyun süresi artırılabilirdi

[i]Not: Oyungezer Online'da yayınlanan incelememi burada da paylaşmak istedim.[/i]
developer_response: Bu dikkatli, düşünceli inceleme için çok teşekkür ederiz. Strangeland'e karşı birçok adil ve cömert puanlar veriyor ve her yorumun (ister iyi ister kötü) iyi gerekçeli olduğu açık. Türk oyuncular sizden böyle bir rehberlik aldığı için çok şanslı ve biz de oyunumuzu oynadığınız için çok şanslıyız.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970510454', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1622688523}
review: A dark psychological horror-adventure, Strangeland suffers from rough animations (presumably due to its aging engine) and occasionally spotty voice acting, but delivers an intense, focused point-and-click experience that's well worth its ~5-hour running time. (Your mileage on that front may vary, but it's definitely not a "big" game—which actually works in its favour.) It's a very different game than Wormwood's previous release, the outstanding Primordia, but still a worthy successor.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the balanced but ultimately very generous assessment of both Strangeland and Primordia. We're grateful for your support!

author: {'steamid': '76561198033120341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1622754679}
review:
Being a man now in my mid 30s I remember many things from my childhood. One of the wonderful things I remember is being huddled around the family computer that took a week to boot, with my 2 sisters playing many amazing point-and-click adventure games.

Throughout the game I had to pause and simply admire the world and environment, as I was taken back with the fantastic art style with the little modern twists of newer technology which blended into the world so well. It brought back so much nostalgia for a game that was released only last month by its classic art, environment, story and unnerving music and characters.

So fast-forward to present time, it was now my partner and I huddled around the computer theorising on the main characters and woman's attire, personality traits and mental state and wondering if really we missed a much deeper and darker meaning to this game, it characters and it's ending.

So thank you so much bringing that nostalgia back with this brilliant point-and click adventure game, I would certainly recommend this to anyone who are fans of this genre!
developer_response:
What a fantastic review to read.

Not sure if you listened to the commentary, but needless to say, we have similar experiences growing up on these games, dreaming of making them. It's such an honor to know that we've been able to add such an experience for another.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989328210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1622671648}
review:
I'm must be honest. I bought this game only because of two things:
1. Wormwood studios is awesome (Mark Y. and his dedication to make a great game, and to answer every question and review, is something we need more in this gaming world... but also in the world overall).
2. Primordia is the best point and click adventure in recent history, if not the best one ever made. 

This game, it's good. Characters are crazy, art is dark and tragic (but really well done) and the voice acting is better then most of the movies. The story, I don't see too much attachment to it or any point in it, but that's just me. Probably because Primordia had all of it, so I'm just complaining without no reason. 

Thanks Wormwood once again for another point and click adventure. Hope the next one finds us quicker :)
developer_response: What a kind review. I'm grateful that you played our games, and very flattered by what you wrote.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024253308', 'num_games_owned': 1155, 'num_reviews': 574, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1623489905}
review: A heady, trippy nightmare in the vein of 'I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream' and 'Dark Seed', executed with a very dark and urgent sensibility. A must play.
developer_response: Thank you so much! "Dark and urgent sensibility" is a great turn of phrase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198175931669', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1622307969}
review: A very personal and beautifully put together tale of loss and madness. It's got a definite voice of its own, but it did also remind me of cherished personal favorites such as I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream and Sanitarium. If you are into dark themes and imagery, it's recommended playing. Bonus points for the extensive commentary, it really enriched the experience.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words -- especially coming from someone who developed such a beautiful game as Gibbous!  (Assuming you are not just a fan with that nick; and even then, it means a lot coming from a fan of such a great game!)

author: {'steamid': '76561197997224346', 'num_games_owned': 875, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1622574959}
review: The game drips with an amazing atmosphere from the very beginning. I don't think that it handles the subject matter particularly well, but the presentation is excellent and the overall flow of the game is great. I don't think it reaches the highs of Primordia, but it's an entertaining way to spend a couple of hours.
developer_response: Thanks -- for the review, and for playing both Primordia and Strangeland! We're lucky to have such fans. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198289953705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1622613542}
review: I had a great time with this game. I loved the artwork and dark subject matter. The story was surreal yet engaging, and I found myself genuinely moved by the ending. I never got stuck for long, the soundtrack was really nice, and I found the retro presentation charming. Exactly what I wanted out of an old-school point and click adventure.
developer_response: Thank you so much for your kind words -- I'm especially proud and pleased to hear that the ending moved you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048832862', 'num_games_owned': 1249, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1622593486}
review:
Another fantastic adventure published by Wadjet Eye Games

+ Bleak surreal surroundings 
+ Intriguing story and characters
+ Well balanced and designed puzzles
+ Excellent sound design
+ I really like the implementation of the hint system (it's very immersive and intertwined with the narrative)
+ Superb writing
developer_response: Thanks so much! Glad you liked the game, and grateful you took the time to leave a review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198076542954', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1622430810}
review:
It's a really nice looking game with fantastic voice acting. It's engaging and it poses a lot of interesting questions... but unfortunately, where it falls apart for me, is that it never answers any of those questions. 

At the beginning of the game, nay from the first trailer, it's pretty plain to see you're playing inside the player character's mind and that they're racked with guilt. They kind of treat that like a slow reveal through the game? 

In the end you don't find out any of the answers about who the Stranger is, what really happened, how he's going to move on from this... in the end there's just some little spark of comfort and then nothing. 

Just because something is inscrutable doesn't mean it's good or interesting. It's just an incomplete story.
developer_response: Sorry you had a disappointing experience. It certainly wasn't meant to be inscrutable -- really, it wasn't even meant to be a mystery to be solved, so much as a fairly straightforward story with underlying meaning that players can explore as they want. The does have some options for direct clarity regarding various references and symbols in the game (annotations) and our intentions (commentary), but I'm not sure those features are really responsive to what bothered you, and I'm reluctant to tell you to try them if you didn't enjoy the time you already spent with the game. I think it's possible you would find more to engage with if you did, and might find it a rewarding experience, but it is also entirely reasonable for an unsatisfied player not to want to replay under any circumstances.

author: {'steamid': '76561198844503953', 'num_games_owned': 189, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1622453469}
review: Strangeland has a lot of wonderful features. The artwork is dark and moody, the voice acting is well done and the story (once you figure out what is going on!) is touching. Overall the game is a fascinating insight into a broken psyche. A place many of us have been over periods of lockdowns and being separated from loved ones. The game offers a lesson in being a little kinder to ourselves, to hold those we love (both here and gone), close to our hearts and a reminder that there is darkness in all of us, because there is also light.
developer_response:
"The game offers a lesson in being a little kinder to ourselves, to hold those we love (both here and gone), close to our hearts and a reminder that there is darkness in all of us, because there is also light."

What a beautiful turn of phrase. Thank you for that, and for the lovely review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030972894', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1622587758}
review: Short and sweet game. Parallel worlds reminds me Dark Seed, another horror classic p&c game from the golden era. But it is sad to say that the story and the world is not epic and immersive as Primordia and the soundtrack is not memorable as in that.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed it! Definitely a less epic story.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989545858', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1624060786}
review:
First, I wanted to wait until I finished my first vanilla playthrough of the game before I gave it a review.  Having done so, I *really* wish that there was an option to give something other than a binary "Yes" or "No" recommendation for a game review but since there isn't I'm going to have to give this game a "No."

Now to explain:  I'm a longtime fan of all things adventure game and absolutely loved "Primordia" so this was a day one buy for me.  All the more so when I saw that Wadjet Eye was the publisher.

I was even more excited when I started up the game and started to get into the world of Strangeland. One of my favorite adventure games of last century was "Sanitarium" and the world of Strangeland reminded me immensely of that game.  As time went on, I was even more impressed by the voice acting and the dense references to multiple subjects (the Tarot, Norse Mythology, etc.) that kept me guessing as to what the ultimate 'twist' of the story of the game was going to be, especially in light of the interesting story twists of "Primordia".  That said... The twist never materialized.  At least, not as far as I could tell.  Perhaps if I had played the game with the commentary and/or annotations on it would've been different? 

In my opinion, the strength of adventure games has always been the story.  Some of the most well-beloved point and click adventure games of yesteryear had compelling stories that had people coming back to play them again and again and beautiful graphics, high-quality music and voice acting (where present) are bonuses that enhance the games, but ultimately story is king.

Sadly, story is where this game seems to be weakest.  Don't get me wrong, it's entirely possible that the story of this game might be amazingly thought-provoking and deep, but none of that really seems to have come through without (I'm assuming) having commentary and annotations on.  Honestly, I'm not about to replay the game to find out because the *last* thing I want to do is risk playing the game with those on and find out that the narrative isn't any better even with those additional resources.

tl;dr for those looking for a more concise review of "Strangeland" - The graphics and sound design is a worthy successor to "Primordia", but the plot left me feeling a big 'meh' of apathy.  Am I glad to have played it?  Yes, but I feel could've saved myself a few hours of my life and gotten just as much enjoyment by listening to the DLC OST.



EDIT 06/18/2021:  So after reading the responses to my initial review I sat down and replayed through the game again with the Annotations and Commentary on.  After completing the game again I feel that the game is *far* better and the story is much more comprehensible and stronger with the view behind the proverbial curtain that those offer.

Ultimately my feelings on the game after my second playthrough boils down to this:  

Do I think the game is as good as Primordia was?  No, but the gap in quality between the two isn't as vast as I thought initially.  

Do I feel that I was a bit harsh in my initial reactions to the game?  Possibly.  

I'm still not super-enthused that I was left feeling kind of ambivalent without the added tracks, but on the whole I have to say that I'm changing my review to a "Recommend" because of the Annotations and Commentary that help bridge the gulf.
developer_response:
Thank you for taking the time to write such a thoughtful review, and for playing both Strangeland and Primordia.  I'm very sorry you didn't have a better experience with the game.

I guess I would start by saying there is not a twist.  I do think there is understanding to be gained over the course of the game, but it's not meant to be a reversal story where some apparent premise of the story proves false in a surprising way at the end.  (Notwithstanding your praise of Primordia as having twists, I don't think of it as a "twist" story, either.)  It's unfortunate that the game suggests to players that there will be a twist because, inevitably, that expectation will be disappointed given the story's structure.

As to the commentary tracks, it would be silly for me to say, "You didn't enjoy the game, but you should spend several more hours playing it."  But I would push back a little on the reason you gave for not replaying -- wanting the game to remain in a state of Schrödingerian uncertainty as to whether it would be saved by the commentary and annotations.  I certainly don't want you to think better of our game for not having played it; if the commentary tracks make things worse, or don't make things better, it would be valuable for us to know that.  Conversely, if the annotations and commentary make your experience much better, that, too, would be important to know.

That seems especially so for a "wobbler" review like this one.  I actually think it's good that Steam requires an up or down vote, because it imposes a certain cruel rigor on reviewers, and makes the data easier for other players to read.  But I would be lying if I said that negative reviews don't hurt.  They hurt a lot -- it's personally very hard to read them, they harm the game's marketability, and they discourage other players from playing.  Despite this, I think it is important for players who genuinely dislike a game to leave negative reviews -- truth in advertising is important, and it is better for players to make informed decisions, rather than being drawn into games that they wind up disliking.

Here, when it seems like your reaction to the game was more equivocal, and when your review was very thoughtful and considered, I think it would be worth your resolving your doubts one way or another.

Anyway, let me close where I started: with thanks and an apology!

author: {'steamid': '76561197988876077', 'num_games_owned': 774, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1622121682}
review:
The thing I like the most about point-and-clicks is when they avoid ridiculous alien logic. I am very pleased to report that Strangeland does a great job, most of the time, of avoiding completely illogical puzzle solutions despite the game's nightmarish setting. Even if you do find yourself stuck, there is a very functional, if not somewhat overly abrasive, in-game hint system to help guide you through. The art is hauntingly beautiful, and probably the main draw. The voice-acting is hit or miss, but mostly hit.

Strangeland is a decidedly compact experience. I know it's probably unfair to compare it to the rich and sprawling Unavowed, which is arguably the best point-and-click made in the past decade, but it is a significantly shorter game here. We're talking no more than dozen screens, some of which are later recycled, which all adds up to probably around 3 to 4 hours for a first-play. Some of that play time is also taken up by things people wouldn't be faulted for finding tedious, like unskippable death animation bumpers and the occasional long-walk. It's probably better than a fail-state and a game over, but I did find myself getting annoyed when trying to experiment later in the game. All these things together means that Strangeland may not necessarily come up with a favorable value proposition to you if that proposition is based solely on playtime. I'll also say that, for a game that deals with the themes of death, suicide, self-harm, guilt, and regret; and has so many references to Greek mythology, the story feels a bit.... shallow. There isn't actually a whole lot going on. Despite no doubt being personal, there isn't anything new or revelatory.

I am a fan of the point-and-click genre so I think it's important to support devs that are still making strong entries into the genre, but at the same time I think it's important to recognize the game's flaws. Pick up the game, but temper your expectations.
developer_response: Thank you for the thoughtful, balanced review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080316088', 'num_games_owned': 951, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1622027002}
review: I am not a point & click guy, but the game is very polished and I didn't backtrack and wrestle with UI and design, activities often associated with old school point & click games. Enjoyed the game very much, though the story is quite sad.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998218945', 'num_games_owned': 1765, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1622521790}
review:
[h1][b][i]Um estranho em uma macabra terra estranha..?[/i][/b][/h1]

A princípio, sim. Porém, através de uma aterradora - e incrivelmente interessante - jornada, [i]Strangeland[/i] vai se revelando algo mais do que familiar em seus fantásticos detalhes, e o nosso protagonista torna-se tão íntimo para aquele terrível mundo quanto para nós, meros espectadores daquele carnaval de bizarrices.

Sem nome, sem passado, e sem dignidade alguma, o tal protagonista segue através de cenários pixelados de altíssima qualidade e psicodelia, nos atirando muitas vezes em diálogos e sequências que parecem ter sido inspiradas diretamente em retratações infernais e, claro, no mais puro horror cósmico. Mas não é "apenas" para isso que o jogo existe, afinal todo o lúgubre contexto e enredo será explicado (ou não, mas prometo que pelo menos fará certo sentido) em seus momentos finais. Em muitos momentos parece que estamos a presenciar desconexas mensagens filosóficas que são vomitadas aleatoriamente pelos estranhos personagens do jogo, mas temos que lembrar que a mente do protagonista é o real terreno dessa trama, e o absurdo é o novo normal em Strangeland.

Para quem já conhece o Wormwood Studios vai, logo de cara, remeter esse jogo ao clássico [i]Primordia[/i], afinal - mesmo pertencendo a diferentes gêneros - temos um contexto parecido e uma arte bem peculiar. Acredito que, por isso, alguns esperavam um tipo de sequência da excelente jornada robótica pós-apocalíptica, mas o que temos aqui é algo bem diferente. Eu diria que temos algo muito mais pessoal nessa "estranha" terra, uma história extremamente íntima, que permeia através da autodescoberta e enfrentamento dos seus medos mais profundos. Há um link muito maior entre o jogador e o protagonista, e não é porque ele é humano, mas simplesmente porque a trama evoca filosofias, passagens, estigmas, conflitos e mais uma série de coisas que nos fazem envolver-se muito mais com tudo aquilo.

O jogo possui cenas pesadas, e - eu diria- cruas, em vários sentidos da palavra, mas o contexto demanda isso e, como já mencionei, tudo fará sentido e realmente precisa ser retratado desta forma - pelo menos neste mundo medonho no qual os variados personagens estão inseridos. Mas o que vem a ser esse mundo? Quem são estes personagens tão estranhos e, por vezes, aterrorizantes? Bem, realmente só jogando para tentar entender todo esse contexto no qual somos lançados e o motivo de certas atitudes e situações corriqueiras que iremos presenciar. Mas logo adianto que nem tudo são flores no que diz respeito ao total entendimento da trama, certo? Realmente acredito que isso foi colocado de maneira proposital, e muita coisa aqui não precisa ser realmente compreendida para ser aproveitada. Uma dica: só siga os trilhos e entre pela boca do palhaço quantas vezes forem necessárias.

A jornada aqui é meio curta. Registrei 7 horas de jogatina, porém eu vasculhei praticamente tudo, interagi com todos os personagens, li todos os diálogos e cacei todas as principais conquistas. Então, certamente, daria para finalizar tudo entre 5 e 6 horas se a trama for seguida da forma mais linear possível, ou até menos. Isso é ruim? Claro que não. O jogo nos apresenta muito bem todo o seu contexto e personagens e, principalmente, consegue transmitir a sua mensagem da melhor maneira possível, nos possibilitando até inúmeras interpretações - e, na verdade, é exatamente aqui que o jogo brilha. Então, não desanime pelo fato do jogo ser relativamente curto, pois o conjunto da obra vale cada centavo investido.

Um adventure que nos apresenta uma lúdica jornada da alma travestida de brutais horrores cósmicos. Estranho? Claro, afinal essa é a real intenção de [i]Strangeland[/i].
developer_response: "Sem nome, sem passado, e sem dignidade alguma" - poesia. Como o jogo diz, a vida às vezes pode ser uma agonia, a menos que você possa ver através dos olhos do amor de outra pessoa, e o mesmo se aplica ao desenvolvimento de jogos para mim. Sua revisão significa mais do que posso articular.

author: {'steamid': '76561198360826263', 'num_games_owned': 451, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1623856369}
review:
Recommend for the effort, but honestly I'm disappointed.

The game fails to make me sympathize with the main character; he is merely to be used as a device to solve puzzles and drive the narrative forward. He never feels human enough; he undergoes an allegorical journey but his personality rarely shows, let along develops.

As for the narrative, everything is either too on-the-nose or too irrelevant for me to care about. 30 minutes in and I already knew what this Strangeland was all about, who the woman was and why she kept jumping into the well. On the other hand, there's an NPC in game who keeps quoting and referencing poems and novels and scripts, but little did these references matter; thus all the richness hidden among those texts was reduced to a harmless quirk.
developer_response:
Sorry for your disappointing experience; it's very kind of you to recommend the game all the same.

If I had a bigger brain (or perhaps it's a big heart or soul), I might be able to figure out why the narrative and protagonist connect so deeply for some players and yet feel incredibly meaningless to others. Sadly, I can't figure it out, and can only be grateful when the story lands for some, and grateful for the forgiveness when it doesn't land for others. 

Much love, and sorry again!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993699776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1622516954}
review:
I only just finished my first playthrough, and while I'm not sure I've fully understood the game, the final point the game makes is certainly clear enough. The game has a bittersweet message, and is told in such a captivating way that it's one of the rare games I've played through in one sitting. Some of the writing might be seen as rather on the nose, but it never felt so much so that it ruined anything, leaving the whole falling together nicely.

I don't know that I would recommend this for any seeking a reprieve from gloom, but at the same time...It might be just what one in that situation needs, as Strangeland feels like it understands that and sometimes, when you're down, that kind of understanding can help. Unlike many other games that dabble in despair for cheap scares and terrible messaging, Strangeland doesn't leave one on such a cynical, grim note, and instead speaks to the struggle and the hope that is ever to be found.
developer_response:
"Strangeland doesn't leave one on such a cynical, grim note, and instead speaks to the struggle and the hope that is ever to be found. "

What a beautiful way to put it. Thank you so much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116211741', 'num_games_owned': 920, 'num_reviews': 220, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 772, 'last_played': 1622513134}
review:
Strangeland is a deeply personal game, but the story it tells is universal.

On the surface, Strangeland is a game about a man with a straitjacket and amnesia who wakes up in the fragmented nightmarescape of a defunct carnival floating in the sky.  The carnival is populated by feral dogs and poisonous creatures, features crumbling floors and rusting rides, and at the center of it all is a wishing well where a beautiful woman plunges to her death again and again.  Our protagionist will also die many times while progressing through the carnival - dying is just another way to solve puzzles, and death is fleeting in Strangeland - at least, until it's not.  Our primary goal is to save the woman, and to defeat the mysterious "dark thing" that appears to be the corruption at the heart of the location.  

Below the surface, Strangeland is a game about grief and loss.  In some ways, this game is extremely heavy-handed with its use of metaphor to convey its messages.  In fact, the third act takes some of the main metaphors to the point of being absolutely literal.  But in other ways, the game is very subtle - or, if not subtle, the main story is sufficiently obfuscated by other details that it's not totally knocking you over the head.  I didn't connect what the game was actually [i]about[/i] until very near the end of the game, and I suspect a number of players might miss it altogether despite the hints along the way.

This is a point and click adventure developed by Wormwood Studios, of Primordia fame.  Wormwood is such an intriguing team because of what each of the three members bring to the table.  Victor Pflug, the game's artist and sound designer, has created a grotesque and beautiful darkseed-esque world of beige and purple that I had been itching to explore since some of the concept art dropped a few years ago.  Sound geeks will appreciate some of the funky, crunchy stuff going on with the audio in this game.  Programmer James Spanos further brings this vision to life by pushing the AGS engine in unexpected ways, from adding visual goodies like crackling electricity, reflections, and dust effects, to also designing what appears to be a custom-made save system.  Finally, writer and designer Mark Yohalem brings his trademark hyper-literary approach to dialogue and worldbuilding, with references that are sure to delight English professors or scholars of Norse mythology but enough dry humor to prevent things from becoming too bleak.

Publisher Wadjet Eye Games also contributed to the casting and direction of the voiceovers, and Strangeland is a treat here as well.  Abe Goldfarb is powerful in the leading role; many other familiar voices populate the supporting cast, and there's not one weak performance in the bunch.  

Puzzle-wise, Strangeland has a modern design with puzzles that are for the most part simple and logical, accessible by the majority of gamers, and takes roughly five or six hours to complete.  There are also several minigames sprinkled in, though most of them offer workarounds or alternate solutions if those aren't your thing.  If you get stuck, a built-in hint system will point you in the right direction.  The game features four endings, though clearly one of them is the intended canonical ending.  One of the game's absolute best bits, involving a tarot reading, also has multiple outcomes.  There is replay value, no one could possibly get all of the nuance out of the game with just one playthrough.  If you're really keen to hear more, you can enable a dev commentary mode as well as an "annotation" mode that explains all of the literary references, etc. 

This review ended up being pretty long, but the final verdict is that you should absolutely give this game a shot - unless you have absolutely no stomach for artistic mumbo jumbo or any kind of point and click adventure.  It's an oddball, but it's an extremely well-made one, with lots of care and attention given to each detail, and it's a personal journey that will resonate with many.
developer_response: This is a truly beautiful review. I'm very grateful for it, not least of all for the thoughtfulness in finding a kind word to say about each team member's contributions. Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980339521', 'num_games_owned': 1052, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1622301887}
review:
[h1]不穏で奇妙でユーモラス [/h1]

本作はポイントアンドクリック型のアドベンチャーゲームです。
システムとしては主人公を操作してアイテムを集め、活用して進んでいくというスタンダードなもの。
本作は、そういったアドベンチャーゲームの要となる世界観、キャラクタービルディング、展開、いずれも良く練り込まれています。

ビジュアルデザインはスクリーンショットでご覧になればわかる通り、グロテスクさも感じるかなり不穏なものです。
ギーガー調の悪夢のような世界に、記憶喪失の主人公。ワンクリックで死に至るお手軽さ。妄執を糧に、罵られながらもがくように道を開いていく主人公。
これだけの紹介では、非常に暗いゲームプレイを想起されるかもしれませんが、内容は奇妙に明るいものです。

というのも、登場人物がかなり多彩でユーモラスなのです。会う度にジョークをかましてくる門ピエロや、意味深で軽快な漫談をかましてくる3人娘、盲目の物書きとカラスの奇妙な関係。果ては1人ツッコミの上手い主人公まで、重苦しい世界観とテーマを彩ります。

そのため、筆者の感覚としては「この状況をどうにかしなければ」というよりも、「このアイテムはどんな反応が帰ってくるだろう？」「こうしたら主人公はなんて言うだろう？」という好奇心に突き動かされてプレイしていた感覚でした。

途中のパズル要素なども、物語を邪魔せず、ちょっとしたスパイスになるよう調整されていたように思います。

とにかく全体的に小気味よく、そして奇妙に愛着が湧く作品でした。
見た目の印象が気に入った方、不穏でおかしなキャラクターが好きな方はぜひ、手に取ってみてください。

なお、レビュー執筆時点で本作は日本語未対応。そこそこの文章量なので、英語がわからない方は遊ぶのがなかなか大変だと思われます。
しかしながら、まだ公式には発表されていませんが、日本語対応にも取り組んでいるとのことなので、英語の苦手な方でも楽しめる日が来るかも。期待しています。
developer_response:
嬉しいお言葉ありがとうございます！ 私たちは翻訳に取り組んでいます (非常に初期の段階で)、素晴らしい翻訳者を雇っています。 日本語の翻訳には通常とは異なる課題があります。ひらがなまたはカタカナのみを使用することにはマイナス面もありますが、漢字を使用することには大きな技術的困難があります。 これらを克服し、日本のプレイヤーにふさわしい翻訳を提供できることを願っています。 

(Hopefully Google translate managed that!)

author: {'steamid': '76561197976028334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 330, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1622349390}
review:
Strangeland is decent. It's a surreal point and click adventure that clearly takes place  inside someone's mind. There is a lot of heavy symbolism in the characters and environments. After finishing it, I can't exactly tell you what the point of the story was. It's some kind of Jungian story. The antagonist is the shadow self of the protagonist who despite a surly attitude, is actually quite helpful. 

The actual game play was decent. The puzzles weren't that tough. Usually when I'd get stuck it was because I missed a screen that I didn't realize existed. The phone number puzzle was the only that really had me stuck. There's a pay phone in the game where if you dial the operator you'll get a hint as to what to do next. The guy on the line yelled at me how to figure it out. There was one part I full-on needed to look at the solution to. As it turns out, there was glitch with the game that wasn't letting me progress. Playing this game right at launch does come with some hazards. 

The graphics is completely pixel art and the aesthetic is surreal nightmare. I really like the pixel art style. It works well for Wadjet Eye games. The cut scenes are all really high-res pixel art that always looks fantastic and visually interesting. 

The game is really short. There are some achievements that somewhat encourage multiple play throughs. There is also developer commentary that may have me dipping back in to hear it. However, a single play through took me under 4 hours. 

Overall, Strangeland is a decent game and I do recommend to genre fans. I don't think this one of the best Wadjet Eye games and will likely be forgotten quickly. I enjoyed my time with it, but it was short and nothing that special.
developer_response: Thanks for giving the game a go, and sorry you didn't enjoy it more.  What was the glitch you mentioned? I haven't seen mention of it, and it would be great to fix it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122905879', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1622407796}
review:
It's difficult to give Strangeland a negative review. I would prefer something more nuanced because some of the individual pieces are very good. The art, as with Primordia, is stunning. Most of the puzzles are clever but reasonable. All together, however, the game is systematically dragged down by the sophomoric delivery of the story.

The protagonist's voice acting is technically fine, but the writing lacks nuance for the actor to work with. His bland reactions give the player very little to work with in understanding the protagonist's plight. His lack of identity makes what is ultimately a very personal story about savage and deep emotional pain fall completely flat. This isn't a complaint that the protagonist's history isn't fleshed out. There's simply no indication that the character on screen is suffering, confused, or even annoyed by the reality he finds himself in.

The flaw bleeds into the plot. There's simply not much to work with. It's not the simplicity of the plot, so much as it is how each moment is sped through as quickly as possible. There's no time given to chew on any particular emotion or allow the protagonist to process the deeper meaning of his journey. The protagonist is never allowed to think or feel deeply. The ending falls flat not because the themes are too nuanced or the visuals don't communicate enough. It fails because without context it's a shallow and obvious resolution.

The story is simple and the themes universal to the human condition. This isn't the first time anyone has ruminated on them. To make it interesting, to make it really hit home, you've got to bring something specific to the table. If I'd learned anything about the protagonist, I might have been able to both judge and empathise. This isn't a demand for some sort of prologue or melodramatic scene in a hospital. However, without a compelling protagonist it falls to the setting to do the communication.

The setting suffers from the same issues. Despite the truly well done art, the content doesn't communicate enough to compensate for the plot. The set pieces are often almost generic in how little they mean to the plot. Since the writing falls back on the visuals to elaborate, and they elaborate on very little, it makes things feel more shallow than they otherwise would be.

In many ways, Strangeland feels like a demo. It's a short game, but there's no shortage of interesting screens and puzzles. What's lacking is context. A real reason for the player to relate to and want to explore with the protagonist. Some questions asked of the audience and the opinions of the creators reflected in their creation. Strangeland has a less interesting take on loss and guilt than the average sulky teenager's diary. The writing isn't even bad, it's just not there. Given such a short and mechanically simple game, there's just not much of anything at all.

There's many games and creative teams that aren't worthy of this much critique and that's what makes this difficult. If they hadn't already made Primordia, I wouldn't have written this review. If Strangeland had been filled with crude humour or the casual sociopathy of many other adventure games, I wouldn't have written this review. Unfortunately, this game demands to be taken seriously and fails as a result.
developer_response:
Sorry you had such a disappointing experience with the game, especially given the overall goodwill you've shown toward both it and us. It's the job of the story and the game to find the player, not vice versa, so when things don't pan out, there isn't really any explanation or argument to be offered in response, just an apology that the game was enticing enough to get you to invest yourself in it, and then unsatisfying once you did. Obviously, it's tricky to tell a story that lands with everyone, and perhaps even trickier when the story and its imagery is personal to the team (which may lend a certain inflexibility or idiosyncrasy), but that doesn't change the outcome.

I appreciate your giving Strangeland a chance, and sharing your thoughts. Sorry again for the disappointment.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994782386', 'num_games_owned': 981, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1621972522}
review:
Игра сама по себе весьма достойная и атмосферная, хотя очень короткая.
Признаться, от авторов великолепной "Primordia", работавших над своей второй игрой почти десять лет, хотелось бы видеть что-нибудь более масштабное.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040528007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1622342152}
review:
The obvious part is, it's an amazing and surreal game, it's easy to play, offering enough hints (I bless thee hint system!) that you don't need to look at a walkthrough to finish the game.

But the story, oh my what a beautiful story. I don't wanna spoil it, but there's many of us here that will without a doubt relate to it.

The devs have done amazing job.
The writers have done an amazing job.
And Dave Gilbert did an amazing job with the voices for the game (and whoever cast the people)

It has beyond exceeded my expectactions. A game worth every penny if not more.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this lovely review -- it means the world to hear that our game connected with you and other players!
