author: {'steamid': '76561198013048477', 'num_games_owned': 1556, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1622340499}
review:
I feel bad not recommending this game, because a lot of things are very good about it, and the devs seem very lovely, but I feel the need to because it's getting such universal praise I feel like that may have given me higher expectations than the game could deliver and perhaps seeing this will let someone else like me temper their expectations. 

The story never clicked, and while I will try to play it again with commentary and such on, because I want to give it a chance and see what everyone likes so much, I found it obvious and somewhat heavy handed. After talking to one or two characters you'll likely know how the story will play out, twists included, and while there is some interesting and fun visuals there aren't enough of them to carry the game alone. While some people will probably call it concise, I felt like the game really suffered for it's 2-3 hour story, as I feel like it really could have done some more, and developed or given me a little more to latch onto with the protagonist, as he comes across as gormless rather than in denial for a lot of it. The mystery and confusion really does seem what the devs were going for, but I think it was a big miss here. The gist of what was going on was obvious enough to me (characters literally tell you) that it really just left me uninterested in the protagonist. 

Honestly at the end of the day, the price is right, and you might love it, but just be aware that I'd say it's somewhat overrated. Having said all that, I probably will buy a third game by the Wormwood lads, I just hope that it will have a little more meat on its bones.
developer_response:
Let me start by saying (1) I'm very sorry you didn't enjoy it and (2) thanks for sharing this review. I think it's important that negative as well as positive reactions are shared, since the last thing I ever want is someone to feel "tricked" into buying the game. I always want our games to be a value proposition for players -- they put their hope, time, and money into it, and we need to give them something substantial in return.

I do hope you try it with the commentary on. As I said to someone else, it's a bit of an outrageous suggestion -- "You don't like the food? Well, here's a second helping, on the house." But it is at least possible the commentary will shift your view. I would not say that mystery was what we were shooting for; uncertainty, yet, but not mystery per se. As you note, the game tells you the basic scenario right away. I would say it is more a matter of dramatic irony:  the player knows what's going on, but the protagonist doesn't. Obviously, that doesn't work for everyone and didn't work for you. But the commentary might at least illuminate what we were trying to do, and provide some additional thematic fodder. (The annotations, too, elaborate on the various references throughout.)

Anyway, this is a longwinded way of saying that I'm bummed you didn't enjoy the game more, but grateful that you gave it a shot and took the time to share your thoughts. Much love.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994297497', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1622410833}
review:
I have had a long standing love affair with point & click titles, starting back with King’s Quest, Space Quest, the Monkey Island series, and the like. I *loved* Primordia, being a solid callback to the feel and style of the classics. As a veteran of these titles and more, I have to say….
Strangeland is incredible.
Couple trigger warnings in the game. Themes of suicide, death, loss, depression, etc. If you’re susceptible to these things, this may not be the game for you. And, fair warning to those with coulrophobia, like any good carnival, there are clowns….or things that look like them.
Surreal, psychological, and bleak beyond belief, intriguing, well written, a nightmare from the start, this game is a journey like no other I’ve experienced.
 You wake on a floating mass that is best called a carnival from hell. I’m saying Zdunich would be proud, here. You’re this confused, lost soul of a man, memory lost, and your first sight is a woman falling/jumping to her death, beyond your control. Spoilers? Nah, we’re a minute in, here.
Everywhere has details, characters, creatures, little nuggets to unearth, interact with, and learn about. And everything, I mean EVERYTHING, is connected. You’ll learn through play exactly how, and how much.
This world oozes Escher, Geiger, Lovecraft, and a pinch of the surreal called to mind with some of King’s work. All rendered in gorgeous 360p pixel art created with immaculate skill, and dedicated love to the classic looks of its predecessors. Improving on the steps of its forebears, the animation is flawless, no jerkiness, and some small animations, like hair movement, or cloth rustling add a beautiful touch of the modern to this classic style.
Again, fair warning, this game is mature themed, full of things that may scare, disturb, or otherwise jar the unwary.
The only flaw I can offer is this: with the bleak colours, some interactive objects are a little difficult to locate, or even know they exist. The game does ABSOLUTELY improve on some classic tropes, where death doesn’t set you back terribly far, the lack of moon logic is wondrous to behold, and everything (eventually) makes perfect sense. Even dying is a mechanic, not a setback.
Puzzles are difficult, but all completely available with in-game information, and you can always dial the operator for help, if you need it. The voice acting is phenomenal (at least in the English translation). And while not for everyone, and likely actively bad for some, the bleak, dark, oppressive tone holds through the entire game without becoming tiresome, cumbersome, or overwhelming. And the story makes PERFECT sense.
And, as a bonus, at least one of the creators, one of the writers, (I can only vouch for the one), is very friendly, responsive, and a delight to talk to, even in the limited way I was able to do so.
All in all, I give this a solid (and surprising) 9.5/10.
Wormwood, keep it up. I can’t wait to see what more you can do.
developer_response: Thank you so much for the detailed and lovely review. It's incredibly gratifying to read such kind things said about our game. We're grateful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055089121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1659655385}
review:
TL;DR 10/10

I don't normally leave reviews for games but I felt that this game deserved more from me than to be just another silent player. On that note I apologize if this review feels scattered or lacking. My friend told me about Primordia around 6 months ago and when he told mid-April that Strangeland would be released this month I immediately wishlisted it. 

Regarding gameplay I think that Strangeland did an excellent job of removing the typical obstacles I find dissuade me from adventure games. I truly appreciate being able to double click screen edges to travel immediately to the next room without having to wait and watch my slow ass walk across the room. The puzzles never felt obtuse or frustrating in a sense that I never felt like I had to try every conceivable item combination on every object with my favourite being the "Wanton One".

The voice acting and superb writing fleshed out the characters beautifully. Going through the game a second time with the annotations enabled is a must for any player, as the breadth and depth of its literary and cultural references is truly astonishing and admirable in its scope. 

The soundscape and visuals throughout are awesome. It truly helped evoke a sense of horror in some scenes to hear things like the almost purring sound during the interaction with the Teratoma, which created particularly memorable moments in the game. 

I am probably going to play this game off and on again for a long time because it's so dense with references, allusions, and metaphors that there will likely be something that has thus far gone unnoticed to take away and appreciate even after several playthroughs. 

This is a great game that I would recommend to anyone who can handle it's darker themes and I want to say Thank You to the team at Wormwood Studios for creating it and sharing it with players.
developer_response:
Thank you so much for this thoughtful and generous review. I'm especially pleased to hear you liked "Wanton One," a puzzle that has frustrated some other players.

You're very kind for taking the time to write your thoughts, and we're grateful you played our games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003199347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1622319299}
review:
As close to art as games have ever gotten as far as I'm concerned. From the writing, to the music, to the visuals, to the puzzles. It rhymes, it reasons, and it does everything a piece like this should.
Be prepared for a dark trip - it is what the promotional material makes it out to be. But it's very worth it, and it does have a light at the end of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998380266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1622314561}
review:
Really good game, as expected from the developers of Primordia.
Art style is amazing and the atmosphere in the game is bleak and mysterious. I would even go as far as to call it Existential Horror, with touches of Cosmic Horror. 

It's a bit shorter than Primordia but I feel like there's still some replay value here if you like to get all the dialogues and endings.
developer_response: Who knew that we were just waiting for Godot and these kind words? :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198036273285', 'num_games_owned': 2273, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1622272697}
review:
Excelente juego de aventura point and click, con una historia muy interesante, actuación de voz de primera y  una dirección artística genialmente grotesca (los diseños de los personajes y de escenarios son de lo mejor, se nota el cuidado que le pusieron). 
Aclaración: el juego requiere un nivel decente del inglés ya que no viene (al momento de escribir esta reseña) traducido al español, esto puede ser un problema ya que el juego usa una gran cantidad de metáforas y expresiones que te van a perder bastante si no manejas muy bien el idioma. Remarco especialmente un puzzle en el que se ve este problema: [spoiler] En el puzzle del número de teléfono para llamar a la Valquiria, un personaje te va a dictar un número e intercala la palabra "wanton", cuya pronunciación es la clave para resolverlo (wan = won = 1 ; ton = ten = 10 [/spoiler]
developer_response:
Muchas gracias por tus amables palabras. Estamos trabajando en una traducción al español en este momento con el mismo excelente traductor que manejó Primordia, mi buen amigo "walas". El español es el único idioma más allá del inglés en el que puedo comunicarme, así que estoy ansioso por que nuestro juego se pueda jugar en español.

Como puedes imaginar, ese acertijo en particular le está dando dolor de cabeza a walas, pero tiene algunas ideas creativas sobre cómo traducirlo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084284469', 'num_games_owned': 898, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1658421456}
review:
[h1] 現在公式日本語ローカライズ進行中 [/h1]
現在、公式で日本語翻訳/ローカライズを担当させていただいてます。ゲームエンジンの特性などもあり、日本語ローカライズは前途多難ですが、協力的な開発者さんで前向きに試行錯誤中です。リリース時期は未定。Twitterで定期的に情報公開予定です。2021/05/31

今作のゲームデザインとシナリオを手掛けたライターのマーク・ヨハレム氏は、欧米の「最も哲学的で物語性の濃いゲームランキング」で必ず上位に入る “Planescape: Torment” の続編 “Planescape: Tides of Numenera” にもライターとして参加していました。本人も「今作は出来る限り軽いタッチにしつつも寓意的に...」というゲーム内のコメンタリーで肩っていますが、ほとんどの現代日本人にはかなり重厚な内容です。それゆえに、人を選ぶ作品にはなりますが、ハマる人はガッツリハマる傑作になっています。

ゲームジャンル：ポイント＆クリック・アドベンチャー / ホラー (ジャンプスケア要素無し)

[b] オススメ・ポイント [/b]
①なんといってもこのビジュアルスタイル/アートが好みの方は『買い』です。

②ウィットに富んだパズルや台詞＝現状では英語が理解できることが必須
(古い文献からの引用も多いため、英語の難易度は高めです。また、ダジャレや韻文なども多いです)

③『聖書』から『北欧神話』まで、『デカルト』から『サルトル』、『ニーチェ』まで、『ウォッチメン』から『ナイトメア・ビフォア・クリスマス』まで...メインカルチャーからサブカルまで、開発者への影響をバチバチと感じる引用やパロディが含まれています。これがハマる人にはガッツリ楽しめる。

有名どころで言うと、LucasArtsのアドベンチャーゲームや、ホラーゲームの名作『Sanitarium』、『I Have No Mouth But I Must Scream』のような雰囲気です。

[b] 自分が日本語同時通訳実況した動画はこちらです、雰囲気を観ていただければと思います!! [/b]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zUzp8zHH7uY&t=768s
developer_response: とても親切な言葉をありがとう、そして翻訳のお手伝いをしてくれてありがとう。 ものすごく大変な仕事になりますが、言葉はすべてあなたの手の中にあります。

author: {'steamid': '76561198008625210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1622299549}
review:
A new and thick aesthetic successor to Wadjeteye's last big game - but not a sequel. A deep and tangled world of puzzles drenched in mood that will surely please fans of Primordia. It did for me. Narratively, the game suffers from from being overly cerebral, nonsensical, and not wholly relatable. Perhaps because it is a painful self-exploration done by the author that they have chosen to share with us. If you approach the game with that mindset, the story is more easily appreciated. 

My message to Victor: Thank you. I would love to go back to primordia again, I loved the lore, and I miss Nathaniel Chambers' music too! But Strangeland is now a proud part of my collection, and for about 5 hours, I and many others shared in your pain. Wishing you well for future projects.
developer_response: Thanks so much!  I'll pass your kind words along to Victor. We also loved working with Nathaniel, but for this game, it was important that all the mood come from the three of us. As you say, it was very personal (and painful), and we didn't think we could necessarily outsource that processing...

author: {'steamid': '76561199174214094', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1622292093}
review:
It's my first time playing a Wormwood Studios game, and boy, was I impressed. I've only recently become familiar with Wadjet Eye Games and their illustrious pedigree of adventure titles, playing both The Shivah and Gemini Rue in the last year. Strangeland has to be another golden (sometimes literally) highlight in that lineup. Unfortunately, I've never played Primordia, the developer's last title, but I'll be picking that up shortly after posting this review.

At first glance, Strangeland offers a scorched blend of Lynchian/Jungian/Giger-esque aesthetic and philosophical archetypes, beautifully crafted and placed, but they betray a game with a very human and existential heart. Rich with symbolism through and through, there's heaps of referential meat to gnaw at here, and I can imagine that analysis of the very many motifs to be found in Strangeland will make at least one enthusiastic YouTube creator very popular within this niche. That said, I'm not sure if carefully sifting through every theme this game tries to represent would be a good approach, as the narrative strikes me as more poetic than a point-by-point plot to be perfectly mapped. Writing like that is always at danger of disappearing into its own behind, but Strangeland never tries to make its themes or conversations inaccessible for the sake of it, rather, with a little thinking, the deceptive polemics flying in all directions are relatively easy to decipher from a tired, emotive point of view.

Unfortunately, the gameplay isn't always as enjoyable, as its puzzle solutions are regularly quite obvious and only sometimes require memorization, or creative and lateral thinking. The 'How to Play' section explains that it's never the developer's intention to gate access to content via artificial difficulty or embarrassing leaps of logic, and that's great, but I wish the game made me work for my progress a little more. You can call a guide via the payphone in the game and sometimes they'll give you direct instructions if you're stuck. I might be a tired boomer, but I miss when adventure games wouldn't hold your hand so readily, especially in a setting that does all it can to present itself as toxic, nullifying, nihilistic, and always laughing at your ignorance. It feels like there's a disconnect there. Nothing you do feels like busywork however, and I applaud the fact that there are sometimes multiple ways in which to solve a problem.

That said, the game's narrative is expertly done, paced well (despite my gripes above), and features another standout performance by Abe Goldfarb, bringing that forlorn-gravel-greatness in every game I hear him in. What looks like a tremendously hollow and painful adventure game reveals itself as a mature response to the trauma of life, affirmative without being afraid to look reality in the eye.

This attitude is also embodied in Wormwood's approach to the relationship between [url=https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/1369520/view/3042722832284843123]developers and players.[/url] I don't feel overly assumptive when I say - this is the kind of studio you want to be creating games.

Strangeland is worth your time.
developer_response:
I get great joy from every review (even negative ones) because of the generosity it shows for a player to take the time not only to play a game, but to share his or her thoughts about it.

But this review in particular made me especially happy. It's goofy to say that a review praising your game is "fair," but this does strike me as fairness lovingly expressed. The critique in the third paragraph is thoughtful, and it certainly resonates with me. I also like challenging puzzles, and share some of the concerns you have -- the question is how to craft puzzles that are challenging and complicated, but fair and well signaled. The game starts with a call from an antagonist who tells the player-character -- in different terms -- that he's bad at the three pillars of adventure gameplay (finding hotspots, collecting items, and solving puzzles), so you're right that there's a disconnect if the player then cruises through the puzzles. :)

That said, I do think we did a good job of having the puzzles/solutions thematically integrated, plausible to the setting and protagonist, and reasonably well cued (though there are a couple places some players seem to get stuck), and there are two or three that still demand lateral thinking. :D

Anyway, this is a long-winded way, via engaging with your thoughtful points, of saying thank you. I loved your review, and I'm grateful for players like you and others who take the time to share their thoughts with us.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017941011', 'num_games_owned': 405, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1622016550}
review: I was so confused by this game, but it still retained my interest by just how strange it was. Got yelled at by the operator a lot but still enjoy it.
developer_response: Ha! Thanks for the kind words, and for playing our game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997383728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1622150777}
review:
Well this was a way better game than I expected!!! It has a lot attention to detail, the narrative was amazing and it got to me really hard. I almost lost my job cause I lost track of time inside your game!! 

Moreover, I love the fact that despite many parts of the game repeat (at least IMHO) it always felt like I was just going towards the right path to continue the game - and even though certain actions were essentially the same, it felt brand new and refreshing in my eyes. I found myself engrossed in the plethora of reactions to my clicks.

The music was perfect! Especially when you talk to the Scribe early in the game, and when you get to the last part of the game.
developer_response:
What a lovely review -- except for the part about almost losing your job! We're hoping to make games that *enrich* your life, not games that make you go broke. :D

You picked my two favorite music tracks, though, like you, I love them all. The Scribe was by Vic (also the artist and sound guy, who did almost all the music) and the ending was the rare instance in which the track is also work from James (the coder, who is also an accomplished composer in his own right). I passed your kind words along to them, as they are slightly less neurotic than I am about reading every review. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198150504460', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1622241616}
review:
Aynı geliştirici ekibin elinden 2012'de çıkan Primordia'dan tam 9 yıl sonra aramıza katılan Strangeland, gerçekten de isminin hakkını fazlasıyla veren bir yapım olmuş. Tuhaflık, henüz ilk dakikadan itibaren oyuncuyu karşılıyor ve oyunun sonuna kadar da kendisinden ödün vermeden devam ediyor. Buna örnek vermesi açısından (merak etmeyin major bir spoiler değil) **mesela oyuna ilk başladığımızda koskoca bir palyaço kafasından içeri giriyoruz, sonrasında ölüyoruz sonra bi daha giriyoruz bi bakıyoruz ki kafamız yok, kendi kafamızla konuşuyoruz**. Bunun gibi durumlar karşısında ''Lan noluyo'' diye sürekli bir Sedat Peker tepkisi vererek devam etmek oldukça ilginç bir deneyim yaşatıyor. Kaldı ki Source Code tarzı bu türden deneyimler yaşamanın, bizleri oyuna daha da perçinlediği kanaatindeyim. 

Şimdiiii, kaybettiğimiz eşimizin imgeleriyle başlayan görüntüler, ana karakterimizin içsel çatışmalarının birtakım somut nesnelere aktarılmasıyla harmanlanarak bizi oyun boyunca kendi dünyasına çekmeye devam ediyor (ulan ne cümle kurdum kendim bile anlamadım he). Bu durum size de bir şey çağrıştırıyor mu ? Evet, oyunumuz Silent Hill 2'den birçok etmeni bünyesinde barındırıyor, buradan da tahmin edeceğiniz üzere oyunumuz psikolojik gerilim türünde. Bu ögeler arasında göze çarpan başlıca konular ise kesinlikle atmosfer ve müzikler. Sürekli tedirgin eden, rahatsız eden bir ortam ve ambiyans var. Yine benzer bir konu olarak ise; kayıplar, trajedi ve içsel çöküşlerin oluşturduğu melankoliyi söyleyebilirim. Nasıl ki Primordia cıvıl cıvıl sevimli bir oyun ise Strangeland onun tam aksine çok daha depresif ve melankolik bir yapım olmuş. İkisi de ele aldığı konuları oldukça güzel işlemiş yapımlar, yani bu türe ilginiz varsa Primordia'yı da denemenizi tavsiye ederim. Benim ayrıca değinmek istediğim iki konu var biri sanat tasarımı diğeri ise metinlerin doluluğu. Muhteşem yani diyecek başka bir söz bulamıyorum, bir tane dahi boş bir diyaloğa rastlamadım. Psikolojiden mitolojiye dek uzanan ve sürekli oyuncuyu düşündürüp, beyin fırtınası yapmaya teşvik eden repliklere sahip. İçerisinde barındırdığı bu repliklerde karşılaştığım bilmediğim bazı terimleri de araştırarak onlarca yeni bilgi öğrenmiş oldum. Bu da benim açımdan çok olumlu bir durum. Yani oyunumuz kısa, öz ve adeta her bir sahnesi ilmek ilmek işlenmiş. 

Son olarak ben yaşamış olduğum bu güzel tecrübeden oldukça tatmin olmuş şekilde ayrılıyorum. İndirim beklemenizi gerektirecek bir durum yok, sadece sanatsal tasarım yani bir ''artbook'' olarak bile sunulsa bu paraya fazlasıyla değecek bir eser olmuş. Wormwood Studios'un oyun sektöründe hak ettiği yerlere gelmesi ve daha çok içerik üretmesi gerektiğini düşünüyorum. Bu sebeple türü seviyorsanız ve hikayesi üzerine de kafa yorarım diyorsanız oyunu satın alarak bu küçük geliştirici ekibe destek olabilirsiniz. Ayrıca böylesine emek kokan bir yapımın ülkemizde çok çok makul bir fiyattan satışa sunulması da ayrı bir teşekkür sebebi.
developer_response: Beğenmenize ve sizin için çok önemli olmasına çok sevindim. Türk oyunculardan gördüğümüz sıcaklık ve destek konusunda her zaman son derece şanslıydık -- gerçekten de Primordia'nın yayınladığı en sevdiğim haber bir Türk dergisindeydi (Level) ve az önce gerçekten güzel bir yayın izledim. İstanbul'un bir başka vatandaşı. Yıllar önce Türkiye'de biraz zaman geçirdim ve bu deneyimden çok zengin olarak ayrıldım. Bana bu kadar güzel anılar yaşatan bir ülkenin insanlarına küçük bir mutluluk sunmayı düşünmek beni mutlu ediyor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042215573', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1622284598}
review:
:(
edit (since the developer was kind enough to read through reviews, its only fair i give the game a serious one) :
The game worked great as a nostalgia trip for someone who loved the retro point and click games such as the Monkey Island series, which is my standard for the genre since its what i grew up with. It also resonates with the different surreal/horror(esque) p&c games i played more recently such as The Cat Lady, where the setting is in a strange and unfriendly enviroment, despite it being mostly a part of your head. I loved the world where the game was set, it always felt so enveloping, and so did the story.
The world creation was amazing, and the attention to detail was great, forcing me to speak to everybody and try everything everywhere, just to get to hear every single interaction, one line joke or complaint about me making stupid combinations that the developers were keen to add.
I cant recommend this game enough to those that enjoy surreal worlds and games with a deep story, since Strangeland does not dissappoint.
developer_response:
The rare time when a sad face review is not necessarily bad...

[HA! Just saw the longer review. Many thanks for those words, too!]

author: {'steamid': '76561198008176023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1622284151}
review:
On par with Primordia, just stranger. The optional hint system is well integrated, although I would have preferred them in riddles at first, to prevent the sense of hand-holding. Expect a well-told story of mystery and metaphors that can be a bit in-cohesive at times.

The game is fairly short, but worth it nonetheless.
developer_response:
Thanks so much -- especially glad that you liked Primordia, too, and found both games good.

The hint system was really tricky to calibrate. A substantial number of players found Primordia's more elaborate and subtle hint system frustrating, so I opted for a more direct approach here. A nudge first might've been better, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059103761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1622266759}
review:
A well-written, unique, heartfelt and compelling psychological horror from the best studio for point and click adventure games - Wajdet Eye Games just don't miss!  If you're looking for a well designed and compact yet satisfying experience, Strangeland is a great choice.  I felt really transported into its abstract world and enjoyed the puzzles which are more logical than the world they occupy.  I also haven't been so oddly attached to an anthropomorphic fire since Calcifer.

+ Distinct and unforgettable visual style
+ Outstanding music and sound
+ Perfect voice acting
+ Homages to classic games such as Sanitarium
+ Puzzles are not overly frustrating and things tend to come together well
+ Perfect length for a game of its type and price (6-7 hrs)
+ Genuinely funny, with some dark and macabre humour!

- Some will want a longer game; I don't consider this a flaw, not every game needs to be 100 hrs.
- Abstract story won't be for everyone - I highly recommend giving it a go though!
developer_response: Thanks for the very kind words -- and the reference to Calcifer, which brought a smile to my face.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142945697', 'num_games_owned': 145, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1622258103}
review:
rating: 6/10

I am a fan of Wadjet Eye's releases but I feel like this game was one of their weaker ones. Wormwood did an amazing job on Primordia (My first introduction to Wadjet Eye's releases) but Strangeland left a lot to be desired. Not saying it was bad, but compared to other titles Wadjet Eye have released and Primordia it wasn't as enjoyable. There are two reasons why I say this:
1. The story is too subjective. This isn't inherently a bad thing when it comes to games but I think it suits other genres better. I like point and click games that are conclusive, a tiny narrative that you can track the start and the end of. In Strangeland it feels as if the game starts halfway through the story and then ends at the climax. You spend a lot of the game learning about his past in a very indirect manner. [spoiler] After finishing the game all I know for certain is that he lost his wife and is now struggling with the aftermath [/spoiler]. I was disappointed when I reached the end of the game and it offered little to no explanation of the circumstances that led to this occurring. The only thing keeping my interest throughout the game was figuring out the aforementioned circumstances but- that never happened. It just left me unsatisfied. I plan to replay the game though, maybe I will pick up on things I missed on my first playthrough. 
2. Because of the nature of the story, traditional logic doesn't apply well. There were a lot of puzzles which did not feel very intuitive. Combine this with the esoteric nature of the game (When I replay this I'm going to have an encyclopedia handy) and you end up feeling a little lost from time to time. It wasn't that the puzzles were difficult, some of them just felt very absurd (But I guess that matches the story). I managed to get through the game without using the hint payphone too much though, so it isn't too bad ( [spoiler] Used it when collecting the last spirit, prior to attaining the torch I wasn't able to interact with the shooting gallery so I just wrote that area off. Also used it to start the spirit hunt in the first place because I was too fixated on bringing the bare torch to the engine to ignite it [/spoiler] ).

The art, soundtrack, overall atmosphere, puzzle mechanics, and voice acting were amazing though.
developer_response: Thanks for the thoughtful and thorough review, and for playing both Strangeland and Primordia -- really appreciate the support!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006004664', 'num_games_owned': 982, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1622226307}
review:
Loved Primordia, liked Strangeland.
The visuals are mesmerising and the soundtrack is haunting.
Those things I cherish the most to fully immerse myself into the game.
And I also was fully into the story. Digging into every detail that I could: the characters, dialogue and all the interactions that were available to me.

I was a bit disappointed that there were not much of different choices that I could take. For every decision I thought to myself: "Could I have done something else? Did I just do a good thing?"
But it was not that kind of game, which I started to appreciate more as I kept playing.
I loved the path that the main character went through, but I didn't really connect with him that much to enjoy the ending. That'd be the hardest thing to explain without spoilers, so be warned, but I'll try to keep them vague anyway.
So [spoiler] I understood the whole gist of the Strangeland, the place, but I still couldn't stop thinking that by doing all the questionable deeds I missed all the good choices I could take to help other characters, and so I went more and more deep into the abyss, on the way to the worst ending. But all those actions turned out good for the main character and pushed him through to the end. And the thing is: I didn't feel like it was deserved. There was a catharsis, but I didn't feel it. [/spoiler]

Aside from that there are a lot of things I missed because I haven't read many classic books, so I'm gonna enjoy replaying the game with the right expectations this time (and also with Annotation mode that let's you see how the classics are referenced and drawn inspiration from).

Oh, and the voice over is amazing. I was ecstatic to hear familliar voices!
Thanks for another brilliant game!
developer_response: Thanks for the kind assessment as to both our games!  I'm curious as to whether your views change (for better or for worse!) playing it again with annotations/commentary.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988671582', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1622305594}
review:
Initially grossed out by the... well, strange look of the game, I still decided to give it a try since I'm a big fan of Primordia.
And I'm glad I did.

Playing the game, its atmosphere actually felt engrossing and well thought out. And not like some kind of "horror museum" as I initially feared. The game definitely felt unique and personal and it's something that I love to see. Some of the artwork look really beautiful. Gross, but beautiful.

The story might lean a bit too heavily on metaphors and such (most of them probably flew over my head) but in the end, what's happening becomes clear anyway and it feels worth it to have braved all this insanity alongside the main character.

The puzzles were fine and made sense, I barely had to use the convenient help system incorporated in the game.

In the end, while it didn't wow me as much as Primordia, Wormwood Studios still managed to surprise me with another good game that felt quite different from their previous one. It makes me wonder what they could have in store for us in the future!
developer_response: Very glad you enjoyed, and that you are such a fan of Primordia! Thanks for the kind review.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970429479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1622207601}
review:
Atmospheric and surreal, with a well-refined point and click interface, this is an nicely crafted game and I would definitely recommend for fans of the genre. If you've played Primordia and are expecting more of the same story-wise you may be a little disappointed, as this is a less literal world that has been created with more abstract mysteries to uncover,  characters speak in riddles and a lot is left to interpretation (I found similarities in terms of the narrative to that of Fran Bow). There are literary and mythological references that I got (and probably others that I didn't) which add to the texture, but I don't think are necessary to understand to enjoy the story as a whole.

The puzzles, whilst often involving strange applications of physical objects are consistent in their approach and make sense in the world they inhabit, so feel logical and never frustrating. There are a couple of more simplistic "click to make shapes" puzzles, that don't quite fit the aesthetic of the world, but this is a minor quibble. 

Overall a very enjoyable gaming experience for which you get out what you invest in the narrative - there is a lot that is up for interpretation and analysis, for those that want to, but this may not suit others that prefer a less figurative story line with a more defined setup and outcome.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind, and balanced, review! Glad you enjoyed the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197960425408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1689801729}

author: {'steamid': '76561198096889697', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1622119905}
review:
[i][b]A Dark Nothing...[/b][/i]

[i]Полагаю, есть в этом что-то поэтическое, что именно создатели, на мой взгляд, лучшей игры для Wadjet Eye (Primordia) - умудрились создать и самую слабую. У игры, конечно, есть плюсы! Это художественная составляющая (хоть многое и клишированно, но сделано это добротно), музыка, адекватный геймплей... Всё это вкупе создает необычную и интригующую атмосферу, в которую хочется вникнуть, которую хочется распутать.

Но c каждой новой минутой игры я всё сильнее понимал, что за всей этой ультра-сюрреалистической ширмой вас ждет - a dark NOTHING. Лично для меня это стало большим разочарованием. Если вам нравятся, так скажем, "сюжетно-цельные" адвенчуры по примеру Primordia, Gemini Rue, Shardlight и прочие, то я советую пройти мимо этой игры. Если же вы способны в адвенчуре поставить сюжет на третьестепенное место и получать удовольствие только от интересной стилистики, то можете попробовать.[/i]
developer_response:
По крайней мере, мы достигли поэтической справедливости, если не поэтического произведения. : /

Если серьезно, мне очень жаль, что я разочаровал вас, особенно учитывая вашу любовь к Примордией. Безусловно, я думаю, что здесь что-то есть. Но если игрок чувствует, что смысла нет, значит, и смысла нет; код, который невозможно взломать, - это вообще не общение, это просто тарабарщина. Так что, по крайней мере, игра не разговаривала с вами, и это наша вина.

Я почему-то подозреваю, что Google translate тоже сделает этот ответ бессмысленным, но я надеюсь, что, по крайней мере, он прозвучит как искреннее извинение.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971392033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1622181887}
review: Absolutely a game for point and click fans. Absolutely beautiful game. Animation and writing alike. Multiple nods to older point and click games but with a style all its own. The ending left me with a huge smile and I am so glad I bought this game on a whim. Highly recommended. It's pretty short. Beat in under 3 hours without using any guides, but absolutely worth the price of admission. There DO seem to be multiple endings though so I may just have to hop back in with a friend behind the wheel this time. Give it a go!
developer_response:
Thank you so much for the kind words! It means a lot to read them!

The multiple endings are perhaps not alone enough reason to replay it, but many puzzles have different solutions, dialogues have different paths (e.g., the Tarot reading), and you could always try it again with commentary/annotations on.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993702866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1622533404}
review:
A must-play for adventure game enthusiasts. Beautifully horrifying art, solid puzzle design, and deep symbolism combine to push the genre to new heights of emotional storytelling. Some players may find the game a little short, but I think it spends exactly the right amount of time to deliver a condensed and powerful message. The craft and character of Primordia are here again in Strangeland and I'm so very glad Wormwood shared it with us.

Edit: And now I can strongly recommend playing a second time with the commentary/annotations on!
developer_response: I'm so glad to read your review--very kind words, and I'm glad our games have connected with you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198033108492', 'num_games_owned': 583, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1627519864}

author: {'steamid': '76561198066503554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1622168914}
review:
Primordia, the previous effort by Wormwood Studios, is quite possibly my favorite "modern" point-and-click adventure. My expectations for Strangeland were sky-high, not just because of my affection for Primordia but because a) the artwork/aesthetics from Victor PFlug that were teased before release were obviously fantastic, and b) the writing in Primordia demonstrated unusually strong worldbuilding and structure, along with the sense of taking part of a broader discourse/tradition in literature, poetry, etc. Developer Mark Yohalem (who comes across as a cool guy and very accessible and generous with players) clearly knows his Shakespeare, Bible, Greeks, etc. Not to mention that Wadjet Eye is apparently allergic to publishing bad games.

So were expectations reached? In terms of quality I'd say yes for the most part, but with the caveat that I don't think this game will have quite as broad an appeal as Primordia did. Partly because Primordia probably just about hit the ceiling of a niche market for an old-school indie P&C adventure, but also because of the unrelenting "inwardness" of the game. There are a lot of games with themes about the human psyche, depression, loss, etc., but even knowing somewhat what to expect I was surprised by the abrupt opening that landed us immediately inside a mindscape with an intensely singular focus. Most players should understand pretty quickly what's generally going on, making later revelations unsurprising. To be honest, I wasn't able to invest in most of the characters in the same way as the characters in Primordia because of the understanding that they were all figments or fragments. In a certain sense, there's not really a plot- the character development and exploration of a character's psychology *is* the story, and it's plumbed at depth (but again, not with much specificity). It is quality in its presentation, but may not be to everyone's tastes in the way that post-apocalyptic robots might be.

The game also openly invites a boatload of easy comparisons to Edgar Allen Poe (to me the most striking influence), H.P. Lovecraft, Ray Bradbury, Kafka, H.R. Giger, the video game version of Harlan Ellison's "I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream" (both visually and in story tone), Greek tragedy, and likely a host of other influences I'm unfamiliar with. You might think that this would open up the game to criticisms about lack of originality- a carnival of horrors is hardly new ground. Given how well mined some of these themes have been, however, I was surprised at how original the game feels. You get the palpable sense that the developers pored their hearts and personalities into the game, and that really goes a long way toward making the whole project work.

Finally, it should be noted how smooth and professional the game as a production. I'm loathe to even implicitly criticize my favorite old Sierra games, but the interface, difficulty, and ease of use are simply much more accessible than most of the old classics. In general the difficulty and puzzles hit the right spot I think, although I wouldn't say most puzzles stand out particularly one way or another.

TLDR- It's a well-made game that the devs clearly poured their hearts into.  It will likely have a narrower appeal than Primordia, but in my book that's perfectly fine. Those looking for a personalized psychological horror will love it.

EDIT- Playing through the endings I noticed that I misattributed the artwork to Spanos (who is responsible for the impressive job done in coding, VFX, and more) rather than Victor Pflug.  Apologies!
developer_response:
Well, with that flattery I feel a little sheepish responding. But I will say: (1) this seems to sum up extremely well why some people may like it less than Primordia; and (2) it seems to state in a very favorable way what we were hoping to accomplish, including by noting things like the smoothness of the play experience, which we spent a long time on.

Grateful to have your supporting words, and your interest, after all these years. Someday we'll get another adventure out there, as long as the world doesn't end before then. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970361977', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1622153547}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042406453', 'num_games_owned': 1063, 'num_reviews': 748, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1622145158}
review:
[quote]For more puzzle game reviews, news and everything puzzle-related, follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/25928931-Puzzle-Lovers/]Puzzle Lovers[/url] and check out our [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/puzzlelovers]Steam group[/url].[/quote]

[b]strangeland[/b] is yet another great point & click adventure by wormwood studios, also responsible for [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/227000/]primordia[/url], one the best adventures in recent years (or ever, really).

it's a similarly dark and thought-provoking tale, largely taking place in a creepy amusement park. lots of symbolism, wordplay, disturbing imagery, sprinkled with a bit of humor. puzzles include typical inventory-based things to figure out, some of my pet hates (lights out and rotating stuff), and more obscure riddles, but there's a [b]hint system[/b] if you ever get stuck.

don't want to talk much about the story, as that's the primary pull of this genre, plus I knew nothing about it either, didn't even skim the store page for the premise. I knew that after [b]primordia[/b] I was going to play it immediately anyway, the few screenshots I saw were enough to convince me it's gonna be a deliciously grim ride.

[b]the artwork is fantastic, voiceovers are a mixed bag though[/b], which was a surprise, even the protagonist wasn't a good fit, I don't think. the clown was definitely the high point, but most of the others sounded more like friends and family doing the devs a favor instead of (I'm guessing) semi-professionals doing their job well (though the devs themselves also voiced a few characters).

another thing of import is that [b]you can and will die, a lot[/b]. it fits the theme and is often necessary to progress, plus it's kinda fun to find new ways to off yourself (one word-based occurence was especially satisfying) or hear a new joke from the clown. also, there's [b]no progress loss, just a bit of backtracking in a relatively small game world[/b], the death cutscene can be skipped with esc, and imminent perishment is usually signposted, but I still found it frustrating after a while. the middle section of the game was especially bad in this respect, as you're constantly in danger of dying and have to leave the current screen to avoid it. added nothing but stress, couldn't think in peace, had to keep moving just in case.

controls and settings are as expected, separate volume settings, windowed mode, brightness, subtitles, click to advance dialog toggle, the usual commentary, and manual saving anywhere, on top of autosaves. there are [b]multiple endings[/b], so it's obviously a good idea to save before making the final decision to check all of them out.

I had no idea what to expect, maybe a bigger world to explore, if anything (and better voiceovers), but [b]I really enjoyed my time with it[/b] (took [b]about 5 hours[/b]), and I hope we won't have to wait another 8.5 years for wormwood's next game.
developer_response: Thanks -- always enjoy your reviews, especially when they are saying such generous things about our games. I laughed several times in reading this, and had a smile the whole time. We're lucky to have your support.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981579111', 'num_games_owned': 1652, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1622147396}
review:
I love games with a psychological theme. Had no idea what i was getting into, since i bought it just for the fact that it was made by a developer i respect. The game scratched that itch for me (at least in the way I interpreted it), and I enjoyed every moment of it. The art, the music, the general atmosphere, the theme and the story were all amazing.

If I had to say something negative about it, it would be that I found the puzzles to be a little easy. I prefer a little more challenge in my adventure games, but I realize a higher difficulty might have detracted from the flow of the game.

In conclusion, I will continue to buy everything wormwood develops day 1. Thanks for the experience.
developer_response:
Thanks so much!

I feel bad that the puzzles were too easy, though, especially since I'm a "keep puzzles hard" evangelist. Of course, they're only ever just right for some players, too easy for others, too hard for yet others.

I hope we continue to make games that you continue to enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001519985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1649771961}
review:
Strangeland is a point and click adventure game from the developers of the truly excellent Primordia. Primordia is one of the best adventure games ever made if you ask me.

I didn't find Strangeland quite as good but it's still an extremely enjoyable game. It still sits quite far above most "modern" point and click games that I've played.

Now, this is a very strange game. A strange setting. Psychological horror for sure, and a lack of... well, real elements. Very allegorical. But, where I think most games stumble in this regard is that they tend to feel pretentious. And maybe Strangeland is that, but I felt like it kind of was very self-aware of what it is. Perhaps due to the humor that also shows up in the game. It really kind of deflates the game of feeling too self-important.

And yet, the story ends up to be really effective in my opinion, surprisingly so. It's a very well written game, just like Primordia was.

The aesthetics and audio are great and feel very unique, especially in the adventure game genre.

My main complaint would be that the game is a bit too easy when it comes to the puzzles. However, this is, as always, a double-edged sword in the case of adventure games. It does keep the game pace up, which is nice in itself. 

A very good game. Highly recommended, just be aware that it is highly allegorical and really embraces its strangeness.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words! Sorry it didn't quite live up to the expectations Primordia raised in you, but I'm glad you found it engaging all the same. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198084947854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1622132396}

author: {'steamid': '76561198064393309', 'num_games_owned': 344, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1622052754}
review:
If only there was an option for “Mixed” review
I’ve discovered Wormwood Studios and Primordia in 2016, 4 years after its initial release and never forgot about the game after all these years, only regretting not getting it sooner. Everything about the game left me in awe: the art, the story, puzzle designs, characters, the list is too long. It was a wonderful point and click adventure that I enjoyed thoroughly even though I never was a fan of the genre, ever playing a few games, and finishing even less.
To say that I was excited about the new game, Strangeland, is to say nothing. I didn’t follow every little piece of information about the game, leaving everything to be a nice surprise once the game is released and I try it out myself, and was patiently waiting for its release.
The story never clicked with me. I feel like I never had a reason to care about the protagonist and his  struggles, the woman he’s desperately trying to save, and pretty much any other character in the game. It also doesn’t help that “everything” is a metaphor for something, to the point you just stop trying to decipher the messages game’s sending you because there’s 10 more on the way and your brain can only process so much trauma deciphering at once. It does unravel at the end but still leaves some things unanswered/unexplained/left for interpretation, which is fine given how personal the theme can be. I also felt like the whole experience the protagonist is going through in the game is, well, meaningless, as in it feels like there’s no character development, no growth, no fighting your internal struggles and overcoming them, learning from mistakes and doing better; everything feels like “a thing to do”, or just another whatever metaphor. “I’ve done this and now I get to continue” – not because the character learned something about himself or ended up victorious in a fight with his own demons (after all, that’s what the game seems to be about: learning to accept tragedy, dealing with your internal insecurities and struggles, and, in the end, moving on), but simply because you did X and Y and solved the puzzle, and the metaphors for the sake of metaphors aren’t helping to associate yourself and sympathize with the character. There are developer commentaries and annotations that can help you understand intricacies better, bringing more insight into the story, but after finishing the game with an understanding of general outlines of the story I felt no urge to engage in them to learn more.
Other important thing to talk about is the music, as it sets up the mood and atmosphere, which I feel is especially important in a game that relies on surreal, fantastic and disturbing imagery, and, to be honest, I don’t remember a single track or melody from the game. I never at any point in the game stopped and listened to its tunes, not paying attention to tracks that play at all. Nothing really clicked or hit, same as the story. I don’t have much to say about it since it almost didn’t exist in my mind during the playthrough.
Puzzles are fine. They lean towards illogical a bit, but that’s because the setting and circumstances demand it, not because “we need to come up with some absolute nonsense to stop the player from continuing”, and the game never turns into “guess what developer had in mind with this one!”. One particular “puzzle” that required writing your name was fun, but felt out of place. Game also features generous tips on puzzles that are woven into it, which is always nice. Only time I used them out of desperation was deciphering Murmurs future prediction.
And even with all this negativity I can’t say I disliked or hated the game, just like I can’t say that it’s a bad game, that it’s haphazardly/carelessly slapped together, that there was no effort/thought put to it, because it is clearly a lovechild of the dev team, with a lot of craft and thought put into all of its many aspects, and the themes developers chose to tackle being challenging to represent or even work with. 
It breaks my heart to say this, but I was disappointed in Strangeland and the experience it offered and can't recommend it.
developer_response:
Breaks my heart to hear it, but I'm glad you said it.

There's really no response to offer but to say sorry. It's bad enough for a game to disappoint; it's worse within that disappointment is mingled with the kinds of hope and generosity you've shown toward us as developers.

Even if in this particular instance I might prefer for you to be able to leave a "mixed" rating, there is a sort of cruel honesty that Steam compels by forcing the big red thumbs down. I mean, for selfish reasons it's a shame because obviously some number of players will just see the icon and not buy the game, rather than reading your thoughtful criticisms of it. But I feel like you might have been driven more by goodwill toward us than anything else if you had given it a "mixed" rating -- the binary nature of the rating system may have compelled a more faithful result.

Anyway, obviously I wish very much to have read the exact opposite of this review (err, except for the part where you said that you loved Primordia), but thank you for sharing it, and for trying our game.
