author: {'steamid': '76561198036431472', 'num_games_owned': 1055, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1622089698}
review:
Аллегорическое хоррор-приключение, вдохновлённое английской поэзией, квестами из 90х (особенно явно чувствуется влияние I have no mouth, and I must scream).

Игра проходится за 3 часа, реиграбельность отсутствует (можно перепройти игру с комментариями от разработчиков и пояснениями сюжета, но, на мой взгляд, это мало кому покажется интересным). 

Плюсы:
- Высокое качество текста, стилистически он похож скорее на пьесу, чем на сценарий видеоигры.
- Выразительная визуальная составляющая.
- Насыщенность и темп повествования.
-  Почти нет бэктрекинга.
- Головоломки решаются интуитивно, но есть пара исключений.

Минусы:
- Банальный сюжет без неожиданных поворотов.
developer_response:
Большое спасибо за подробный и сбалансированный обзор. Извините, что вы нашли темы банальными, но я рад, что игра вас в целом порадовала.

Поскольку это русскоязычный обзор, я добавлю, что мы работаем над русским переводом, пока говорим. Это, конечно, не поможет с банальностью, но, надеюсь, расширит аудиторию.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977415429', 'num_games_owned': 766, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1622857844}
review:
Strangeland is a traditional point'n'click game with excellent production values and story - the art and voice acting are top-notch, the music does its job but is not particularly memorable.

The puzzles are a bit on the easier side, which I don't see as a failure - compared to the dev's previous game, Primordia, there's much less of "try everything on everything else" and "search for the hard to see object". The game took me less than 6 hours to complete - there are multiple endings, but the paths don't seem to diverge much.

When it comes to the story, it's hard to talk about without spoilers - it's a grim tale helped by the creepy, unsettling art (but not scary - the horror here is more psychological). The game draws explicitly on some psychoanalytical theory (and implicitly on philosophical ones), and it leaves a lot of the plot up to the player's interpretation - which might annoy some people, but it didn't annoy me.  If anything, I think the story is well crafted, and the ending left me a bit disappointed because it actually seems to oversimplify what was going on.

But it is certainly a game worth experiencing, and a very good addition to Wadjet Eye's great adventure portfolio.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind assessment!  I'm glad the themes engaged you.  I agree it's a bit easier than Primordia, but I *think* that because it has fewer unfair puzzles, not because the puzzles are less sophisticated. That said, who knows? Maybe I'm just getting soft as a designer!

author: {'steamid': '76561197977774874', 'num_games_owned': 699, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1622155647}
review: Игра от создателя Primordia и Until I Have You. Если вы бывалый любитель квестов, то вам не нужно ничего объяснять. Покупайте и играйте. Если же вы мимокрокодил, то получите от игры теплые и ламповые вечера с превосходным артом, интересными паззлами и синтвейвом. Это не просто "хорошая" игра, а знаковая. Печально, что игрожур жанр квестов практически не обозревает, из-за этого многие отличные проекты проходят мимо многих.
developer_response:
Огромное спасибо за щедрый отзыв - «iconic» - это высокая оценка! Также трогательно то, что вы заметили «Пока у меня нет тебя» (увлеченный проект кодера Primordia / Strangeland) и оценили музыкальный подход, который мы использовали в Strangeland. Передам ваши добрые слова остальной команде!

Отмечу, что мы работаем и над русским переводом. Хотя российские игроки иногда жестко (но справедливо!) Критикуют наши игры, мне кажется, что любовь к старым играм, возможно, сохранялась среди них дольше, чем среди англоговорящих.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118836726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1622117173}
review:
Absolutely stunning. Another masterpiece by WadjetEye Games and  Wormwood studios. Beautiful, thought provoking with amazing voice acting by the ever amazing Abe Goldfarb (Joey from Blackwell, Rabbi Stone in The Shivah, Doc in the Golden Wake and many many more). Would recommend. Only downside is that I would have loved it to be longer, I could have easily kept playing for several more hours.
All in all solid 9/10 only lost a point for the shortness
developer_response:
So glad you liked it! That was a very kind review -- "thought-provoking" is always a nice thing to hear.

Sorry that it was a bit short -- I'm not sure whether commentary tracks are your cup of tea or not, but if they are, the game *might* warrant a replay with the commentary and annotations on, and you could explore some of the different puzzle solutions and dialogue paths.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983967315', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1622175791}
review:
First there was the robotic, post-apocalyptic adventure game Primordia that seemed tailor-made for my love of deserts, humanoid robots, quiet melancholy, and mystery.  Now, Wormwood Studios has made a game that directly taps into my love of surrealist imagery, ravens, psychodramas, and also mystery.  I'm beginning to think someone on this development team is reading my thoughts.

With regards to the game, its quietly nestled its way to the top of games whose themes and imagery already occupy my head space after I turn the game off.  It's quite good.  You should play it too.  Especially you.
developer_response: I'm so glad to hear that both our games connected with you, and have nestled their way into your brain. We're very lucky to have found fans like you!

author: {'steamid': '76561197977887115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1622098274}
review: Another great point and click game published by Wadjet Eye
developer_response: Thank you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198086280475', 'num_games_owned': 398, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1623813005}
review:
I'm sad to say this but honestly, this game was very disappointing.
I saw this on the store page and couldn't believe that Wormwood Studios has made another game, so I excitedly bought it thinking I'll have another amazing experience like Primordia, which is the best point & click game I've played. But this was such a let down.

I was bored throughout most of the game, it started out well enough and had me curious about things. But as I kept playing, I felt like everything I was doing was pointless and I barely had any of my questions answered, it was just random puzzles. I kind of stopped caring around the end, but I kept playing because I wanted to see the game through. 

Everything I'll write from here on out is a spoiler.


[spoiler] The endings of the game still don't answer much.
Who the hell am I?
Where am I?
How did I get here?
Am I dead? Am I insane?
What is "the dark thing"? Or the crab. I don't even know at this point. And what did it do to me? I was sent to a dead version of the carnival, then I did some more pointless puzzles that sent me to a mirror room that opened a portal back to the "normal" carnival. What exactly, was the point of that whole section?
Who is my shadow? And why was it relentlessly killing me at the end?
Who is the blonde lady? And why was she jumping into the well over and over, but when I reached her at the top of the carnival it was like nothing happened?

 
The game essentially ends either with you dying, or flying into the sun. whatever that means. Was I just not paying attention? Or is the game really that vague? I really hope it's the former, but even still, I don't really like that kind of conclusion, I feel like the player or the reader shouldn't have to make up an ending that satisfies their logic. The author should end the story for me. [/spoiler]
developer_response:
This is a very hard review to read because not only did Strangeland disappoint you, that disappointment was a product of the love you'd shown our prior product. The only real response is to say I'm very sorry to have let you down.

While I think the questions you raise are answered in the game, that doesn't change the fact that the answers didn't come through to you or, more importantly, that the drama and themes of the game didn't come through to you.  That is our fault (more precisely, my fault as the designer, it has nothing to do with the art, music, voice acting, or code).

I would, of course, be happy to answer the questions now, but it seems to me that might be worse than nothing. Boring you with a long response after boring you with the game would be bad on top of bad.

Again, my deep apologies for disappointing you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993837279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1622291315}
review:
A dark psychological horror in the form of a point and click. The story is engaging and it flows extremely well from point to point with very little backtracking. The built-in hint system is a really nice touch - gives you just enough of a push to get through if you get hung up on a particular puzzle.

I love the art style, it's extremely fitting with the story; disturbing without being "graphic". The voice acting is superb; with Abe Goldfarb doing a fantastic job as the lead character but they're all voiced and performed brilliantly.

All in all this is a fantastic release from Wormwood Studios. It's a definitely must for fans of point and click games, doubly so if you like psychological horror.
developer_response: Thank you so much! I'm really glad to hear that each of the pieces worked for you, and that the whole was satisfying!

author: {'steamid': '76561198119622222', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1622816821}
review: Great job wormowood and wadgeteye. I loved primordia and have been stoked for this since announcement and have not been disappointed so far. Great gameplay with good puzzles, and an incredible soundtrack, very good at setting the tone of the game. I also enjoy the allegory.
developer_response: Thanks so much! Very glad you enjoyed the allegorical aspects, as it's not always for everyone :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198000296297', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1622423387}
review:
Strangeland is a point-and-click adventure game about a guy that wakes up in a straight jacket next to a sign pointing the way to Strangeland. All in all, thematically, this game is something special, creating an evocative, well, creepy aesthetic. This is accomplished in large part by the absolutely fantastic art design. It's interesting, it's unique, it's original, it's cohesive, and it manages to tell a story on its own. I am not the kind of person who often appreciates art in games, but the imagery in this game really improved it as an experience.

The puzzles are great, and while I struggled to solve many of them, I never thought "How was I supposed to know to do that?!" The difficulty is about right, with plenty of puzzles that make you feel clever. This is prime 90s point-and-click except with all the modern day conveniences you expect. 

The plot has an interesting premise but it wasn't concrete enough or developed enough for me to be satisfied with it. Because so little information is given, I couldn't care about the minimal plot events.
developer_response: Thanks for the thoughtful assessment!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041971048', 'num_games_owned': 1493, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1622076026}
review:
I bought this the minute I saw it was from the Primordia devs.
And maaan did it deliver! Such a unsettling game with incredible voice acting and great characters. The story is a barely comprehensible mindfuck but it's a journey worth-taking.
I kinda wish it was longer because I was willing to spend 10 more hours exploring this fucked up world. The art, the soundscape and the puzzles were all fantastic.
I'm gonna stop gushing now wait for the next game.
developer_response:
Thanks so much! "Unsettling" was the goal, so I'm glad it worked!

If it's your cup of tea, playing again with commentary and annotations adds a lot of *content* -- the question is whether it's content that you enjoy.  There's like 3 or 4 hours of commentary between the three of us, and then probably a couple hundred notes on the various references in the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972710279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1622157848}
review:
One of the weirdest adventure games I've played and I did play "a lot" :) The atmosphere, the environment, the pacing, and the puzzles are quite top notch. The story is ....... strange to say the least. The puzzles are all in-line with the current state and atmosphere of the game. None of them seemed out of touch with the game at all. 

I strongly suggest Strangeland for adventure game enthusiasts. If you like digging through meanings, finding hidden meanings in some references, Strangeland seems like a very, very good experience.
developer_response: Thank you so much! Particularly glad the puzzles worked so well for you, as they're a very tricky thing to get right. (Of course, they're never right for *everyone*, but I'm very glad that they were right for you!)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970406934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1622075759}
review: Introspective and Strange adventure with it's own style. Very Atmospheric.
developer_response: Many thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561197982405795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1669064168}
review:
< Coherent > <Subtext > < Story >

As a fan of Primordia my high expectations were dashed and my hopes left in dust. Every new thing that's happened, I've thought 'that was amazing.' I struggle to think of one other point-and-click adventure game where you can play conceptual mind games with a giant psychic starfish. Immensely creative, intensely engaging, meaningful. Genius.
developer_response: Hahaha. I'm hearing it in the Seastar's voice!

author: {'steamid': '76561198063605752', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1622071055}
review:
As in classics like "Something Wicked This Way Comes", the horror does not consist of being forced to endure terror - it is realizing that you seek the terror out yourself, because it is enticing and exciting. In the same way, the resolution is not escaping the frights, but realizing the horrors can't control you. And so the end is bitter-sweet: satisfying, mature, but also a finality to the adolescent excitement.

There are perhaps a small amount of technical improvements that could be made to the game and to the puzzle-design. But they couldn't detract from the narrative flow of the game, which is a rare accolade for any computer game.
developer_response:
"And so the end is bitter-sweet: satisfying, mature, but also a finality to the adolescent excitement."

Beautiful. Thank you. I'm so glad the game hit you like that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010503490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1622638654}
review:
It was by far the darkest game I have played in a while, and was an ACTUAL adventure. 
Even though the subject matter is pretty heavy, by avoiding shock value for shock-value's sake, and a hearty dose of black humor, this game succeeds in maintaining a well balanced ratio between the individual parts (being a solid story, having an emotional impact, being self aware that it is a video game, balanced riddles/avoiding moonlogic). 
It is a distilled experience, boiled down to the important parts, that does not outstay its welcome. 

Pros:
Atmosphere 
Great Story
Black Humor
More than one way to beat some puzzles
Amazing dialogue
Loved the commentary by the devs
Price (seriously less than 13 Euros? Are you trying to go bankrupt or something?)


Cons:
Abrupt Ending 
Could use some higher contrast color grading
developer_response: Thank you so much for generous and lovely review! I'm so glad you enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197977918917', 'num_games_owned': 739, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1622064528}
review:
Fantastically well crafted adventure full of dark and macabre imagery and symbolism. A story about loss, depression, suicide, introspection, that's very open to interpretation. It's obvious a lot of love and heart went into this game. 

The artwork, music, and sound effects strongly evoke the mood and theme brilliantly. The writing and voice acting bring the crazy and fascinating characters alive. Puzzles are simplistic but interesting and make sense, and there's a help system that's well integrated in-case you get stuck.

Definitely reminded me of I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream in the themes and characters. There's even a reference in the game, so I feel it must have been an influence.

My only complaints are minor technical points. The game doesn't alt-tab well, and I encountered a bug where an audio effect kept playing until I restarted. The game caps at 40FPS, probably due to animation speed, but this causes tearing in some scenes. None of this really affected my enjoyment though.

Definitely recommended if you enjoy point-and-click adventure games.
developer_response:
Thank you so much for this review -- a very generous assessment, kindly put. :)

The sheering issue seems a bit better if you run it in OpenGL. Too late to do you much good, but perhaps someone else will read this and be helped.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145661544', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1622064404}
review:
This is a really creative and entertaining sit-through. What does Strangeland bring in comparison to other indie adventure games? A psychedelic setting within a grim atmosphere, through satisfying retro graphics. There is voice acting, which is nothing spectacular but surely on point and served its purpose successfully. The music score is subtle and abstract, fitting the setting which is, let's say inside the protagonist's head. The selling point of this game though is it's writing. Its a heavy game with deep meanings in it, not a breeze of fresh air. Only thing i would enjoy more is maybe a little more content like puzzles or riddles, because 5.5 hours is really not that long, still worth every cent.

SPOILERS AHEAD

It totally nails the feeling of dread, self pity, depression and the suffering of loss. There is no hero and there is no journey, it's what comes before getting on with our lives after experiencing a tragedy. The loss in our head, the struggle, the self blame, the existential crisis, the fear of death and the pointlessness of life.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this review, especially the last paragraph. It means a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994403825', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1622864572}
review: My only complaint is the awful audio quality of Mark Yohalem's commentary when you have the commentary mode turned on. It sounds like he recorded it with the built in mic on a 20 year old laptop that was dunked in a toilet then thrown down some stairs. I have to wonder if they even listened to the audio before putting it into the game.
developer_response:
The coder was really pissed when he heard the quality when I sent them the recordings. I did them on an ostensibly nice headset (the one I've been using for work since the quarantine), and by the time I listened, I had already recorded like 2 hours of commentary, and I just felt I had to push through. Since I was transcribing them, I figured it would be marginally tolerable.

Apparently not. :/

Sorry for the unpleasantness, especially because I really did hope people would enjoy the commentary.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079337394', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1642949191}
review:
[i]Tell me if you heard this one before. A guy wakes up on a carnival with a killer headache... *cackles*[/i]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2498526391
[h1]Strangeland[/h1]
Strangeland is a point and click adventure that's definitely, well, [i]strange[/i]. First thing you notice is the nightmarish weirdness. The beautifully drawn art sets the mood to [i]you're screwed[/i]. The game just throws you into this distorted reality. At first I felt just as confused and lost as the main character himself. And I'm glad they didn't explain everything from the start, really makes you wanna explore. The writing in this game is very engaging. When I started the game I just played it through till the end. I was too curious to take a break. That being said, the game took me around 4-5 hours to finish. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2498526464
Every line is voice acted- and it's great. I kept returning to a cackling clown, just to hear its jokes and cackles again. Also I got a [i]raven[/i] to say ass outloud. ᵂʰᵃᵗˀ ᴰᵒⁿ'ᵗ ʲᵘᵈᵍᵉ ᵐᵉ... The puzzles were fairly straightforward. Managed to solve all of them without using the ingame help system. One puzzle made me wonder if there were other outcomes, but I didn't manage to find anything else so moved on... [spoiler]The puzzle where you have to write down your name.. I thought writing down the name of the blind man would maybe do something else..[/spoiler]. I would like to share more about the game, but I think it's best experienced without too much spoilers or hints as what is going on.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2498526295
I've only recently been exploring Wormwood's adventure games. I can honestly say that I've become a big fan. This game is definitely on the strange side.- so if you are into adventure games and a bit of weirdness, [b]absolutely recommend!!!![/b]
developer_response: Thank you so much for this amusing, and generous, review! So glad that you liked the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045743398', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1622006730}
review:
Dear Wormwood Studios, thank you very much for the work you've done. I really enjoyed the game. I liked everything - the atmosphere and art, the characters, the music, the story.
The game looks much better than in the screenshots or trailer. Very atmospheric and exciting adventure! 
Really liked the difficulty level of the puzzles - they are interesting to solve, but you don't get stuck for long. There's a built-in hint system - which, however, doesn't give detailed instructions - It still makes you think a little and doesn't kill the interest of the process. 
Highly recommended! 5/5
developer_response: Thank you so much! I'm glad you enjoyed the game and found the puzzles at the right difficulty. (It's always hard to calibrate them right, and I'm glad they were the right level for you.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198048334094', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1621982388}
review:
Great point-and-click adventure into the depths of the psyche (and the monsters that dwell therein). All the puzzles are logical and not particularly hard. The writing can get a bit too "clever" and self-absorbed at times and it doesn't reach the levels of Planescape: Torment, but it's still enjoyable throughout and has plenty of flashes of brilliance too. Primordia was one of my favorite adventure games of the past decade, and while this one isn't as much of a masterpiece in this reviewer's humble opinion, it's still great & worth your time & makes me look forward to whatever Wormwood might have in store for us next.

To conclude: He that hath wings let him soar.
developer_response:
Thanks for your kind words!

I'm sorry it didn't reach the level of Primordia for you (reaching the level of PS:T seems out of the question, but it's nice to even have it suggested as a possibility), but I'm very glad you enjoyed it all the same!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970784893', 'num_games_owned': 1007, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1622055229}
review:
Strangeland is an overall lovely little indie game that explores grief and insanity. It is a very personal tale, a bit too simple for my taste, but also touching, warm and fundamentally uplifting and wise in its simplicity seen out from the protagonists view of being in a very dark place, having lost his way.
The games ambience took me on a beautiful and joyous journey and I was especially pleasantly surprised by its use of humor, treading a fine line of still being serious but on the other giving it a comic feel, don't think I'd finished it here and now otherwise, unless perhaps it'd been a longer and more complex game.
Speaking of which, the protagonist seemed a bit simpleminded on the one hand, though on  the other hand his mind could just have been broken? I mean had he read, grappled with and understood something of the psychoanalyst  Lacan himself and various mythologies? Had he just faced a too impactful trauma and hard life, or was it in a Jungian vein, just the collective unconscious that tried to bring him back to the world of the living giving him a hand? (the developers have kindly added a dev commentary you an toggle on, but not sure I have the patience to walk through the game again with it in hand - though I am somewhat tempted! :D). 
  
The in-game build hint system in the narrative structure was lovely touch, even if I'd prefer more complex puzzles (or none at all; adventure games are not really my genre) like we find them--or some of them been ages--in games like Riven. though if you like puzzles like those in Primorida and its ilk, then they seem to be as beautifully and skillfully made or more so.
A delightful game showing that the developers have honed their craft looking forward to possible future offerings.
developer_response: Thanks so much for your kind words -- honestly means a great deal to have someone play the game and see in it something "fundamentally uplifting" rather than despairing. That was what we were shooting for but it was a shot in the dark (ha ha). I'm sure it won't hit for everyone but I'm very glad it did for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980482234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1623475114}
review:
I am a huge fan of Primordia, and Strangeland is a very different game of the same quality. I think which a person prefers is entirely up to their preferred genres. In any case, it's a worthy addition and worth playing.

The graphics are appropriately detailed for a point and click adventure game, and the art direction is on point. Visual effects are the match of anything in the genre, and the soundscape is immersive and thematic to the point where I don't remember it as anything but an integral part of the game.

Point and Click gameplay is always its own special beast. While there's no insane jump of logic at any time, some things are less clear than others. However, the game has a built-in hint system for anyone, like me, who sometimes just gets frustrated at a puzzle and wants to move on. 

The storytelling and plot are the kinds of things that can really speak to someone's experiences, but can tell a solid story regardless of life history. Of course if you ever laid awake at night wishing your love of Greek play structure or Norse mythology led to a deeper understanding of a work, this is a game for you.

Which brings me to what made me go from luke-warm to hot on the game: it contains both a developer commentary, discussing things from home-built audio equipment to executing the will of a family member, and an annotation mode that carefully explains the truly heroic amount of allusion in the game. My enjoyment increased ten-fold with a second playthrough going through the commentary and reading about all the references I simply failed to notice.

My first run was about four hours, and I was reasonably thorough, but I expect detail-orinted players, and those who refuse to use the help system, may take a bit longer.

I recommend the game, it's technically excellent and is a solid point and click aventure, but it does take some settling in to really feel comfortable. If you liked Primordia or point and click adventures, it's worth a shot. If you like developer commentaries, you should just buy it, because your second playthrough with the commentary will be simply amazing.
developer_response: Thanks so much for your thorough and balanced review! I'm glad you liked the commentary and notes so much! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197995896297', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1622007859}
review:
A beautiful game telling an intriguing story built around an enjoyable point-and-click adventure/puzzle game. The voice-acting was surprisingly good, writing was very enjoyable (only dragging on at times), the music was appropriate and decent, the puzzles weren't so easy that you felt like you were being insulted, nor were they quite hard enough to make you feel clever for solving them. 
8.5/10, I look forward to more from Wormwood Studios.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993919266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1622005347}
review: I absolutely love this game. It reminded me of a twisted/demented kings quest. The puzzles were very intuitive and satisfying. Don't worry if you get stuck because the developers made it easy for stupid people like me, and gave hints when I was banging my head on the keyboard. I loved the art design and dialogue. The setting takes place in a Carnival hell dimension with a lot of sick and twisted side characters. Your objective is to figure out what the HELL is going on. The storytelling is excellent and kept me curious until the very end. I'm glad I gave this game a shot and I can't wait until the next game comes out! 5/5
developer_response:
"A twisted/demented King's Quest" brought a big smile to my face!

I takes us years to make a game, so I fear you'll be waiting a while. (We do have our older Primordia if you haven't played that yet.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198127872503', 'num_games_owned': 659, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1655869184}
review:
Never thought I'd see the day when games would reference Tom Stoppard of all people and actually make it work.
At first I had my worries. Sure, the art looks great and it's from the people who delivered before, but how long can a company stay in business and not get complacent? And why do I keep remembering other games while playing? Didn't I see that feature in Dead Synchronicity and this one in Whispered World? And I could swear I saw that in Samaritan Paradox. Didn't I see that design decision in Sanitarium? Didn't I see that style of storytelling in Tormentum and art style in Dark Seed? Is this supposed to be a love letter to those who came before or a postmodernist take on some sort of meta point and click adventuring? Or have I been playing these for way too long at this point?
Whatever the answer is, they still managed to come up with a fresh and polished feel that keeps you riveted long enough to play through in a single sitting. The use of mythology is the most inventive and clever I have seen in a very long while. The psycho-philosophical musings and rants of madness are written so well you never get dropped out of the experience in spite of the obviously alien feel they are supposed to evoke. Dark themes intertwine with very subtle humour. And that is helped by voice acting that is incredible even by Wadjet's own standards.
AdventureGamers is probably going to say that this is the Dark Souls of point and clicks, I am going to say that you should play it because it is great and will be on everyone's 2d adventure top list this year and boy have the last couple of years been dry in that regard.
P.S. Unsettling and certainly gory, but not. a. single. jumpscare. that alone is worth the price tag.
developer_response: Thanks so much for this generous review. Glad the Stoppard reference was appreciated! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198010217378', 'num_games_owned': 930, 'num_reviews': 248, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1621999602}
review:
It's odd to see how a creator whose cultural context is clearly so close to mine can produce a game that would fall so flat.

I don't mind that Wormwood are doing a Planescape: Torment thing again (at least there's no floating head this time — but hey, we got a giant blacksmith!). I don't mind the on-the-nose references (geez Louise, is that a one-eyed old wisdom-seeker under a tree, I wonder if it's referring to mythology in any way). I think the imagery is there — some overused (circus, crows, mirrors, golden light), some original (the whole imago thing with its layers on meaning and more), some brilliant (the Dark Thing turning into a [spoiler]crab[/spoiler] seems odd and even ridiculous at first, until you realize it represents [spoiler]the character's depression due to his wife dying of cancer — so, literally of "crab"[/spoiler]). The art is beautiful and the voice acting is serviceable.

So why does the whole thing feel less than the sum of its parts?

[b]WHY IT FALLS FLAT[/b]
The answer is simple: because the core story is so impossibly overused and trite.

Like, seriously. It seems like 90% of dark surreal plot-driven games are about how:
[list]
[*] you're actually already dead;
[*] or your wife is and you're coping with the loss;
[*] or you've actually MURDERED your wife;
[*] or you've actually MURDERED your wife and then killed yourself so you're now DEAD TOO;
[*] (optionally: it's about writer's block).
[/list]

I'll let you guess which category this game belongs to. And sure, it's possible to tell an old story so brilliantly it will feel fresh — but representing a broken character with broken mirrors and writing "don't we all wear masks every day?" with a straight face is not the way to go about it.

I think I see what it tried to do writing-wise. Instead of spelling out the obvious or burying the player under unnecessary detail (kudos for that!), [i]Strangeland[/i] went for a sort of [i]Dear Esther[/i]-like poetic writing, full of wordplay and emotion. Unfortunately, it just doesn't work. There wasn't enough detail in the writing (I mean granular, specific imagery, not biographical detail), weren't enough interesting and insightful metaphors, the long-winded speeches felt empty, often regurgitating the same idea many times without adding new facets to it. 

(There were exceptions, like the aforementioned imago moment, or the mention of [spoiler]an onkos mask[/spoiler] that was a nicely subtle way to communicate the main plot point without being too in-your-face.)

[b]UNEXPECTED BRILLIANCE[/b]
The strangest thing (heh) is that there are glimpses of interesting worldbuilding. A character's surreal mental scape is a free-for-all — it doesn't really [i]need[/i] original imaginary creatures and a wider context of a setting. Yet [i]Strangeland[/i] has them! A trio of characters who'd done something terrible to a streammaid have an odd and curious idea of what life is, odd patterns of speech. I want to know more about them, not the protagonist's trite drama!

The dialogue with the starfish in particular was the highlight of the game for me. It was a good attempt to represent an inhuman mind, and I laid off finishing the puzzle for a while to read all conversations. They did indeed feel like I was talking to a fundamentally alien being.

I'd much rather play a game about the hunter who interacted with it and caugth it, and I hope in the future the developer would rather explore that side of their creativity.

[b]OVERALL[/b]
There's clearly a lot of passion and talent behind the game. And good cultural education, too. Judging by the "Im memoriam" at the end, the core story might be personal for the developer — and it has been pointed out before that it's the most personal stories that sometimes come across as the most banal when we try to share them.

It's not an entirely "thumbs down" game too, I'm more on the fence. Giving it a thumbs down for now to balance out the perfect review score — I don't think it deserves that either. More like a 6/10. And short, too, which is a plus for the genre.
developer_response: Sorry to hear about your bad (or at least mixed!) experience with the game. I think cosmically the positive player reviews are more than balanced out by the negative critic reviews (such that perhaps a 6/10 should go off the net the other way), but I've always valued candor in reviews, and negative reviews are always a valuable teaching item.  More than anything, I'm disappointed in having disappointed you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029072719', 'num_games_owned': 1572, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1622001898}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995669628', 'num_games_owned': 1581, 'num_reviews': 531, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1622415030}
review:
I could feel the dev's passion and dedication while playing the game, and not just because it has beautiful artwork, many games do, I am more impressed by the writing and the subtle details in the dialogue, even poetic to some extent.  It's not a very long game, about 4 to 5 hours, granted it would be a bit longer if it didn't have a hint system. There is an object you can use to get hints, most of the time it's a spoiler so be careful if you want to figure out the puzzle yourself. Technically it has multiple endings, but you can get them by saving at the end, they are not tied to the progression as far as I can tell. On that note, I assumed that the choices I made throughout the game would have more impact, it feels like the game implies more possibilities than it has. I won't elaborate on the narrative too much, I am sure you can tell it has some kind of psychological twist on the internal struggle. I have to say the whole mind exploration is not very unique, and frankly, the outcome is somewhat predictable, but as far as the dialogue and characters go, I enjoyed the writing. You will meet all kinds of strange individuals that will poke you and make fun of you, the game is actually funny, despite being somewhat serious - love that bird by the phone, best character.

At first, I didn't like the inventory system because you have to open a separate panel, that said, you can just use the mouse scroll which solves the problem. As far as the puzzle design, I like that you incorporated the theme of the world - there is context to what you doing, and that is what I am looking for in a narrative game. I didn't struggle too much despite the obscurity of the environment, if you paying attention most of the puzzles are not too difficult. I can never find the words to express how I feel about beautiful artwork, but I will add that it feels like you planned the visuals very well, there is a lot of variety and changes in scenery that I didn't expect, especially the second half of the game, it was pretty cool. 

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

(+) [b] The Narrative & Optional context [/b] - I don't think that you picked the most original idea to work with, but I did enjoy the conversation between the characters and the context it adds to the experience, the game is not wasteful with the words and always provides something interesting. On that note, I like that game has optional responses if you doing something that is not intended to progress. There is a good mixture of humor and philosophical views, it's a strange tone overall I must admit, but at least I was engaged the entire time. 

(+) [b] The Visuals [/b] - what can I say it's a good looking game, and it was fun to explore. There are many additional animation cycles and backgrounds that most devs would not care to animate, so nice attention to detail there as well. I also enjoyed the atmosphere while I was playing the game, but now that I think about it, I can't remember the music. Not that I didn't like the soundtrack, it only worked for me within the context of the game. Like I said in the forum, it feels like a $20 premium indie game based on the effort, but thank you for the lower price.

(+) [b] Creative Puzzles & Optional Hint system[/b] - my stance on the puzzle design is that they should be a part of the narrative, and for the most part you did a really good job with it. In some games the puzzle might not have a reason to exist, but here they are used to add more context for the characters. I only found one puzzle a little confusing, you already know which one.

(+) [b] UI [/b] - I don't mind the lack of highlights as long as the game is visually clear, and I don't recall having any issues. I see that you streamlined the interactions a bit, for example, the puzzle with feeding and dialogue skip in general. Also, the mouse scroll is very helpful. 

(+) [b] Optional Achievements, Optional responses, Optional triggers [/b]

[h1] Feedback: [/h1]

[u] Random Nitpicks [/u] - so that visual effect the character gets every so often got pretty annoying, I get why it's there, but I don't think it needed to happen as often as it did (reminds me of that Castlevania cutscene lol). Come to think of it, you probably don't need to see the death cutscene the second time, unless it loads the game maybe. On a side note, some people that play adventure games might struggle with a speed-based puzzle due to accessibility issues (not sure if you can skip it).

[u] Voice acting [/u] - overall the voice acting was decent, the only reason I bring it up is because some characters were voiced extremely flat, and it took me out of the experience. Look, I get it, you work with what you got, but if I had to nitpick one thing, I wish all characters were a bit more immersive. The fortune teller was done very well, feels professional, I wish everyone was like that. 

[u] The endings [/u] - I don't like that you can just save at the end and choose whatever you want, if you used those as part of the choices during the game, it would be more interesting to figure out, in my opinion. I thought the tarot cards and the ladies had something to do with it, but I guess not - would have been a good way to do it. I don't want you to change anything now, unless maybe you want to add more secret endings.

[b] Overall Thoughts: 9/10 [/b]

I have to say it was a little difficult for me to enjoy the game because I came with high expectations, I wish I could experience it not knowing the dev's previous work, but it did not disappoint by any means. I see that a lot of thought went into making every aspect of the game, and sometimes that is all I can ask for as a fan of the genre. I was not completely in love with the story and that is where I feel I get a disconnect, I think it was too predictable, but it's just my opinion. Again, the dialogue was fine, I enjoyed the characters, but the actual plot overall, feels like I went there like 50 times before. Don't have much criticism for the actual gameplay though, clearly, it was planned very well. 

[code]Review By: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31294838-Hidden-Gem-Discovery/ [/code]
developer_response:
Thank you so much for this thorough, thoughtful, and kind review!

I think the nits are well picked, and the suggestions well taken. Above all, I'm very grateful that you enjoyed the game. We're lucky to have such fans!

author: {'steamid': '76561197974970808', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1649060727}
review:
This will be some people's favorite Wadjet Eye game; it's not mine, but that's because it's third, behind Technobabylon and Wormwood's own Primordia. If you are in the unlikely position of being here and having no idea what this means, it means you should buy this game immediately if you like point-and-click adventures.

Why will it be a select favourite? Because certain aspects of Strangeland are exceptional. Beneath a bizarre horror aesthetic lies the most "human" game in the entirety of the Wadjet Eye catalogue. Barring what I feel to be some story missteps near the close, the starkly personal tale is refreshing in its originality. Within such a context the game understands that the player has no reason to care for the woman, but very deftly eases you in and makes you care. The empathy, with the duality that implies, is strong with this one; rare stuff for any point-and-click.

Tightly coupled with this is the presence of an almost possessed design vision. You can almost detect the way Mark Yohalem was gripped by the impetus to make this game and absolutely nothing else until it was completed, even knocking Fallen Gods, another Wormwood game in progress, by the wayside in his fervor. This intensity makes the game what it is and cannot be described piecemeal; you will simply have to play this game to understand, and it will not take long.

Puzzles are on the easy side, but this is partly faciliated by the thoughtful ergonomics seen in other Wadjet Eye titles such as the aforementioned Technobabylon and Unavowed. The game simply does not waste the player's time and provides conveniences where possible, making the game look and feel easier than it is. 

This is the best looking game in the Wadjet Eye catalogue. That should be all there is to say about the graphics.

Voice acting is good, typical Wadjet Eye fare. Due to the game's aesthetics there are occasional situations where the main character sounds rather out-of-place, or the characterization is not as confident as it could be. In short it is the dissonance of having jokes or glib, cosmopolitan remarks in an abstract, largely humorless setting. But these are rare and and in any event not immersion breaking.

The music occasionally threatens to be memorable; it never is. You could remove it and it's not clear if the game would be less for it. This is certainly the game's weakest aspect. I will nevertheless give the soundtrack a separate listen but it should augment the game first and foremost.

So you see, the things that make Strangeland unique really are unique and can't be found anywhere else in this space. The meh stuff you can live without, anyway. That's why you buy it, and keep supporting Wormwood.
developer_response: What a beautiful review. "The presence of an almost possessed design vision." What more could a developer ask than to be understood? Many thanks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198256137537', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 261, 'last_played': 1622225924}
review:
I've one-shotted this game. That's a rare enough occasion, and it's even rarer to see me write a review about it. 
I simply haven't had this much fun playing a point and click in ages, and P&C is my favourite type of game, which is to say that I'm used to having *tons* of fun while playing them. 

Of course, if you're not an amateur of horror, then you won't find the same attachment to this game as I did. 
The horror elements are kept soft and ambient, with no jumpscares in the entire game at all, which is very refreshing. Yet, there were still moments I tensed up from the visuals, which didn't need to be brought up suddenly to provoke a feeling of unease. Psychological horror has always been a sweet spot for me, and this hits it just right. 

The game makes you laugh and wonder, as well as it makes you wince and apprehend. Despite a plot and narration-device that has been seen before, it makes for a unique experience that doesn't feel like a copy of anything. You can definitely feel the inspiration of works like Sanitarium (Which was brought up as an example by the creators themselves, and which is a very fitting comparison indeed!) but the game retains a very personal identity, whether it be through the artistic direction or through dialogues and storytelling. I'll add, if you liked Sanitarium I think it very very likely you will enjoy Strangeland. It definitely feels like a successor in spirit!

I want to point out two things that make the Strangeland adventure worthwhile, apart from it's good writing and mysterious storyline, and that would be the visuals and voice acting. 

Firstly, this game is gorgeous. Though very desaturated compared to my usual tastes, the artists just make it work. The painting style used for the illustrations is beautiful, and I think it really sends the point across as to how the writers envisionned their story. That is to say, it fully does everything you could ask from it. It has a strong visual identity, an attention to details, it fits the theme. I'm a hobbyist artist myself, and I feel like I will learn a lot by just looking at Strangeland's illustrations and analyzing them. 

Then, the voice acting. The protagonist has exactly the kind of voice that fits for such a role: He has something monotone to it, as many point and click protagonists do, which immediately put me in that mood of settling down in front of a good P&C like I did when I was younger. But it also has a lot of depht to it, and the actor's performance is admirable. The emotions are just subtle enough to not be an obstacle to the script, but present enough that you get a clear feeling of what the character is feeling. Thus, our protagonist rarely has to state out his emotions ; You just feel them through the voice work. Annoyance, despair, tiredness or victory. 
Apart from the main character, everyone else has interesting voices that fit their characters surprisingly well. The world is brought to life through them, and every character is recognizable from their voice alone. Point and click voice acting is often good, but not so often as good as this in my opinion. 

Strangeland feels, to me, a step above the usual quality I find in point and click games. Some may find this  glowing praise to be maybe a little much, but it is how I feel, sincerely. 

Now, bear in mind that I  am exactly the target audience of this game, being a fan of indie games, horror *and* point and clicks. If you are not all of the above, this is a good game. If you are, then Strangeland is made for you.
developer_response:
This was a really special and gratifying review to read, in particular this bit: "The game makes you laugh and wonder, as well as it makes you wince and apprehend."

I'm so glad it found the right audience in you!

author: {'steamid': '76561197967433737', 'num_games_owned': 1084, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1621987146}
review:
Little shorter than I hoped it would be but the puzzles were fun to solve and it had more than a few very memorable moments. Took me just under 4 hours to reach the (an?) ending. 

Did you like Primordia? Looking for something from the same team? I think you'll get your money's worth. 

Everyone else? Maybe skip / wait for a sale, this positive review is right on the edge. 

[b]Pros / Cons:[/b]

+ The story is a very human one and there were some characters and moments that really shined. 
+ Spooky little point-and-click adventure game with some interesting puzzles
+ Genuinely unsettling experience at times; great horror atmosphere when it leaned fully dark
~ I mean this with love but the amount of literary metaphor and reference felt like it was aspiring to greater revelations than this story was actually able to tell. It fell short, which had the retroactive experience of making all of that... all seem pretentious? I could see other people enjoying it but it didn't do it for me. 
- Was left just wishing there had been more puzzle-y meat to the game but I felt I got my money's worth.
- The nu metal WYCKYD CARNIVAL aesthetic / metaphor of the early game is... honestly bizarre as hell and kind of pulled me out of the horror at times. (The Beksiński/Geiger-esque horror elements are much better executed, just wish there had been more of it.) I am still wondering if it's intentionally trying to capture an early 00's sensibility or something.
developer_response: Thanks for this detailed, balanced, and ultimately generous review! Certainly wish you had no cons, but I'm glad you liked it all told!

author: {'steamid': '76561198040659283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1621984697}

author: {'steamid': '76561198005733650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1621980771}
review:
Another great adventure from this developer. 

Compared to their previous game, it is shorter, the tone is more serious(no more robot sidekick telling bad jokes, although there's still some funny lines here and there, so it's not completely devoid of humor), the writing is more "abstract"(which was to be expected since the whole game goes on within one's mind) but just as good - as are the puzzles and characters.

And speaking of puzzles, you have even a FPS minigame in it. I don't think I've ever seen such a thing in the classic games, so that counts as a point for innovation in my book.
developer_response: Thank you so much! Glad you enjoyed it, especially since you came from Primordia. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197972346426', 'num_games_owned': 1692, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1621976436}
review:
A wonderfully streamlined adventure game. I don't feel like it lasted as long as Primordia, but that's probably because I spent less time getting stuck at parts. Not to say it's a breeze to play, but it definitely flowed better in my experience.

The subject matter is 100% meta-narrative; choosing instead to tell a story within the protagonist's psyche, and making reference to real world events that it chooses not to elaborate upon. It's an interesting approach, and a breath of fresh air for adventure game enthusiasts.

It's dark, and demented, with an art style and soundtrack that will scratch at the rusty parts of your brain. It's as thrilling as it is unique.

Another masterpiece from Wormwood studios. Highly recommend.
developer_response: Thank you so much!

author: {'steamid': '76561198066530789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1621974806}
review:
This game, not as expected from Wormwood studio's.. it was even greater!
I have played Primordia a few times and I loved the humorous tone of that game. This game is more serious but it kept me just as engaged throughout albeit for different reasons.
It covers a very hard topic for a game beautifully and in a way that keeps you engaged. With the many options you get throughout the game it seems there is some good replayability and I even wanted to restart right after the credits screen.

The writing grabs the player and the puzzles where not hard at all. I got the feeling that the player truely has influence on the outcome of the story that is being told. The ending of the game resonated well with me and hopefully the game can also deliver this with other players.

In my opinion a masterpiece of a game that any adult should play and it is definitely worth it's money!
ps. if you have not player Primordia also grab that as the artstyle and writing are just as good :)
developer_response:
You rascal -- my heart dropped as I started reading the review. :)

In seriousness, thank you for the kind words.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134366680', 'num_games_owned': 841, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1621973849}
review:
Strangeland is surreal, nightmarish and probably a way for the writer to deal with his inner demons. If you have been in a dark place before, doubting yourself, your life, your decisions, you might find themes in this game that resonate with these feelings. 

The visuals are fantastic and bleak, the voice acting is on point and I LOVE that every dialogue is fully voiced, there are some quality of life additions to some puzzles ([spoiler]you have to bring an item to somewhere 7-8 times but when you do it twice, the game shows the rest as a cutscene [/spoiler]) and as an adventure it's not that hard at all, you can get an idea of what to do next. If you stuck, there's an in game hint system, calling the payphone.

I only stuck once for maybe 20 minutes at a puzzle that I knew what I had to do but I couldn't understand the solution. I just had to LISTEN instead of READ :D

This is not a carefree adventure though, nor a fairytale. This deals with heavy themes, the writing is also vague at times and I think you need to be in the right mindset to appreciate it.

Still totally worth it and for that price it's a steal.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this kind review, which accurately reads the author's intention. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198023965464', 'num_games_owned': 852, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1621794604}

author: {'steamid': '76561198122874857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1641386840}
review:
I was betatester of this game and I have played it several times so I know what I am talking about when making this review. First of all, don’t expect another Primordia. This game is very different because it was made from grieve, it was made not only from the heart but the very soul itself (if you want to know the inspirations for the game, just google Strangeland inspirations). It is complicated to talk about the game without spoilers, but I will try.
The game is strange, yes, bizarre, disconcerting until you keep putting all the pieces together. Puzzles are logical, you have a helping hot line so it is difficult to get stuck. Visuals are superb, the sound is outstanding and the characters… well, it is better you discover them yourself.
It’s a game that Goya would have painted if he could. It’s a game that Borges would had written if he could. It’s a game that touches you, that makes you suffer with the main character, but hey, there is no gain without pain. Don’t expect a Disney story here. 
To nitpick, I would say there are too many quotes in the game, but that’s how the author wanted to write it, so who am I to judge?
Is it a game for everybody? Probably not, as The Cat Lady or Fran Bow. But if you are not afraid of darkness, madness, you like H. R. Giger work, or just want to get on board on a trip through a strange Carnival or Theme Park, you will enjoy it as much as I did.
I strongly recommend to replay the game with annotations. You will learn a lot from a lot of things, and you will find out why the game is like it is. 
And as The Smiths used to say, “There is a light that never goes out…”
developer_response:
Thank you so much, Walas!

I look forward to seeing you translate our humble script into Spanish poetry! :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198088213112', 'num_games_owned': 1212, 'num_reviews': 256, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 631, 'last_played': 1644317649}
review:
Wormwood Studios did a smart move when they decided not to release a Primorida sequel next but something completly different, so it doesn't have to compete with the fomer that much.
What you'll here get is an atmospheric, dark game with many layers of metaphors where you play a person coping with personal struggles. The puzzles are quite simple and straight-forward and come with a comprehensive ingame hint system. They're just there for the flow basically, so if you are a die-hard puzzler, you might be disappointed, but if you're here to embrace a well-told and well-presented story, you'll like it.
What I'm not sure about are the multiple endings. In Primordia every ending brought its own ambivalence which made you question yourself whether you did the right thing. In opposite, "good" and "bad" endings are easy to identify here and they feel like they have less impact. But still, the endings aren't pure letdown, don't get me wrong - they do a good job in tying all metaphors, allusions and story bits together, which might be even more important for the kind of story we have here.
Definitly an outstanding game on its own!
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed it! I'm not sure straight sequels are ever something I'd want to do, but exploring similar themes, philosophies, etc. is definitely on the table. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198038181840', 'num_games_owned': 972, 'num_reviews': 524, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1615815800}
review:
Wormwood Studios and Wadjet Eye Games really set the bar for modern Point and Clicks with Primordia so it's understandable to have high expectations for their most recent release. And they deliver. My advice:  It's not a sequel, so go in with an open mind and enjoy it for what it is.

Another spectacular point and click entry by Wormwood Studios and Wadjet Eye. As expected, it's deeply philosophical, very well written, and features top notch voice acting, and striking pixel art.

For more niche curation, follow me at: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/27440015-CSH-Picone/
developer_response: Many thanks for the kind words!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030422133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1622141963}

developer_response: Ha, forgot I have to be on this "official" account at the moment to post a developer response -- anyway, my sentiments were expressed below! Many thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561199019661982', 'num_games_owned': 134, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1621099155}
review:
Strangeland deserves all the praise.
It is rare that my high expectations can be surpassed. And let me tell you, this time my expectations were really high. Not just that I read the beautiful Dev commentaries (a thing you should do as well, they are amazing), but also because I dove into the inspirations. I read Something Wicked This Way Comes by Ray Bradbury, looked at Goya's art and researched the american carnival. But nothing could prepare me for the ride to come.

No spoilers here, but when I entered Strangeland, I was blown away. Not by the graphics, because that's the only "normal" thing about Strangeland. You could say the look is retro-classic or something. But it is unique in it's way of combining pixelart with a black-orange-violet color palette. Still, this is not the point that makes this point-and-click so fantastic. No, I was blown away by the music, the weird organic-mechanic look of everything, the voice-over that is truly outstanding. And of course I was intrigued to find out about this strange woman falling down the well.

So I entered this weird carnival and never really left again. The story captivated me, sucked me in and threw so many mysteries at me I couldn't help but be overwhelmed. At first, some of the puzzles seemed off to me, but then I got a hold on the game's way of thinking. To a point that I stopped playing and started being the stranger in a strange land. I love every single character that I encountered. I made my way through the realms of my own consciousness and what i found was even darker than expected. Let me tell you: The more you peel off this game, the deeper you look into your own soul.

I can only recommend to play Strangeland on a summer's evening, when the sun starts to vanish behind the trees and the shades grow larger. Then you will feel as uneasy as I did when you enter the clowns mouth, and you will shiver when the phone rings. This is a masterpiece of game development, and the devs fully understood how to get to a player's mind.

See the first part of my walkthrough here on [url=https://youtu.be/pdATM4tn9rA]Youtube[/url]. Spoilers ahead!

More indiegames here in my curator group [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/IGR_daily]IGR Daily[/url]
developer_response: Thank you so much for your generous and beautiful words about our game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198139512856', 'num_games_owned': 354, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1621750751}
review:
Egyértelműen kijelenthető, hogy érdemes volt várni a Wormwood Studios új játékára, a Strangelandre. A nagyszerű képi megvalósítás mellé egy metaforákkal teli, allegorikus történetet kapunk, nagyon komoly témával. Ez viszont senkit se riasszon vissza. A melankolikus cselekmény ezúttal is tanító jellegű lett, miszerint a sötétség, illetve sötét dolgok mellett mindig ott lakozik valahol a fény is, amelybe tanulva a hibáinkból, bármikor kiléphetünk. A Strangeland pontosan erre próbál megtanítani bennünket, és teszi mindezt a lehető leggördülékenyebb módon. Ha tehetitek, mindenképp adjatok neki egy esélyt.

Teljes cikk: https://www.adventuregames.hu/tesztek/strangeland-az-emberi-elme-sotet-bugyrai
Videotesz: https://youtu.be/O6O9PURMNvE
developer_response: Nagyon köszönöm! Hálás a kedves szavakért.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044901263', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1664716134}
review:
An amazing experience, with a beautiful prose, clever worlds and words, quality and disturbing art without being openly horrible, immersive OST and voice acting. It's weird in all the right ways, and it sucks you in.
I was honored to play it to test it with fresh eyes for bugs and ease-of-use checks in certain later sections, and I can't find the words to say how charmed and moved the game made me. A true experience. Highly recommended.
developer_response: Thank you so much!
